I owe it to myself.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toTechScapeFree weekly newsletterA weekly dive in to how technology is shaping our livesEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionAs a responsive exercise, Creative Acts gives participants physical masks to paint. On the outside o the mask theyâ€™re asked to portray how they believe society perceives them; on its inside, how they see themselves. On his mask, Garcia wrote â€œcondemnedâ€ with cracks on the outside, to reflect his sentence of life without parole. â€œBut I want to be bigger than that,â€ he said, â€œso on the inside I painted a sunset, full of life, so bright.â€Working through â€˜a lot of painâ€™ in virtual realityReflecting on her experience in VR six months ago, Royal shares that she initially â€œsaw a lot of painâ€ when the group started. â€œBut by the end, I saw smiles on the faces of all these women and the ability to trust somebody again,â€ she said. Released from solitary confinement within two months after donning the headset, Royal still conducts unified breathwork she learned from the program with people in the prison if she senses conflict.View image in fullscreenSome incarcerated people have reported transformative experiences when using the VR devices.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of  Creative ActsGarcia similarly retains his meditation practice, oftentimes putting in earbuds to quiet his surroundings, slowly counting while envisioning a sunset. Matias Magana, another program participant at Valley State, shares that now he says hello to individuals he never would have spoken to had it not been for his Creative Acts group. For him, â€œweâ€™re breaking cultural boundariesâ€. And Ortega, who spoke sporadically on a Tuesday when he had gone to Creative Actsâ€™ office to pick up some of his old art, says that he now finds himself â€œbeing comfortable in the uncomfortableâ€. His birthday was the second to last day of his Creative Actsâ€™ experience; he still has the sticky notes the facilitators put on his â€œtherapeutic moduleâ€ with birthday wishes from everyone.Closing a solitary unit after virtual reality workshopsIn response to Creative Acts programming, facilities are witnessing an immense change. â€œPrison is toxic. You become accustomed to it: the corruption, the duplicitousness. Hell is normalized,â€ Ortega said. But prisons that have piloted the VR program report a 96% reduction in infractions from incarcerated participants in solitary confinement, according to Creative Acts. Corcoran state prison in rural centralCaliforniasaw the number of infractions of the men in solitary go from 735 to one after one week-long session. One of Corcoran wardens commuted so many solitary confinement sentences that the facility closed one of its four buildings dedicated to the practice.The organization attributes this level of transformation to the role that art plays in encouraging people to redirect their anger, share and process their trauma, and envision, quite literally with the help of VR, a world beyond the bars that confine them.Pros and cons of tech in prisonsIntroducing new technology into prisons has inspired skepticism as well as praise. Making available tablets with texting, email and books en masse in prisons has also made way for anotherpredatory profit channelfor companies, increased the ability to further surveil incarcerated people, and createdfalse promises of more connectionoreducation. Many argue that tech is just a bandage solution that only serves to maintain an inhumane carceral system. Others say that working with the same prisons that continue to incarcerate people in droves cannot possibly benefit those inside. Williams has grappled with these critiques.I learned that, even if someone has nothing in common with me, I can find a way to connect with themSamantha â€˜Royalâ€™ Tovarâ€œAnything can be used to cause harm, [and] people will always make money off of anything that goes into prisons, so the benefits for the people inside, to me, outweigh the issues,â€ Williams says when discussing the introduction of tablets and other technology inside prisons. For the Creative Actsâ€™ founder, the key to administering VR is by utilizing team members who have endured incarceration themselves to thoughtfully facilitate the experience as well as providing trauma-informed art exercises paired with every scene. As for criticisms about working with the California department of corrections and rehabilitation rather than against it, Williams has a consistent motto: â€œDo you want to be right, or do you want to make change? You canâ€™t make deep cultural change without including the people that work there.â€View image in fullscreenCritiques of the VR program have included that it helps maintain an inhumane carceral system.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of Creative ActsStill, the non-profit must go the financial and physical lengths of bringing VR inside prisons while many of the scenes that participants interact with in their headsets are just on the other side of their cell walls. However, participants said the small doses of virtual freedom and exposure to the outside world shifted their behaviors and perceptions more than solitary confinement ever did.â€œI learned that, even if someone has nothing in common with me, I can find a way to connect with them,â€ Royal shares. She will parole from prison in May and feels more confident in her ability to build a community for herself. For Ortega, Creative Acts laid an emotional foundation that informs the work heâ€™s doing upon release. â€œI feel content, Iâ€™m more tolerant, people call me reliable again. I go to AA and NA meetings, Iâ€™m in school. I actually started my own program. Itâ€™s called Dream Catchers. Iâ€™m trying to catch that dream that I didnâ€™t catch before.â€Explore more on these topicsVirtual realityUS prisonsCaliforniaSolitary confinementWest CoastfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: See how Australiaâ€™s first 3D-printed multi-storey house is being built: four bedrooms in five weeks | Housing | The Guardian
description: The slab has been laid, a frame is being printed and cement piping that looks like soft serve is poured by robotic crane
Author: Cait Kelly
Headline: The slab has been laid, a frame is being printed and cement piping that looks like soft serve is poured by robotic crane
Content: â€˜Iâ€™m going to live in it personally,â€™ Luyten CEO Ahmed Mahil says of the 3D house his firm is building in the Melbourne suburb of Wyndham.Photograph: LuytenView image in fullscreenâ€˜Iâ€™m going to live in it personally,â€™ Luyten CEO Ahmed Mahil says of the 3D house his firm is building in the Melbourne suburb of Wyndham.Photograph: LuytenHousingSee how Australiaâ€™s first 3D-printed multi-storey house is being built: four bedrooms in five weeksThe slab has been laid, a frame is being printed and cement piping that looks like soft serve is poured by robotic craneEx-Tropical Cyclone Alfred LIVE: latest news and updatesGet ourbreaking news email,free appordaily news podcastCait KellyInequality reporterSat 8 Mar 2025 14.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 19.00 ESTShareIn a quiet street in the city of Wyndham, in Melbourneâ€™s outer western suburbs, a house is being built. The slab has been laid, the frame is being printed.Almost silently, cement piping that looks like soft-serve ice-cream is methodically poured by a giant robotic crane.This will be Australiaâ€™s first 3D-printed multi-storey house.Affluent suburbs targeted in Victorian government move to seize planning controls to build more homesRead moreâ€œIâ€™m going to live in it personally,â€ says Ahmed Mahil, the CEO of Luyten, the Melbourne-based company that is printing the house.â€œIâ€™m not just selling it to people, I actually trust the science behind it.â€At the heart of Australiaâ€™s housing crisis lies a central issue: there are not enough homes. Also, over the past 15 years, weâ€™ve become slower at building them.Sign up for Guardian Australiaâ€™s breaking news emailThe average build time for standalone houses has slid from nine months to 12.7 months (a 40% increase), while apartment construction timelines have blown out from 18.5 months to 33.3 months, Master Builders Association data shows.Mahil says he is about to move into the answer to that problem.Melbourne 3D house construction interactive3D printing shaves huge chunks of months off a build. Mahilâ€™s house, which will have four bedrooms and five toilets, will be completed within five weeks.â€œThe printing itself is about three weeks, and then to put the roof and the lighting and all the other services, that will take us about five weeks,â€ he says. â€œThen I can move and live inside it.â€While there has been no Australian research into the cost differences between traditional brick and mortar builds and 3D ones, Mahil says he got comparative quotes for his house.LiveHow did Australia's housing market get so bad, and is it all negative gearing's fault? â€“ videoâ€œI have three quotations, and the best of them, [3D printing] comes cheaper at 25% to 30% [than traditional builds],â€ he says. Mahil did not tell Guardian Australia how much it is costing to print his home.Australiaâ€™s first 3D-printed home â€“ a one-bedroom inNew South Walesthat was completed in May 2023, took just two days to construct. Overseas, entire suburbs are being printed and built. Last year, in Wolf Ranch, a suburb in Georgetown, Texas, 100 homes were printed.Melbourne 3D house construction interactiveGovernments are warming to the idea.In NSW, the Dubbo 3D-printed social housing project â€“ two modern two-bedroom duplexes â€“ is about to be completed. Starting late last year, it took about two weeks to finish construction of all internal and external walls. Indigenous tenants are expected to move in to the building by the end of March.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toBreaking News AustraliaFree newsletterGet the most important news as it breaksEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionGuardian Australia understands the Dubbo project will cost the government $814,000, and is estimated to cost 10-20% less than a traditional build.The NSW housing minister, Rose Jackson, says her government opted for 3D printing because it wants to deliver more houses, more quickly. She calls 3D-printed houses â€œa gamechangerâ€.â€œItâ€™s faster to construct, cheaper to build, and more environmentally-friendly than traditional construction methods because it cuts down on material waste,â€ she says.There are also lower environmental impacts. Two weeks ago, a study published in the Journal of Building Engineering, looking at the environmental impact of a build in Canada, found the technology has the potential â€œto support sustainable and efficient construction, particularly in remote locationsâ€. â€œHowever, material consumption and transportation remain significant contributors to environmental impact,â€ it said.Property developer Kavitha Vipulananda is now completing her PhD in housing at the University of Melbourne. She says there are environmental benefits with 3D-printing homes â€“ but other issues are also in play.3D printing homes in urban environments and the middle ring suburbs that sit just outside the CBD and inner-city neighbourhoods is â€œa bit trickyâ€, Vipulananda says, pointing to the size and manoeuvrability of the 3D printer. â€œYou can only really do houses at the moment.â€Banks are also reluctant, for now, to fund developers to 3D print homes because it is a new technology, she says. Prospective customers are also limited in the design options to choose from. â€œIt just needs to be more flexible on sites and more flexible for consumers.â€Michael Fotheringham, the AustralianHousingand Urban Research Institute managing director, says 3D printing could help the federal government meet its target of 1.2m homes in five years, but there are a lot of unknowns.â€œWeâ€™re really early days with this stuff in terms of actually delivering housing,â€ Fotheringham says. â€œI think weâ€™re really more at a demonstrating potential than delivering in any mainstream sense.â€Fotheringham says more research is needed on the insulation and energy efficacy of the builds.â€œWe need to make sure that weâ€™re building housing that is suitable for our climate â€¦ and energy efficient going forward,â€ he says.While alternate building strategies are worth exploring, Fotheringham says governments should concentrate on more high-density housing close to the CBD.â€œ3D printing probably plays a role in that infield development quite effectively,â€ he says, â€œbecause of its pace of delivery, itâ€™s less disruption to communities.â€Explore more on these topicsHousingInequalityMelbourneVictoriaNew South Wales3D printingfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Worldâ€™s hottest brandâ€™: how Miu Miu defied sales plunge in fashion industry | Fashion | The Guardian
description: As luxury firms struggle worldwide, the â€˜knowingly coolâ€™ label is posting record-breaking sales figures
Author: Morwenna Ferrier
Headline: As luxury firms struggle worldwide, the â€˜knowingly coolâ€™ label is posting record-breaking sales figures
Content: Sydney Sweeney, left, and tennis star Coco Gauff wearing Miu Miu at last weekâ€™s Oscars, while Willem Dafoe walks the catwalk for the labelâ€™s spring-summer collection. Photogaphs by PA and Rex/ShutterstockComposite: PA and Rex/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenSydney Sweeney, left, and tennis star Coco Gauff wearing Miu Miu at last weekâ€™s Oscars, while Willem Dafoe walks the catwalk for the labelâ€™s spring-summer collection. Photogaphs by PA and Rex/ShutterstockComposite: PA and Rex/ShutterstockThe ObserverFashionâ€˜Worldâ€™s hottest brandâ€™: how Miu Miu defied sales plunge in fashion industryAs luxury firms struggle worldwide, the â€˜knowingly coolâ€™ label is posting record-breaking sales figuresMorwenna FerrierSat 8 Mar 2025 12.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 15.15 ESTShareWhile profits fall across the luxury fashion industry, one kooky Italian label is posting record-breaking sales figures.For a global industry worth almost Â£1.5tn, fashion is having a bruising time. Last month London fashion week had such a small number of catwalk shows it shrank to a weekend. Even super-conglomerate LVMH â€“ which includes Dior, Fendi, Louis Vuitton and most of the drinks brands in your cocktail cabinet â€“lost a fifth of its profits last year.Yet the Italian brand Miu Miu almostdoubled its profitsthis year, hitting close to Â£1bn in sales and being named â€œhottest brand in the worldâ€ by influential search site Lyst for the second year running. Retail sales were up 93%.Miu Miu is owned by the Prada Group, a small conglomerate overseen by Miuccia Prada â€“ including the well-known Prada label. In 1992, around 14 years after she started working for her familyâ€™s business, Mrs Prada â€“ as sheâ€™s known in the industry â€“ launched a cheaper womenswear subsidiary inspired by the sort of clothes (cardigans, skirts, wearable shoes) she wanted for her own wardrobe. Miu Miu is Miucciaâ€™s nickname.The label has always been a bit cooler, and crucially a little bit cheaper than many luxury fashion brands. But its recent success is down to more than just clothes. Itâ€™s the shows, the models, the campaigns and â€“ the white whale of modern designers â€“ Mrs Pradaâ€™s knack for turning out a viral trend.Over its past five golden years, Miu Miuâ€™s huge fashion hits have included amicro mini skirtwith a raw hem that became so famous it spawned its ownInstagram account; satin ballet pumps, which started an (ongoing) race for ballet shoes on the high street;Â£750 silk briefsdesigned to be worn without trousers; narrow framed spectacles, and even plasters on toes. And thatâ€™s before we get to the It bags (the most liked luxury item on Vinted right now is a Miu Miu metallic handbag). For a designer who says she is vehemently opposed to trends, Mrs Prada has a gift for starting them.View image in fullscreenBritish actress Raffey Cassidy attends the 2025 Vanity Fair Oscar party in a Miu Miu dress.Photograph: Daniele Venturelli/Getty Imagesâ€œWhat I like about Miu Miu is that itâ€™s irreverent,â€ says Elektra Kotsoni, deputy director forVogueBusiness and Runway. But itâ€™s also strangely familiar. Kotsoni thinks this sets Miu Miu apart from other brands: â€œThe mishmash of references in every collection basically seems to reflect what women already have in their wardrobes,â€ she says. â€œEveryone [can] dress in the style of Miu Miu even if they canâ€™t afford to buy it.â€Fashion is as much about how you wear clothes as the clothes themselves, says Dal Chodha, editor and pathway leader of St Martinâ€™s fashion communication course. â€œI have started to see a lot of young men wearing Miu Miu-style shrunken womenâ€™s cardigans around college. And I understand why â€“ [the look] has a certain freshness; it feels knowingly cool.â€Mrs Prada also has an uncanny eye for spotting creative talent â€“ in the first flush of fame, making a comeback or just perennially cool. A year before Drew Barrymoreâ€™s iconic turn inScreamin 1997, she fronted a Miu Miu campaign. Lupito Nyongâ€™o was Miu Miuâ€™s girl the year she won the Oscar for best supporting actress.Emma Corrin, fresh fromThe Crownand sporting an elfin cut, has also fronted a campaign. Tennis star Coco Gauff and actor Sydney Sweeney both picked Miu Miu gowns for this yearâ€™sVanity FairOscar party.Willem Dafoe, 69, closed the last Miu Miu show, and so has Kristin Scott Thomas, 64. The autumn/winter 2024 show included Qin Huilan, a 70-year-old Chinese doctor from Shanghai,picked from Instagram. Miu Miu has a talent for appealing to women who want to see themselves reflected on the catwalk.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toFashion StatementFree weekly newsletterStyle, with substance: what's really trending this week, a roundup of the best fashion journalism and your wardrobe dilemmas solvedEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionâ€œ[Miu Miu is created by] women of different generationsâ€ says Kotsoni. â€œYour mum can wear it as well as your daughter.â€The label also excels outside the world of fashion. Many brands have cultural projects, but Miu Miuâ€™s are exceptional. Directors such as Miranda July, ChloÃ« Sevigny and Joanna Hogg have made films for Miu Miuâ€™s Womenâ€™s Tales short film initiative.The brand has just announced the second year of the Miu Miu literary club to be held at Milan design week. Last yearâ€™s Summer Reads event â€“ when the brand gave away feminist books for free at news stands around the world â€“ was a huge hit.Finally for fashion editors, their love of Miu Miu may be all about the timing. The brand shows in Paris on the final day of the final fashion week of the season. If something is as much fun as Miu Miu, youâ€™re more likely to remember it.Explore more on these topicsFashionThe ObserverShareReuse this content

title: Jack White review â€“ rockâ€™nâ€™roll showman makes believers of us all  | Jack White | The Guardian
description: Touring his 2024 solo album No Name in a barnstorming gig, the former White Stripe plays fast and loose with the truth but is absolutely the real deal
Author: Kitty Empire
Headline: Touring his 2024 solo album No Name in a barnstorming gig, the former White Stripe plays fast and loose with the truth but is absolutely the real deal
Content: â€˜Guitar shock and aweâ€™: Jack White at Troxy.Photograph: David James SwansonView image in fullscreenâ€˜Guitar shock and aweâ€™: Jack White at Troxy.Photograph: David James SwansonKitty Empire's artist of the weekJack WhiteReviewJack White review â€“ rockâ€™nâ€™roll showman makes believers of us allTroxy, LondonTouring his 2024 solo album No Name in a barnstorming gig, the former White Stripe plays fast and loose with the truth but is absolutely the real dealKitty EmpireSat 8 Mar 2025 09.00 ESTShareâ€œDo you believe me yet?â€ yellsJack Whitefrom the lip of the stage, a few songs into his second nightâ€™s work at this classy art deco venue in east London. Itâ€™s a very Jack White kind of location: highly stylised, lovingly restored, but not entirely removed from its unglamorous surroundings.Lit in deep blue and strobing white, the colour palette of his solo career, White and his band have played tracks from his most recent album, the surprise-releasedNo Name, firsthanded out freeon white-label vinyl to unsuspecting shoppers at Third Man stores in Nashville, Detroit and London last summer (Third Man Records is Whiteâ€™s own imprint).Itâ€™s Rough on Rats (If Youâ€™re Asking)is a particularly rousing workout full of guitar shock and awe, from an album that has drawn relieved and delighted comparisons to Whiteâ€™s first band,the White Stripes.Heâ€™s also stormed throughBlack Math, from the White Stripesâ€™ fourth album, 2003â€™sElephant, a disc recorded entirely on analogue gear at Toe Rag Studios in Homerton, Hackney, just a few miles down the road. Roaming across his discography, White and his band have just absolutely pulverisedBroken Boy Soldierâ€“ a 2006 cut fromthe Raconteurs, another White side outfit. Itâ€™s virtually unrecognisable in this early 70s acid-blues-rock version. Mini whirlpools of flailing bodies ebb and flow through it all.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Johnny Guitar, from Hackney.â€™Photograph: David James SwansonWhite began this gig with an affirmation â€“ that â€œeverything that comes out of my mouth tonight will be the truth!â€ A little while later, though, he introduces himself as â€œJohnny Guitar, from Hackneyâ€. You canâ€™t help but grin. Itâ€™s 2025, the postwar world order is in grave flux, but we are on surprisingly steady ground here tonight. Kaleidoscopic garage-punk blues fills the air, and a mischievous artist who always delivers is playing fast and loose in more ways than one.Since White first started damaging speaker cones as half of the White Stripes in the early 00s, this Detroit-born Nashville transplant has enjoyed a relationship with fact perhaps best described as capricious. White Stripes drummer Meg White being his â€œsisterâ€ was a key foundational sleight of hand.But White doesnâ€™t actually want audiences to believe every tall tale he tells. A keen student of legends past, he has long been drawn to obfuscation and myth-making â€“ creative strategies that go back to Bob Dylan and beyond, to blues people and showfolk of all kinds.Rather, White wants us to believeinhim â€“ in the intensity with which he curates his 360-degree aesthetic, and in the righteousness of the sound-world he has manifested from source materials brimming with raw, pre-modern resonance.Most of all, he wants us to be won over by the fervour with which all this is delivered. He stalks around in bone-white shoes, shaking his replenished mop of curly black hair (it was short and blue for a while). He faces off against the keys player, wears grooves in the stage. The band make everything heavy and roiling, then they pull out a blithe, garage-pop song such as the White Stripesâ€™Youâ€™re Pretty Good Looking (For a Girl).The viral terrace-chant riff to Seven Nation Army causes the usually immune security guards to whip their heads aroundThereâ€™s never been a bad set of musicians backing this showboating guitarist, but tonightâ€™s trio â€“ go-to drummer Patrick Keeler (the Raconteurs), bassist Dominic Davis (from the Buzzards, a previous White backing band) and Bobby Emmett, a relative new boy vamping on keys, who wears his shades all night â€“ are a particularly taut lineup. White joins Emmett at his organ station for a keyboard-heavy, rococo romp through the White Stripesâ€™Apple Blossom. Elsewhere, there are long, jam-like codas, near-constant segues; at one point, Iggy and the Stoogesâ€™ I Wanna Be Your Dog emerges out of the squall.The encore is nearly as long as the first set. At the end, the viral terrace-chant riff to Seven Nation Army causes the security guards â€“ normally immune to whatever music is going on behind them â€“ to whip their heads around. Somewhere in the middle isArchbishop Harold Holmes, an instant classic White tune from the new album, where truth, falsehood, patter and faith are remixed to a Led Zeppelin-like swinging chug.In the lyrics, White plays the itinerant preacher, coming to your town. It is, in part, a riff of hucksters ancient and modern, promising a cure for all ills. â€œAnd if you are suffering a strange sickness,â€ White hisses, â€œOr someone is blocking up all of your success, you need to see me right away so I can fix this.â€The many parallels between religious and musical spectacle are well studied but tonight, White makes a very convincing salesman of rockâ€™nâ€™rollâ€™s fundamentals. Under all the bluster, his belief in the power of pacy, sly electric blues to cure a lot of ills remains very persuasive. He really is the kind of showman who can make you feel better for a while.Watch the video for Thatâ€™s How Iâ€™m Feeling by Jack White.Explore more on these topicsJack WhiteKitty Empire's artist of the weekThe White StripesThe RaconteursPop and rockreviewsShareReuse this content

title: Meet-cutes, boysâ€™ bedrooms and buff bodies: meet the people behind TikTokâ€™s viral vox pop accounts | Life and style | The Guardian
description: From the woman who asks to see teenage boysâ€™ rooms to the gang who want to know how couples found love, some people are attracting a huge following (and financial rewards) from being nosy - and asking one killer question
Author: Michael Segalov
Headline: From the woman who asks to see teenage boysâ€™ rooms to the gang who want to know how couples found love, some people are attracting a huge following (and financial rewards) from being nosy - and asking one killer question
Content: Rachel Coster: â€˜A lot of boys have no idea whatâ€™s in their room.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianView image in fullscreenRachel Coster: â€˜A lot of boys have no idea whatâ€™s in their room.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianLife and styleMeet-cutes, boysâ€™ bedrooms and buff bodies: meet the people behind TikTokâ€™s viral vox pop accountsFrom the woman who asks to see teenage boysâ€™ rooms to the gang who want to know how couples found love, some people are attracting a huge following (and financial rewards) from being nosy - and asking one killer questionMichael SegalovSat 8 Mar 2025 09.00 ESTShareâ€˜Boy, will you show me your room?â€™Rachel Coster,@boyroomshowTikTok followers: 232,400Instagram followers: 71,400Rachel Coster (pictured above) loves boys. â€œTheyâ€™re fun,â€ she says. â€œIÂ love to date them, befriend them, and see how they decorate their bedrooms. Women, I think, from childhood are taught how to keep a home. Itâ€™s less ingrained in the culture of raising young men, so a lot of them are misguided when it comes to domesticity.â€New York-based Coster, 28, is a comedian with aÂ background in film production. During the Sag-Aftra film and television actorsâ€™ strike in Hollywood, jobs were few and far between. â€œI sent a few one-sentence ideas to a new social media production company for short-form digital shows,â€ she says. â€œBoy Room was one of my pitches: Boy, will you show me your room?â€A proof-of-concept was shot at a friendâ€™shouse. â€œHeÂ told me a girl had been over the previous night, refusing to stay because of the mess, then asked what he should do to change his room.â€ On camera, Coster surveyed the scene. â€œThrow out the garbage, put your clothes in a dresser, and put sheets on your bed. HeÂ nodded along, gratefully.â€At first, she didnâ€™t tell participants that her focus was untidy rooms. â€œBut turns out these boys donâ€™t feel shame about their messiness,â€ she says. â€œIt made no difference if we told them. Some boys, it transpires, are proud of their mess. Others do start to reflect on their choices in an outsiderâ€™s presence: youâ€™re right,Â whydoI have a 30-month-old boiled egg on myÂ bedside table?â€There are plenty of messy-home TV formats, butÂ Costerâ€™s tone is different: nonâ€‘judgmental. She has shot at least 40Â episodes now, and themes are emerging. â€œA lot of boys have no idea whatâ€™s in their room: a housemate left that; an ex-girlfriend this. Lots of garbage. They often lack ownership of their space. And thereâ€™s a lack of concern for their cleanliness and comfort. Like,whydo you want to sleep on a yellowing pillow, a stained, broken mattress and a disgusting quilt? Itâ€™s so easily fixable.â€The intimacy of the format is what makes it endearing. â€œIn the same way we like to watch Architectural Digest on YouTube to see how the rich and famous live, itâ€™s also nice to see how normals do.â€ Itâ€™s this, she believes, alongside some of the muckier moments captured (â€œThink extremely yeasty smells or baked-in cigarette stench â€“ one boy had maybe 7,000 vapes in a drawer and behind his bedâ€) that keep viewers coming back. â€œNothing gets more comments,â€ she says, â€œthan a handsome boy living in total squalor.â€â€˜How did you two meet?â€™Jeremy Bernstein, Aaron Feinberg and Victor Lee (below, from left),@meetcutesnycTikTok followers:1.8 millionInstagram followers:2.9 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜Early on, we were only looking for the best meet-cute stories.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianTwo years ago, friends Aaron Feinberg, Jeremy Bernstein and Victor Lee werenâ€™t even onTikTok. Now, itâ€™s an occupation for the three 30-year-old New Yorkers. Feinberg handles partnerships and collaborations; LeeÂ oversees editing and posting; Bernstein is the voice, politely accosting random couples on the street, and probing into their relationships.It was Leeâ€™s baby, initially. He was working in his family clothes manufacturing business. â€œThe first question you ask a couple,â€ he says, â€œis where did you guys meet? Maybe it could be something â€¦ â€ He floated the idea of asking strangers on camera past Feinberg.â€œI thought it was fun,â€ says Feinberg. â€œWe didnâ€™t realise what it could become, but I knew we had the perfect person to ask the questions in Jeremy, who wouldnâ€™t be afraid to stop people â€“ and he won the most distinguished voice award at high school.â€Bernstein wasnâ€™t interested at first. â€œI was selling renewable energy on the street, so, yes, I was always approaching strangers. But when Aaron suggested we do this, I took quite a lot of convincing.â€ However, interviewees were receptive to the concept from the getâ€‘go, says Bernstein, â€œalthough we had to learn about the physicality. How to approach someone in a non-threatening way is key,â€ he says. â€œFirstly, itâ€™s body language â€“ making yourself small and smiley. Then, get to the â€˜Are you two a couple? How did you meet?â€™ questions immediately. Once people hear that, they relax.â€They have heard some remarkable stories: highâ€‘school sweethearts, chance encounters, arranged marriages. â€œMy favourite,â€ says Lee, â€œis the onewe titled Tunnel Vision.â€ In it an older gentleman who was a train supervisor at Grand Central station explains how he met his wife, 30 years ago. For days, he kept moving trains on to the platform he worked nearest to, to try to find a beautiful woman he had noticed getting out of a carriage. She grins, standing next to him, as he tells the story, and says: â€œI had no idea!â€Itâ€™s no wonder people love it. The group have started working on a book, and begun franchising. â€œWeâ€™ve just opened aMeetCutes London account,â€ says Feinberg â€“ a British friend goes out to record, â€œand weâ€™re interviewing to hire people in Paris and Madrid. Weâ€™reÂ off camera, so we can recreate it globally.â€To date, the lads have interviewed maybe 7,000 couples, but only post a small fraction. â€œEarly on, we were only looking for the best meet-cute stories,â€ says Bernstein. â€œNow weâ€™re also asking about the relationship: whatâ€™s your favourite thing about your partner? What advice do you have for a new couple?â€They have each used these lessons in their own love lives. â€œMy favourite piece of advice, which Iâ€™ve taken into my relationship, is â€˜Never stop datingâ€™,â€ says Lee. â€œIâ€™ve been with my fiancee for six years. Itâ€™s so easy to fall into a routine and be lazy.â€â€œAs someone looking for a relationship while asking all these couples questions,â€ says Bernstein, â€œmy main takeaway is that thereâ€™s no one way to do it. People have such different types of romantic relationships.â€â€˜Whatâ€™s your dream?â€™Simon Squibb,@simonsquibbTikTok followers:6.1 millionInstagram followers:3 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜I wanted to make my son proud â€“ not just sit around and play golf.â€™Photograph: Simon SquibbFor Simon Squibb, 49, perfecting the question was key. â€œAÂ dream is both something weâ€™re never really asked, but also feels safe to admit,â€ he says. â€œMuch bigger than an objective thatâ€™s fleeting, or a resolution that comes and goes. Ask someone their dream, and you get to the heart of what they want from life.â€This is exactly what he does when approaching strangers on the street. â€œIâ€™m an entrepreneur, and investor in startups,â€ he says. â€œI offer free business knowledge, support peopleâ€™s dreams, and promote them on my channel.â€ In essence, heâ€™s an iPhone-wielding, street-scouring, one-man Dragonsâ€™ Den.Squibb, who lives in Sussex, started his first business aged 15. â€œI had no choice, having been made homelessÂ when I fell out with my mum.â€ His dad had recently died. â€œI couldnâ€™t get a job, so I started my own gardening company. IÂ asked someone who knew I was struggling for help. They were selling courses, andÂ offered to support me â€“ for a fee. I couldnâ€™t afford to pay. I vowed one day, if IÂ could afford to help people for free, I would.â€In2015, Squibb sold his business â€“ a Hong Kong-based creative and digital agency â€“ to PricewaterhouseCoopers. â€œI made life-changing money. I wouldnâ€™t need to work again. I took two years off. My wife and I had a baby. But I wanted to make my son proud, I realised â€“ not just sit around and play golf.â€He thought back to his hustling teenage self. â€œI knew so little about business. School hadnâ€™t equipped me for it at all. I wanted to help educate others, and TikTok is where young people were.â€No doubt his advice is gratefully received. He has also invested in 79 businesses to date. Most significant, though, is the exposure a chance encounter with Squibb and his camera brings: millions of followers; 315mÂ monthly views. â€œLots of people still think you shouldnâ€™t film kind gestures,â€ says Squibb, â€œthat IÂ should offer my advice privately, else itâ€™s tainted. Thatâ€™s stupid; part of the help I can offer is eyeballs. Why not use social media for social good?â€œNot long ago, someoneâ€™s reply to me was, â€˜I want to travel and take picturesâ€™.â€ Squibb had a think. â€œHow do we get there? Not, I said, saving money and planning. Letâ€™s get you a sponsor. That video clocked 112m views.lastminute.comoffered to sponsor her â€“ now sheâ€™s travelling the world, filling their social media feeds.â€ There was a woman in Lewes, getting off the bus. â€œShe said her dream was to be a fashion blogger and designer. Twenty-four hours later, she had 300,000+ followers. Done. The rest is up to her.â€œMy whole life is built around this concept: whatever I want to achieve, put a business model behind it. Teach people the basics, and any dream is possible.â€Simon Squibbâ€™s bookWhatâ€™s Your Dream?, published by Century, is out nowâ€˜What do you do for your workout?â€™Mark Langowski,@bodybymarkTikTok followers:527,200Instagram followers:1.5 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜Of course fitness trainers have the perfect workout. But what about real people?â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianThe approach, for Mark Langowski, 44, who lives in New York, still feels a little icky. His street-interview format relies on the camera rolling before the first question is asked â€“ initially filming someone without their consent. â€œI try to get them walking towards me,â€ he says, â€œso Iâ€™m looking two blocks ahead. Then I have a split second to scan them and decide if they look fit. I donâ€™t love that.â€ After making a judgment on their physique, heâ€™ll ask: â€œWhat do you do for your workout?â€ The shtick is simple, but the results are compelling: revealing the dedication of the majorly muscled, uberâ€‘athletic and, often, shirtless.The scale of the challenge varies seasonally. â€œInÂ summer and springtime New York, itâ€™s obviously easier to spot someone fit: tank tops, vests and workout gear; lots of skin on show,â€ he says. â€œWinter and fall are harder. Itâ€™s why I travel to Miami or Los Angeles at that time of year.â€He has been in the fitness business for 20 years, and started TikTokâ€‘ing 18 months ago. â€œIâ€™m a personal trainer by trade. I already had theInstagramaccount of a traditional fitness influencer: me and my clients working out; showing my abs off,â€ he says. â€œI got bored with it. Sick of the narcissism. I knew I needed a presence for my business, to keep myself relevant. But how to without making it all about me?â€Then, inspiration. â€œI was in an exercise class, and saw this woman in the most spectacular shape. I wondered what she was doing? It couldnâ€™t just be this class.â€ He went out the next day to film on the streets of New York. â€œIâ€™m an introvert; Iâ€™d never approach a stranger. I was so self-conscious and nervous, holding the camera down by my waist.â€ After a few weeks, people started to know about the videos. â€œIt made things easier â€“ if someone was into fitness, the algorithm was probably already showing them my stuff. And people were keen to talk. Now, my videos have been seen more than 1bn times.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. Sign up to get the inside story from our top writers as well as all the must-read articles and columns, delivered to your inbox every weekend.Enter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionOccasionally, heâ€™s still thrown by interviewee responses, like â€œwhen I was interviewing a stripper at a nightclub who had been shot in the leg by his dad and said he never goes to the gym and hasnâ€™t been since high school, and yet he had a six-packâ€.Heâ€™s confident his films have real value for people who watch. â€œEveryone knows what fitness trainers or influencers do to work out,â€ he says, â€œthey tell you every day. Itâ€™s tedious â€“ofÂ coursethey have the perfect breakfast, perfect workout, perfect everything. Itâ€™sÂ their day job. But what about real people? Iâ€™m asking the construction worker, the stay-at-home mum of three, the doctor or shop assistant.â€Langowski has learned plenty himself. â€œYou start to see patterns: lift heavy weights, donâ€™t run too much, eat healthy, sleep a lot and donâ€™t drink much alcohol. Iâ€™m surprised at how little cardio very fit-looking people do.â€â€˜How much do you pay for rent?â€™Caleb Simpson,@calebwsimpsonTikTok followers:8.5 millionInstagram followers:2.5 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜At first, 100 New Yorkers told me to eff off. Then one guy in Brooklyn showed me his apartment. It went viral.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The Guardianâ€œEveryone is low-key a snoop, when it comes to homes,â€Â says Caleb Simpson, 33. â€œWe all want to poke around places.â€Simpson grew up in Morganton, North Carolina, â€œinÂ aÂ small house with eight siblings, very humble beginnings â€“ a food-stamps-and-white-rice sort of lifeâ€. He moved to New York in 2015, and soon started to make a living doing social media for startups. â€œI was also always trying to do my own thing,â€ he says, â€œmaking videos on YouTube and Instagram.â€Simpson had spent years wandering the streets of New York, looking up at buildings, imagining what was within. â€œI had this lightbulb moment: just ask to look inside. Now most people know me as the â€˜apartment tour guyâ€™ â€“ the dude who asks the questions: how much do you pay for rent? Can I see?â€ He has done about 300 apartment tours in New York. â€œGlobally, itâ€™s more like 500 now: Paris, London, Hong Kong. All major US cities.â€œIt began with being shown a bunch of middle fingers on the streets of Manhattan,â€ he says. â€œNew Yorkers are straight up â€“ they told me to eff off.â€ How many times? â€œMaybe 100. It was deflating.â€ Then, a yes. â€œA Â guy in Brooklyn showed me around his apartment. It went viral.â€ It hasnâ€™t stopped since.Simpsonâ€™s selections are dictated by his own sense of curiosity. â€œThere are lots of identical, cookie-cutter flats in New York, housing finance guys.â€ He no longer steps foot inside them. â€œIâ€™m not interested. Instead, itâ€™s places where I think: I want to see what that looks like. A strange building, low-income housing, rent-controlled places, someone who pays $70,000 a month.â€ He still roams the street looking for volunteers, but with 11 million followers on Instagram and TikTok, there is no shortage of doors opening these days; sometimes prearranged.What has he learned from the endless property perusal? â€œAll New York renters think theyâ€™re getting a deal, but, really, everybody is getting ripped off,â€ says Simpson. â€œAnd beauty really lies in the eyes of the beholder. Sometimes, I film small apartments, and people comment saying itâ€™s depressing, but the people who live there are thrilled.â€This is why, heâ€™s certain, itâ€™s not just beautiful Brownstone-owning Brooklynites who let him in. â€œPeople are proud of what they have,â€ he says, â€œon whatever scale, and they want to show the world. Price isnâ€™t the only determiner of worth or value: how they decorate, how they live in the architecture, how they found a place. And thereâ€™s the 15 minutes of fame that comes with letting me in.â€â€˜What do you do for a living?â€™Daniel Mac,@itsdanielmacTikTok followers:14.2 millionInstagram followers:2.8 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜It was tough at the beginning â€“ Iâ€™m shy by nature. Money was the motivator. I wanted to know how to get rich.â€™Photograph: CraSH/Shutterstockâ€œWhen I started,â€ says Los Angeles-based Daniel MacDonald, 27, known online as Daniel Mac, â€œIâ€™d just moved to Dallas, Texas, from a small-ish town in Arizona where there werenâ€™t any Lamborghinis. Iâ€™d never seen supercars â€“ and was curious. How did the driver afford it? What could I, fresh out of college, do to get one?â€ Unabashed, he began walking up to their tinted windows to ask: â€œWhat do you do for a living?â€His first video clocked up 40m views. â€œWhen I posted it, I thought there was a glitch in the app and the numbers were wrong, but within a week Iâ€™d gained aÂ million followers on TikTok.â€ This quadrupled in aÂ matter of months â€“ all during Covid. â€œPeople were bored and needed cash,â€ he says. â€œThey wanted to get rich, and to find out how.â€Sometimes, answers are unexpected.He has stoppedformer stockbroker Jordan Belfort, rapper Wiz Khalifa and Shou Zi Chew, theCEO of TikTok. Mostly, though, the responses are fairly formulaic. â€œThe golden rule to getting rich, it transpires, is to invest, and buy real estate. Otherwise, common jobs are finance, healthcare, computer science and tech. Plus some trades, like plumbing and electricians â€¦ Accumulating wealth isnâ€™t that sexy, it transpires.â€How does he earn his living? â€œMy revenue is split into three buckets: roughly 40% from ad revenue paid out primarily by Facebook and Snapchat, then some from YouTube and TikTok.â€ Thatâ€™s his commission from the advertising that the platforms sell. â€œAnother 40% or so comes from brand partnerships.â€ Thatâ€™s the sponsored content. â€œInstagram brings in the most from this, then TikTok. And the last section comes from other miscellaneous things like speaking gigs.â€Raised in Tucson, MacDonald had just graduated with a degree in finance from the University of Arizona when he started his TikTok. Initially, he was reluctant to be in front of the camera. â€œIt was tough at the beginning,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™m shy by nature, and wasnâ€™t used to negativity and criticism, or people being mean to me online. Money was the motivator to continue. I wanted to know how to get rich.â€ It worked. In 2023, he bought his dream car: a $100,000 Porsche GT4.Thereâ€™s a candidness to interviewees, he reckons, when theyâ€™re filmed on an iPhone camera, with no chunky kit or team of producers. â€œIâ€™ve gotten people into hot water. One of thehigh-ups at Apple left the company after they made a lewd joke in a video of mine. People say stuff they regret.â€Certainly, a strata of the super-wealthy would be reluctant to publicly parade their wealth. But MacDonald preys on those in flashy cars â€“ the shy, modest and secretive types donâ€™t tend to drive Bugattis. â€œItâ€™s very American, for sure,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™ve tried filming in several other countries where people donâ€™t show off so much; they arenâ€™t as flashy. In London, people were far more reluctant to talk about money.â€â€˜Why are you a fan?â€™Morfo Peyiazis,@morfopeyiazisTikTok followers:47,800Instagram followers:15,600View image in fullscreenâ€˜Football fans are either portrayed as mindless, violent hooligans or as sugar-coated and family-friendly. Nothing captured the true, unfiltered chaos somewhere in between.â€™Photograph: Robin Lee / robin.p.leeLondon-based Morfo Peyiazis, 30, took a clinical approach to viral success. She worked in marketing before starting out as aÂ professional poster. â€œIÂ wasÂ pitching video ideas to brands,â€ she says, â€œparticularly football clients. IÂ wanted to do interviews embedded with fans, and got fed up with being told, â€˜No, itâ€™s too risky.â€™â€During Euro 2020, she spotted a chance. â€œFuck it,â€ she thought, â€œIâ€™ll make my own fan-focused series. Football fans are either portrayed as mindless, violent hooligans on the news, or, by their clubs, as sugar-coated and family-friendly. Nothing captured the true, unfiltered chaos somewhere in between.â€Getting in among it suited her personality. â€œI get it from my dad,â€ she reckons, â€œa crazy Cypriot man. Growing up he had so much energy, and so much empathy with people.â€Peyiazis saw TikTok as a way in to a more traditional telly career. â€œIn essence, I used it to create a public portfolio: a place to make your own pilots, and prove that your ideas are popular. My ambition over the nextÂ five years is to build a media brand, and I want to be future-proof.â€ Whether or not thatâ€™s possible on TikTok, sheâ€™s still unsure. â€œThe turnaround is so crazy. I couldnâ€™t tell you the last five videos I watched. Itâ€™s instant: bam-bam-bam. How to create long-term impact is challenging.â€ She has landed gigs with Channel 4 and Sky Sports.Thereâ€™s a natural warmth to her presenting style: playful, inquisitive, genuine interest in what her interviewees are saying. â€œI donâ€™t like being on the periphery; Iâ€™m there to soak up the experience theyâ€™re having.â€ Itâ€™s this attitude that explains Peyiazisâ€™s on-screen appeal, entirely unfazed by whatever sheâ€™s confronted with: hordes of screaming Celtic and Rangers fans at the high-octane â€œold firmâ€ derby; youngÂ men playing up to the camera once microphonesÂ are pointed in their direction. â€œAmong some of the supposedly most dangerous rivalries in theÂ world, IÂ feelÂ entirely safe. Having no fear, and gettingÂ stuck in. Youâ€™ve got to be able to hold your own â€“ and I can.â€Explore more on these topicsLife and styleSocial mediaTikTokInstagramDigital mediafeaturesShareReuse this content

title: I adore my children. Iâ€™m also scared that one day my son will kill me | Femicide | The Guardian
description: In the UK, more than 170 women have been murdered by their sons in the past 15 years. An anonymous mother reveals what it is like to be frightened of your child while desperately wanting to support him
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: In the UK, more than 170 women have been murdered by their sons in the past 15 years. An anonymous mother reveals what it is like to be frightened of your child while desperately wanting to support him
Content: â€˜It is hard enough to walk away from an abusive partner, let alone your child, whose vulnerabilities and misery claw at the heartâ€™.Photograph: olga Yastremska/AlamyView image in fullscreenâ€˜It is hard enough to walk away from an abusive partner, let alone your child, whose vulnerabilities and misery claw at the heartâ€™.Photograph: olga Yastremska/AlamyThe ObserverFemicideI adore my children. Iâ€™m also scared that one day my son will kill meIn the UK, more than 170 women have been murdered by their sons in the past 15 years. An anonymous mother reveals what it is like to be frightened of your child while desperately wanting to support himAnonymousSat 8 Mar 2025 06.12 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 13.07 ESTShareI am staring at the faces of women on my screen, transfixed by emotions too complex to disentangle; discernible, though, are grief, rage... and fear.For the women pictured are some of the more than 170 who have been killed by their sons in the UK in the past 15 years. Their appalling tragedy â€“ being killed by the person to whom they gave life â€“ has a chilling resonance. Like many of those whose deaths have been highlighted in the2,000 Women report by the Femicide Census, I am a professional with adored adult children and a close circle of friends. I am also frightened of my son.The womenâ€™s backstories are all too familiar â€“ that is, an adult son with mental health and social problems, drug misuse, neurological diagnoses and a history of controlling and violent behaviour. Invariably, the perpetrators have fallen through every net designed to safeguard them. Often such a net never existed.It is a peculiar place to inhabit, to be simultaneously scared of your son while desperately wanting to hold and support him. It is hard enough to walk away from an abusive partner, let alone your child, whose vulnerabilities and misery claw at the heart. My son lives in a state of deep unhappiness, prey to stimuli he canâ€™t filter, fraught social encounters, chronic anxiety and physical discomfort. Life is bewildering, painful, hard.At 24, he is a young man with learning disabilities and no hope of any of the aspirations of neurotypical peers: no career ladder, no partner, no festivals or functional friendships. Life is something to be battled and endured. I would not spend a minute in his shoes. He needs me for support, advocacy and protection. He still sleeps with his security blanket. I canâ€™t and wonâ€™t walk away.But I often wish I could. On my phone is a recent text, the words â€œfucking cuntâ€ written repeatedly. It was sent because I had blocked his calls after being asked the same question for 20 minutes. I was at work. He rang a further 76 times. Such messages are common, as is driving somewhere while he violently elbows the seat close to me â€“ the list of challenging behaviours is exhaustive and exhausting. It is not just autistic meltdowns caused by an inability to regulate emotions but an expression of deep-seated mental health problems.In the photographs, I see resilient, smart, smiling women â€“ doing their best to live normally against a backdrop of abnormality few can relate to. I am paralysed with sorrow for them, as I am for the mainly young men who killed the one person who loved and supported them the most.In many instances the women sought help. The inquest into thedeath of Sally Poynton, 44, stabbed repeatedly by her 22-year-old son Jacob Poynton-Whiting during a severe psychotic episode in June 2021, found thather death could have been avoidedif her sonâ€™s mental health condition had been diagnosed sooner. She had tried more than 20 times to get help for him.View image in fullscreenSally Poynton tried to get help for her son 20 times before he stabbed her to death in 2021.Photograph: LinkedinThat matricide is largely linked to mental health is borne out by research that is soon to be published.It was reported last weekthat academics Prof Rachel Condry and Dr Caroline Miles, from the universities of Oxford and Manchester, in collaboration with theFemicide Census, have found that in cases of women being killed by their sons and grandsons from 2009-2021, 70% involved perpetrators with mental health problems.Yet help is too often either not forthcoming or ineffectual because, in the words of the British Medical Association, our mental health and social care systems are â€œbrokenâ€.In itsMental Health Report 2024, the BMA pointed to key areas it said needed â€œurgent actionâ€ including underfunding; lack of trained staff in health and social care; and support systems operating in silos.In our case, my son does not merit a dedicated social worker because he isnâ€™t perceived to be in crisis. That he isnâ€™t thriving physically or emotionally is not reason enough to intervene. The social care system is reactively predicated â€“ action happens when a crisis presents, not when it might have been prevented. As for mental health, like many adults on the autistic spectrum, hefalls through the gaps. There have been no mental health interventions since he turned 18 and ceased to be eligible for the Child and Adolescent Mental Health Service.Yet my son desperately needs therapeutic input to help manage his anxiety, depression and emotions, alongside medications prescribed by an expert in his diagnoses, which include autism, pathological demand avoidance, ADHD and OCD. Medication is managed by a GP who, while competent, is not trained specifically in mental health and neurodivergent conditions.Crucially, he needs help navigating his complex feelings towards me. A misfiring mother-son relationship isnâ€™t, of course, confined to the neurodivergent, nor is it new. The Orestes complex, in which a son harbours the unconscious desire to kill his mother, is a parable dating back to ancient Greece. Friends complain of walking on eggshells around sullen adult neurotypical sons. But during flashpoints, their sons roll their eyes or behave peevishly. With a son who is hostage to unregulated emotions, flashpoints can be tragically fatal.This is where societal structures should save lives.Mental healthsupport that offers tools to manage emotions, joined up with a social care system that enables those with behavioural and social challenges to thrive. And residential and supported living that offers community, activities and cohesion, rather than simply warehousing vulnerable people.Yet such a picture seems depressingly far off, and I fear this year wonâ€™t have been the lastInternational Womenâ€™s Daymarked by reports of failings that led to deaths and shattered families. It is inevitably parents, particularly mothers, who bear the brunt of systemic failures and step in to support volatile, troubled sons. That they may be in danger is often overlooked; Condry points to a case where a manâ€™s medical notes said he shouldnâ€™t be left alone with female staff, â€œbut nobody had questioned whether he should live on his own with his motherâ€.My son was removed from the house in 2018, not because he was attacking me but because there were minors present. I remain very involved in his care, but at times I feel unsafe. Sitting in the quiet of my house, it seems dramatic to write these next words, but had he remained living with me, I believe my picture could have been among those women. I canâ€™t say it never will be.Explore more on these topicsFemicideThe ObserverViolence against women and girlsMental healthCrimeWomenfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜We joke about whoâ€™s getting their knees doneâ€™: the rock veterans still touring into their late 70s | Music | The Guardian
description: Yoga and ice baths have replaced all-nighters, but musicians such as Graham Nash, Bonnie Raitt, Rick Wakeman and Elkie Brooks arenâ€™t planning to retire any time soon
Author: Dave Simpson
Headline: Yoga and ice baths have replaced all-nighters, but musicians such as Graham Nash, Bonnie Raitt, Rick Wakeman and Elkie Brooks arenâ€™t planning to retire any time soon
Content: Rock of agesâ€¦ how and why do mature musicians keep going so long?Photograph: Martina Lang/The GuardianView image in fullscreenRock of agesâ€¦ how and why do mature musicians keep going so long?Photograph: Martina Lang/The GuardianMusicâ€˜We joke about whoâ€™s getting their knees doneâ€™: the rock veterans still touring into their late 70sYoga and ice baths have replaced all-nighters, but musicians such as Graham Nash, Bonnie Raitt, Rick Wakeman and Elkie Brooks arenâ€™t planning to retire any time soonDave SimpsonSat 8 Mar 2025 06.55 ESTShareIalways said Iâ€™d retire when I got to 50,â€ chucklesRick Wakeman, who didnâ€™t do any suchÂ thing. Instead â€“ after realising that far fromÂ being left adrift by popâ€™s ever-changing styles, people were still interested in what he had to offer â€“ he recorded another 37 albums (taking his total to more than 100), penned two bestselling autobiographies and a film score andÂ carried on performing shows. ThenÂ last yearÂ he announced that heâ€™d stop touring whenÂ heÂ reaches 77, but heâ€™ll be 76 this May andÂ his packedÂ liveÂ schedule doesnâ€™t suggest a performer saying his last goodbyes.â€œThere was a time when I thought, maybe itâ€™s time to gracefully bow out,â€ the prog keyboard caped crusader explains, before his latest gig in Bradford. â€œBut unfortunately I canâ€™t. Music is the world to me. Itâ€™s just become blatantly obvious that Iâ€™m going to keep doing it until they put an epitaph on my gravestone reading: â€˜Itâ€™s not fair. Iâ€™m not finished yet.â€™â€Elkie Brooks knows exactly how he feels. TheÂ â€œQueen of British bluesâ€ (whose hits include Pearlâ€™s a Singer and Lilac Wine) has had 13 Top 75 albums in total andÂ isÂ on the road again at 80, having performed a â€œfarewell tourâ€ when she was 40. â€œThe promoter thought it might be a nice idea,â€ she chuckles. â€œIâ€™ve been saying â€˜farewellâ€™ ever since.â€View image in fullscreenThereâ€™s Only One â€¦ Graham Nash.Photograph: Ralf LouisThe pair are not alone in rocking way past pensionable age. When rockâ€™nâ€™roll was considered a young personâ€™s game, the young Mick Jagger once said: â€œIÂ donâ€™t wanna be singing Satisfaction when Iâ€™m 30,â€ but he still tours with the Rolling Stones at 81, while other venerable rockers treading the boards include Bob Dylan (83), Paul McCartney (82), Bruce Springsteen (75) and Mavis Staples (85). Folk legend Peggy Seeger is even touring this year aged 89. â€œItâ€™s like a drug,â€ Wakeman explains. â€œOnce itâ€™s inside you, you canâ€™t do without it.â€The top stars donâ€™t need the money but perform because it is rooted in their psyche and the demand is there. For Graham Nash, the Blackpool-born co-founder of the Hollies and supergroup Crosby, Stills and Nash, itâ€™s about â€œthe passion of music, and the energy I get from performing a new song to an audience. And when itâ€™s a song Iâ€™ve sung a million times, Iâ€™m going to sing it with the same passion I had when I wrote it.â€Seventy-five-year-old, California-born roots singerBonnie Raitthas spent 54 years on the road and says she canâ€™t think of anything more fun. â€œWhen I started out, my heroes were the jazz, blues and classical people who played well into their 70s and 80s. But touring is like a travelling summer camp. Then every night I get to have a party with the audience.â€Iâ€™m about to turn 83. I donâ€™t have a vocal coach, I do 22 songs a night, 25 shows a tour. Iâ€™m singing as well as everGraham NashStars get hooked young. Wakeman first performed in childhood and Salford-born Brooks got the bug through singing in her uncleâ€™s wedding band. Raitt watched audiences going â€œnutsâ€ when her father sang in musicals such as Oklahoma! â€œNone of us could believe this was his job,â€ she remembers. â€œSo once I took to it and got to open for James Taylor and Muddy Waters there was no turning back.â€Nash was a teenager when he entered a talent contest at Manchester Hippodrome with his pal Allan Clarke. â€œOn that show were myself and Allan, who later formed the Hollies, Freddie Garrity, who became Freddie and the Dreamers, Ron Wycherley, who became Billy Fury, and Johnny and the Moondogs, who became the Beatles.â€ John Lennon, Paul McCartney and George Harrison had dashed for the last bus back to Liverpool by the time Nash and Clarke were declared the winners, but Nash says â€œ2,000 people going crazy was the moment I knew I loved singing for peopleâ€.In the Hollies, he experienced the archetypal touring life: â€œFive of us in the back of a Transit, trying to get toÂ sleep on the amps and drum cases. One night the doors flew open and I fell out of the van.â€ Aged 20, Wakeman lived similarly during his time in the Strawbs.Â He chuckles. â€œYouÂ couldnâ€™t get my keyboard rig in a Transit now.â€View image in fullscreenâ€˜The trick is to pace yourselfâ€™ â€¦ Bonnie Raitt.Photograph: Scott Newton/Photo Courtesy of Austin PBS/Austin City Limits Photo by Scott NewtonJoining prog rock giants Yes in 1971 took his touring experiences to a very different level. â€œStaying on Sunset Strip with a whole bathroom and a shag pile carpet. IÂ thought: â€˜Bloody hell. I could move in here.â€™â€ But for older artists comfort is essential, rather than a luxury. â€œI wouldnâ€™t want to be running around in a van trying to break into the business, loading the equipment andÂ not getting decent hotels or food,â€ Raitt says. â€œThe trick is to pace yourself.â€ Sheâ€™s been touring for the last four years, and she does five months on the road out of every 12. â€œEnough to keep my band and crew working with me and to keep it fun.â€In her youth, Brooks hated touring. â€œJust me in my little Mini with a little suitcase, driving everywhere, finding my own bed and breakfasts. I wouldnâ€™t wish it on my worst enemy.â€ Now she tours the country with long gaps between gigs, pointing out that her vocal warmup, soundcheck and show still add up to more than three hours of exertion. â€œYou wouldnâ€™t ask Mo Farah to run the marathon again the next day, would you?â€ On show days, she avoids speaking to restÂ her voice. Raitt concurs: â€œOne of the great gifts hasÂ been texting and email to save your voice during the day.â€I never want to hear people walk out of a concert and go: He used to be really good.Rick WakemanIt also helps to stay fit. Brooks became a black belt in aikido when she was 50. Raitt does yoga and weights, hikes and takes a bike on tour. Wakeman merely walks his dogs. â€œWe recently sold a house and in one of the outbuildings I came across this strange equipment,â€ he chuckles. â€œMy wife said: â€˜Thatâ€™s the gym you built four years ago.â€™â€As a member of Yes, he enjoyed excesses such as mocking a studio upÂ like a farmyard, after which his keyboard had to goÂ forÂ repair because it was full of woodlice. â€œWeâ€™dÂ comeÂ up with mad suggestions,â€ he chuckles. â€œâ€˜Why donâ€™t we travel by camel?!â€™ It was ridiculous, butÂ it was the 70s.â€ His own excess stopped at drugs â€“ â€œIâ€™ve never popped a pill or smoked a jointâ€ â€“ but, heÂ says, tooÂ much booze and cigarettes gave him aÂ series of heart attacks by the age of 25, so he quit both.Â â€œIÂ tryÂ notÂ to think about all that,â€ he admits, moreÂ seriously, â€œbecause you ask yourself: â€˜Should I still be here?â€™â€â€œHonestly, to go on at the Newcastle Fiesta in 1964 or 65 you needed half a bottle of brandy,â€ argues Brooks, who admits that in Vinegar Joe, the band she formed with Robert Palmer in the 1970s, taking cocaine was like having a cup of coffee. â€œThe thing was, weâ€™d go on in Sheffield at 10pm, then weâ€™d be doing a gig in the London Roundhouse at 3am. Two shows a night. I often wondered why the record company were taking cocaine but we were taking it just to stay bloody awake.â€ SheÂ stopped after meeting Trevor, her sound engineer husband of 47 years, who didnâ€™t touch the stuff. â€œIÂ wanted him to like me,â€ she says. She last drank alcohol before a show in 1979, when â€œa stomach upset meant I couldnâ€™t keep anything downâ€.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. Sign up to get the inside story from our top writers as well as all the must-read articles and columns, delivered to your inbox every weekend.Enter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionView image in fullscreenElkie Brooks â€¦ â€˜Text and email mean I can save my voice during the dayâ€™Photograph: Kev Nicholsonâ€œBy your 30s, staying up drinking and doing drugs and not sleeping arenâ€™t wearing so well,â€ considers Raitt, who had also got â€œsucked inâ€ to the rockâ€™nâ€™roll lifestyle. â€œThe next thing you know your liver is shot or youâ€™re not recovering from colds or you lose your voice, say stuff you donâ€™t mean or youâ€™re sloppy on stage.â€ After a 1987 skiing accident, she had to take two months off after surgery so took the opportunity to get sober, go on a diet and lose weight, in preparation for a video shoot with Prince. â€œThe biggest change was not partying all night after the show but it proved serendipitous: I got famous at the same time I got sober.Â Then I saw other people whoâ€™d got sober and they were singing and playing better than ever, so my last excuse was gone.â€In Nashâ€™s autobiography Wild Tales, he describes mind-boggling 70s tours involving helicopters, limousines, coke dealers and five-hour shows that wentÂ on past midnight, but life is different now. â€œIÂ wasÂ never really an addict,â€ he insists, â€œbut I stopped taking cocaine 40 years ago after I went to an aftershowÂ party and saw everybody smiling, but the smiles never reached their eyes. I realised they must be looking at me and seeing the same thing.â€ He still uses marijuana before shows, but says, â€œIâ€™m about to turn 83. I donâ€™t have a vocal coach, I do 22 songs a night, 25 shows a tour. Songs such as Military Madness or Immigration Man are still relevant and Iâ€™m singing as well as ever.â€Some older stars carry scars from a lifetime on the road.Â Along with those heart attacks, Wakeman has had â€œdouble pleurisy,Â double pneumonia, arthritis, diabetesâ€ and has to plunge his throbbing arthritic hands into an iceÂ bath after every show. â€œI had some health problemsÂ in America this year and if it wasnâ€™t for the show Iâ€™d have been in bed or calling the medics,â€ heÂ reveals. â€œBut when you go on stage, something takesÂ over â€“ adrenaline or whatever â€“ and you feel great, until youâ€™re back in the dressing room and you feelÂ dreadful.â€View image in fullscreenRick Wakeman â€¦ not planning to put his musical career on ice any time soon.Photograph: Lee Wilkinson MultimediaRaitt has had to postpone shows in recent years because of laryngitis or â€œwear and tearâ€ and says her older musician pals joke about â€œwhoâ€™s getting their knees done or whoâ€™s got tendonitis and so on. But in every city there are parks I love to go to, friends I love to see. And there are people who saw me in the 1970s who still come and see me now.â€Younger fans discover veteran artists through parents, radio, magazines or streaming. It amazes Nash that he can pack a hall at his age and Wakeman appreciates every second in ways he could never have done when he was younger. What would make him stop performing? â€œIf I couldnâ€™t play like I want to. I never want to hear people walk out of a concert and go: â€˜HeÂ used to be really good.â€™â€Raitt wants to prove that sheâ€™s as â€œbadassâ€ as ever, but insists: â€œIâ€™m not slowing down and Iâ€™m not going toÂ stop until I canâ€™t do it any more.â€ Brooks jokes thatÂ when she can no longer hit the high notes, â€œtheyâ€™llÂ find a place for me in Tesco on the tillsâ€. NashÂ saw Spanish guitar giant AndrÃ©s Segovia play when he was 92. â€œAnd he knocked me on my ass withÂ the energyÂ andÂ brilliance of his performance. SoÂ IÂ think: â€˜Why not me?â€™â€Perhaps thereâ€™s a life lesson here for all of us. AsÂ RaittÂ puts it: â€œIf you find something you love doing, keep doing it.â€Elkie Brooksplaysthe Lowry, Salford, 16Â March, and is touring until 2026;Bonnie Raitttours the UK from 1Â toÂ 17Â June, starting atthe Usher Hall, Belfast;Graham Nashis touring from 4 to 19 October, starting at theGlasshouse, Gateshead;RickÂ Wakemanand the English Rock Ensemble tour the UK from12 to 29October.Explore more on these topicsMusicPop and rockRick WakemanBonnie RaittfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: The gift of the gab: did an iron age brain drain bring Celtic to Ireland? | Language | The Guardian
description: The rise of the precursor to the Irish language remains a historical mystery that linguists, geneticists and archaeologists continue to debate
Author: Laura Spinney
Headline: The rise of the precursor to the Irish language remains a historical mystery that linguists, geneticists and archaeologists continue to debate
Content: Celtic was probably well established in Ireland by the time Saint Patrick was on his mission in the fifth century.Photograph: Darren Matthews/AlamyView image in fullscreenCeltic was probably well established in Ireland by the time Saint Patrick was on his mission in the fifth century.Photograph: Darren Matthews/AlamyThe ObserverLanguageThe gift of the gab: did an iron age brain drain bring Celtic to Ireland?The rise of the precursor to the Irish language remains a historical mystery that linguists, geneticists and archaeologists continue to debateLaura SpinneySat 8 Mar 2025 11.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 16.38 ESTShareSaint Patrick, whose feast day is celebrated on 17 March, left behind two short works in Latin, but he probably spoke a Celtic language. By the time he was saving Irish souls in the fifth century AD, linguists are pretty sure that Celtic was spoken throughout Britain andIreland. When Celtic first arrived in those islands, however, is an enduring mystery â€“ one that new findings in archaeology and genetics might help to solve.The dates range between the early bronze age, around 2500BC, when archaeologists detect a major cultural transformation in Britain and Ireland, and the first century AD. Most linguists place it in between, in the last millennium BC â€“ the iron age â€“ but they canâ€™t prove it because the language wasnâ€™t written down until much later.The oldest known Celtic inscriptions come from the region of the northern Italian lakes and are dated to the sixth century BC. Greek and Roman historians attest to Celtic languages being spoken as far east as modern Bulgaria at about the same date. In Britain, however, Celtic wasnâ€™t recorded until the first century BC, and in Ireland later still.Linguist David Stifter of Maynooth University in Ireland says that an iron age introduction is most likely because the Celtic languages of Britain, Ireland and what is now France look strikingly similar when they are first captured in writing, suggesting that the three varieties hadnâ€™t parted ways long before. â€œIf Celts or pre-Celts were in Ireland in the early bronze age, we would expect the language to look very, very different,â€ he says.We have this big crash in Ireland at 800BC. Something big happened, and itâ€™s presumably related to the climateRowan McLaughlin, Maynooth UniversityThe cultural upheaval of the early bronze age may well have seen the introduction of a new language, Stifter thinks, but it wasnâ€™t Celtic; Celtic eventually replaced that language.Migration is considered to have been a major driver of language change in prehistory, and in 2022 a group of researchers at Harvard University, led by computational biologist Nick Patterson,reportedthat they had detected a big turnover in the British gene pool around 1200BC. From that date until the Roman invasion of AD43 they were unable to detect any other large shift, so they suggested that this marked the wave of immigration that brought Celtic to Britain. â€œMy gut feeling is itâ€™s still a little bit early,â€ Stifter said at the time.However, geneticist Lara Cassidy of Trinity College Dublin says that a finer resolution is needed to detect people moving around the north-western corner of Europe in the last millennium BC, because the populations of France and Britain were already quite interconnected by then, and genetically more similar than they had been in the bronze age.In January, Cassidyâ€™s groupreportedfinding identical sequences of DNA in the genomes of people who died either side of the Channel in that crucial period, indicating that they were more or less distantly related â€“ up to nine generationsâ€™ separation. â€œWe found evidence of substantial contact between at least the south coast of Britain and France during the iron age,â€ she says.The arrival of Celtic in Ireland is even harder to detect, because thereâ€™s no evidence of any major reconfiguration of the Irish gene pool after the early bronze age. Again, that doesnâ€™t rule out immigration from genetically similar populations, Cassidy says, and archaeologist Rowan McLaughlin of Maynooth University thinks he has evidence of such an influx.Human DNA preserved from prehistoric Ireland is scarce, in part because the Irish cremated their dead throughout the iron age. That makes it difficult to estimate how the population size changed over time, but McLaughlin has found a way to do so indirectly. He has built a database of all archaeological traces of human occupation in Ireland starting in the late stone age. At 2500BC, he says, the population was about a million, and it remained that size until 800BC. â€œWe have this big crash at 800BC, and then a few centuries of low levels of activity,â€ McLaughlin says. â€œSomething big happened, and itâ€™s presumably related to the climate.â€View image in fullscreenThe Roman invasion of Britain, AD43.Photograph: Lebrecht Music and Arts Photo Library/AlamyAround 800BC, a global climate event caused western Europe to become very wet. McLaughlin thinks that associated disasters such as crop failures or epidemics triggered an Irish â€œbrain drainâ€ to Britain. This is the date at which the bronze age gave way to the iron age in Europe. Continental societies experienced a major rupture, with new cultural practices and religions replacing old ones, but in Britain it was business as usual â€“ and business was thriving. Population centres were growing, impressive hillforts were being built, and cross-Channel traffic was increasing. â€œBritain is an unusual place in the iron age,â€ McLaughlin says.About 300 years later, the Irish population recovered, which could reflect the descendants of those earlier economic migrants returning to their roots. Only now they may have been speaking a different language, one they had brought back with them from Britain: Celtic.This scenario strikes many linguists as plausible, but McLaughlin says the smoking gun is missing: clear genetic evidence that Irish people settled in Britain around 800BC. Cassidyâ€™s approach of searching for genealogical links between genetically similar populations could provide it, but she says that itâ€™s not yet possible to rule out a third scenario â€“ one proposed by linguist Peter Schrijver of Utrecht University in the Netherlands.Schrijver thinks that Celtic could have arrived in Ireland as late as the first century AD, brought by Celtic-speaking Britons fleeing the Roman invasion of AD43. They may have prospered in their new home, forming an elite that managed to impose its language by force or persuasion, or because others wanted to imitate them. An archaic form of Irish could have been what came out of local peopleâ€™s mouths when they mispronounced what was, to them, a foreign tongue â€“ British Celtic, or Brittonic.But the split between Brittonic and the so-called Goidelic languages of Scotland and Ireland could have happened differently. Goidelic could have arisen in the west of Britain, before being pushed across the Irish Sea by the Roman invasion. â€œI think everybody would be very confident that Celtic came from the continent into the islands,â€ Cassidy says, â€œbut after that, movements could have been in both directions.â€Breton, a Brittonic language still spoken in Brittany, is thought by many to have been planted in France by Cornish people who themselves took to the sea in small boats. Irish slavers seeded Goidelic in Scotland and the Isle of Man in the early middle ages, when they were capturing local people, including the future Saint Patrick.Does it seem complicated? Thatâ€™s language for you. If the Celtic story is becoming clearer in some respects, Cassidy says, itâ€™s unlikely ever to be entirely limpid: â€œThe more data we gather, the more questions we raise.â€Proto: How One AncientLanguageWent Globalby Laura Spinney is published on April 24 by HarperCollins (Â£22)Explore more on these topicsLanguageThe ObserverIrelandfeaturesShareReuse this content
