title: Mao Zedongâ€™s first Little Red Book had blue cover and less propaganda | Communism | The Guardian
description: Rare early editions of book by communist party chairman, who shunned the idea of wealth, set to fetch Â£1m at auction
Author: David Barnett
Headline: Rare early editions of book by communist party chairman, who shunned the idea of wealth, set to fetch Â£1m at auction
Content: A crowd waving copies of the Little Red Book in Tiananmen Square, Beijing, circa 1966.Photograph: Pictures from History/Universal Images Group/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenA crowd waving copies of the Little Red Book in Tiananmen Square, Beijing, circa 1966.Photograph: Pictures from History/Universal Images Group/Getty ImagesObservedCommunismMao Zedongâ€™s first Little Red Book had blue cover and less propagandaRare early editions of book by communist party chairman, who shunned the idea of wealth, set to fetch Â£1m at auctionDavid BarnettSat 8 Mar 2025 10.00 ESTShareThe thoughts ofMao Zedong, published in 1964 under the titleQuotations, are considered the blueprint for Chinese communism and a guidebook to theCultural Revolution. The collected soundbites from his speeches and writings have become known the world over as theLittle Red Book.But the red-coveredQuotationsof the former Chinese Communist Party chairman, who died in 1976, aged 82, went through many ideological iterations before the official version was settled on. The original cover was also a different colour â€“ in fact, had some of those earlier thought experiments been declared the final draft, we could now be talking about Chairman Maoâ€™s Little Blue Book.For the first time, a huge collection of the various editions ofQuotationshas been assembled and is to be unveiled and presented for sale at the New York International Antiquarian Book Fair next month, with a communism-busting price tag of Â£1m.The collection is the work of more than two decades by Justin G Schiller, an American collector who began to visitChinain the 1990s. Dr Matt Wills of London rare book dealer Peter Harrington, which is representing the sale, said: â€œAt that time, the market for collecting the Little Red Book was only just beginning, and you could find all kinds of rare and one-off editions being discarded by institutions and private individuals if you knew where to look. Justin was in place at the perfect time to build a collection without parallel. It would be impossible to do the same today, as the majority of the rarer editions have long perished.â€View image in fullscreenMao Zedong watches an army parade in Beijing, then known as Peking, in 1967.Photograph: Apic/RETIRED/Getty ImagesThe collection is some 200 items strong and includes many of the early versions as well as first editions and international printings of the book. Before the famous red vinyl cover was settled on, the prototype editions had brown, white and blue bindings.And it wasnâ€™t just cosmetic changes that were effected for the final printing. Many of the ideas in the book changed and evolved from 1960, when Maoâ€™s sayings and slogans started to be compiled.â€œThe first widely published edition of the Little Red Book, released in May 1964, naturally opens with a quote on the vanguard role of the Chinese Communist Party,â€ said Wills.â€œLook to prototype and trial versions and you will see that most do not open with this quote. As the Little Red Book became a â€˜mass marketâ€™ publication, it became very important to put the party at the forefront on page one.â€œYou will also see, across editions from 1961 to 1964, that the text shrinks, and the quotes often become punchier and rhetorically impactful as compilers tried to make the Â­selection as effective and user-friendly as possible.â€In fact, it seems that even 60 years ago spin doctors were at work to make the thoughts of Chairman Mao easily digestible for the masses.View image in fullscreenPart of the collection of Quotations editions, including one with a blue cover. The collection is set to go on sale for Â£1m in New York next month.Photograph: Peter Harrington Rare BooksProf Christopher Marquis, Sinyi professor of Chinese management at Cambridge Judge Business School and author of the bookMao and Markets, said: â€œThe original book was for the Peopleâ€™s Liberation Army so it focused a lot on Maoâ€™s military guidance and quotes on discipline and loyalty.â€œFollowing the start of the Cultural Revolution in 1966, the book was transformed into much more of an element of propaganda and a more ideologically focused text to rally the populace behind Mao and his ideas.â€Wills agrees: â€œThe final version represents a very specific way of presenting Maoism: short, punchy phrases, many of which became everyday idiomatic expressions during the Cultural Revolution, arranged in no more than three dozen easily digestible chapters produced in a cheap and durable binding.â€View image in fullscreenThree early editions of the book, which is considered the blueprint for Chinese communism.Photograph: Peter Harrington Rare BooksThe Little Red Book has earned its place as an item of cultural significance â€“ Prof Marquis points to Chinaâ€™sRed Guardswaving the book in revolutionary fervour as an enduring image of Maoâ€™s time and also its utilisation by 1960s leftwingÂ movements.The Little Red Book is more than just a piece of nostalgia though. â€œMany of the business entrepreneurs I have researched quote Mao and discuss his work as inspiration and in some cases a guide for their work,â€ said Marquis.â€œAnd [Chinese president] Xi Jinping also quotes Mao and uses his ideas in guiding his policies.â€œMore broadly, I think it also shapes the general propaganda atmosphere and idea that political control through propaganda is essential to governing China. I think of the promotion of â€˜XiÂ Jinping thoughtâ€™ and literally hundreds of books Xi has â€˜authoredâ€™. It reflects an attempt to create a written canon like Mao.â€The Cultural Revolution: all you need to know about Chinaâ€™s political convulsionRead moreMao himself said in the Little Red Book: â€œIt is dreadful to imagine a time when everyone will be rich.â€ So what would he think of his work going on sale for Â£1m?â€œI think he would have a very mixed reaction,â€ says Prof Marquis.â€œOn the one hand, selling items for the rich to buy at such astronomical prices does point to the underlying problems with capitalism, which he strongly resisted.â€œHowever, on an intellectual level, it is a great manifestation of commodity fetishism â€“ a key idea of Karl Marxâ€™s â€“ so in some ways he might have foundÂ it reinforcing of his world view being right.â€œBut he might have actually been quite pleased, because aside from his ideological positions, he was an extreme narcissist and revelled in the cult of personality he created, so he might have been pleased that this book is getting such attention and is being so highly valued.â€Explore more on these topicsCommunismObservedMao ZedongChinaShareReuse this content

title: Dread haunts Gaza as airstrikes dent hopes of renewed ceasefire | Gaza | The Guardian
description: The territory is mired in a â€˜grey zoneâ€™ of uncertainty as the peace process has stalled and neither side seems willing to compromise
Author: Jason Burke
Headline: The territory is mired in a â€˜grey zoneâ€™ of uncertainty as the peace process has stalled and neither side seems willing to compromise
Content: Palestinians sit at a large table surrounded by the rubble of destroyed buildings as they gather for iftar, the fast-breaking meal, on the first day of Ramadan in Rafah, southern Gaza Strip, on 1 March.Photograph: Abdel Kareem Hana/APView image in fullscreenPalestinians sit at a large table surrounded by the rubble of destroyed buildings as they gather for iftar, the fast-breaking meal, on the first day of Ramadan in Rafah, southern Gaza Strip, on 1 March.Photograph: Abdel Kareem Hana/APThe ObserverGazaDread haunts Gaza as airstrikes dent hopes of renewed ceasefireThe territory is mired in a â€˜grey zoneâ€™ of uncertainty as the peace process has stalled and neither side seems willing to compromiseJason Burkein Jerusalem andMalak A Tanteshin GazaSat 8 Mar 2025 12.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 16.47 ESTShareFears of a return to war in Gaza are intensifying this weekend, with faltering diplomatic efforts and almost daily airstrikes by Israeli forces in the devastated territory.There has been relative calm inGazasince a ceasefire for prisoners deal between Hamas and Israel came into effect in January, pausing 15 months of conflict. However, the first phase of that agreement expired more than a week ago and a second phase has stalled, leaving Gaza plunged into a â€œgrey zoneâ€ of uncertainty.â€œI feel happiness and relief that the fighting has been stopped for so long but right now, I am really anxious the war will start again. I follow the news continuously,â€ said Ranan al-Ashqar, who works in the education ministry in Gaza City.Many observers see only a narrow and unlikely pathway to any durable peace. â€œWe are in a grey zone. I am pessimistic about the potential going forward because the political calculations for the Israeli leadership do not favour a ceasefire that would involve an Israeli withdrawal from Gaza,â€ saidHugh Lovatt, a senior policy fellow at the European Council on Foreign Relations.Some analysts fear a return to wider hostilities within days as Israel seeks to pressure Hamas into new concessions.Others suggest that a large-scale ground and air operation by the Israel Defense Forces (IDF) â€œwithin weeksâ€ is more likely if no new deal is reached. Last week, senior IDF officers told Israeli journalists that if Israeli forces launched a renewed offensive, it would be massive and very destructive.So far, the IDF has limited itself to a series of airstrikes across Gaza, though these appear to be increasingly frequent.On Saturday, Palestinian media reported casualties from an airstrike in southern Gaza near the town of Rafah. The IDF said an aircraft had struck a drone tracked entering Gaza from Israel as well as several suspects who collected it. A day earlier,the IDF saidit had targeted a group suspected of placing a bomb near Israeli soldiers in the east of Gaza City.Palestinian aid officials said two people had died when a drone â€œshot into their tentâ€. Aid officials and residents described similar incidents in the past week, and repeatedly hearing artillery fire, though the IDF has denied any extensive bombardment.In the first phase of the ceasefire, 25 living hostages held by Hamas in Gaza were released, along with the remains of eight others, in return for the release of about 1,900 Palestinian prisoners from Israeli jails. Israel also withdrew its forces from many positions in Gaza and allowed more aid to come in.In Gaza, humanitarian workers differ about the effects of the pause in hostilities. One senior UN official said aid organisations had been able to rehabilitate some schools and clinics, set up bakeries and build up stocks of diesel fuel that is vital to supply power and water to the population of 2.3m.More than half a million people have returned to what is left of their homes in northern Gaza after spending months in the south.But prices have soared since Israel imposed a strict blockade on Gaza, cutting off supplies of fresh fruit, vegetables and meat, as well as further aid shipments of tents and other essentials. The price of gas on the hidden market is 10 times higher than from aid organisations charged with its distribution. Israel accused Hamas of seizing and profiting from aid.â€œWe could be facing a quick deterioration. Every day we are hearing these statements of a return to war. Itâ€™s very difficult for people,â€ said Amjad Shawa, the director of the Palestinian NGOs Network in Gaza, speaking from Gaza City.â€œIt is a very sad city here. There is a lot of rubble and only a few bulldozers so we have opened a few streets and are trying to collect the remains of families under the ruins. We donâ€™t have the equipment we need but people are trying anyway.â€The Israeli offensive has killed more than 48,000, mostly civilians, and destroyed swathes of Gaza. It was triggered by a Hamas surprise attack into Israel in October 2023 during which militants killed 1,200 people, also mostly civilians, and took 250 hostages. Fewer than half of the 59 hostages still held in Gaza are believed to be alive.While Israel has said it wants to extend the current phase of the ceasefire until the end of the holy festivals of Ramadan in late March and Passover in mid-April, Hamas has insisted on a swift transition to the second phase, and a permanent end to the war.Zev Faintuch, head of research at Global Guardian, a US-based risk consultancy, said Israelâ€™s war aims remained unchanged: to eliminate Hamas, return the hostages, return its displaced civilians to border areas affected by hostilities and minimise any future threat.But at the same time, Hamas has remained faithful to its original goals: to thwart progress towards the normalisation of ties between regional Arab states and Israel, isolate Israel diplomatically, widen divisions within Israeli society and retain control of Gaza. â€œThe four points on each side are pretty mutually exclusive,â€ Faintuch said.Diplomatic efforts to bridge the wide gap between Israel and Hamas have faltered, and there are now two competing plans for Gaza post-war.President Trump has said the US wants tooversee the displacement of Gazaâ€™s populationso the territory could be rebuilt as â€œthe Middle Eastâ€™s Rivieraâ€ and US officials have dismissed a $53bn reconstruction proposal put forward last week by regional Arab states.Trump has also threatened Hamas with destruction on social media, though it was revealed last week that the US is engaged in unprecedented direct talks with the militant Islamist organisation. Lovatt said that recent US behaviour had been unhelpful, though the direct talks left an â€œoutside chance of agreementâ€.Almazah al-Masri, a nurse in northern Gaza, said she was worried and frustrated. â€œUnfortunately, those involved in the discussions [about the ceasefire] do not care about whatâ€™s happening in Gaza or the wellbeing of the civilians there,â€ she said. â€œWe do not want war at all. We have already been destroyed.â€Explore more on these topicsGazaThe ObserverMiddle East and north AfricaPalestinian territoriesIsraelnewsShareReuse this content

title: German election winner Merz moves step closer to forming government | Germany | The Guardian
description: Conservative bloc and SPD to start full coalition talks as chancellor-in-waiting plans to revive ailing economy
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Conservative bloc and SPD to start full coalition talks as chancellor-in-waiting plans to revive ailing economy
Content: Friedrich Merz conservative bloc and SPD announced they had wrapped up exploratory talks and would move on to full coalition negotiations.Photograph: Annegret Hilse/ReutersView image in fullscreenFriedrich Merz conservative bloc and SPD announced they had wrapped up exploratory talks and would move on to full coalition negotiations.Photograph: Annegret Hilse/ReutersGermanyGerman election winner Merz moves step closer to forming governmentConservative bloc and SPD to start full coalition talks as chancellor-in-waiting plans to revive ailing economyAgence France-PresseSat 8 Mar 2025 14.35 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 15.53 ESTShareGermanyâ€™s conservative election winner,Friedrich Merz, came a step closer on Saturday to forming a government that he says will revive Europeâ€™s top economy and its armed forces with massive new spending.The bold moves are part of his plan to rebuild Berlinâ€™s standing inEurope, which Merz has said must respond to the sweeping changes driven by the US president, Donald Trump, that have rocked the transatlantic alliance.Merzâ€™s CDU/CSU bloc and the Social Democrats (SPD) of the defeated chancellor,Olaf Scholz, on Saturday announced they had wrapped up exploratory talks and would move on to the decisive stage of fully fledged coalition negotiations.â€˜A risky betâ€™: Friedrich Merz criticised over plan to lift Germanyâ€™s debt rulesRead moreâ€œWe concluded the consultations between CDU/CSU and SPD, and we have drawn up a joint exploratory paper,â€ Merz said.He praised the â€œextremely good and very collegial atmosphereâ€ of the talks that had passed a major hurdle less than two weeks after the 23 February elections.Merz said both sides shared â€œthe conviction that we have a great task ahead of usâ€. He said all were â€œaware of the great challenge we are facing â€“ above all the international situation, but also â€¦ facing the whole of Europeâ€.Merz said both sides had agreed on tough new steps to limit irregular immigration, including refusing all undocumented migrants at the borders, even those seeking asylum.The move was a key demand of Merz, who has stressed the need to win back voters from the far-right Alternative forGermany(AfD), which scored a record of more than 20% in the election.Lars Klingbeil of the SPD called Saturdayâ€™s deal â€œan important first stepâ€ and said both sides agreed on the need to â€œget our country back on trackâ€. He said his party had won assurances on key demands, such as a â‚¬15-an-hour minimum wage from 2026 and stable pensions.The plan is for Germany to have a new government by mid-April that would end half a year of political paralysis after Scholzâ€™s three-way coalition imploded in November.The probable future governing allies have already surprised European partners with their plan to spend hundreds of billions of euros to revive the ailing economy and rebuild the military.â€˜People see it as invasiveâ€™: did anti-green feeling fuel the rightâ€™s rise in Germany?Read moreThe ambitious plans would cast aside Germanyâ€™s historic reluctance to take on large-scale debt and see it invest in defence on a scale not seen since the second world war.The spending boost â€“ which Merzâ€™s Bavarian ally Markus SÃ¶der has termed an â€œXXLâ€-sized splurge â€“ comes in response to Trump and his administration casting doubt in Europe on the future strength and reliability of the Nato alliance.Alarm at Trumpâ€™s actions has added urgency to the talks, spurred by his public berating of his Ukrainian counterpart, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, in a White House meeting.The two parties are moving to talks on a detailed formal coalition agreement, including haggling over cabinet posts. Their spending plans would circumvent Germanyâ€™s constitutionally enshrined debt brake and exempt defence spending when it exceeds 1% of GDP.The parties also agreed a â‚¬500bn (Â£420bn) fund to invest in creaking infrastructure over 10 years.The SPD has long pushed for action on Germanyâ€™s economy, which has been mired in two years of recession. Merz voiced hopes on Saturday that the stimulus would help the economy grow by â€œone, preferably two, per centâ€.However, both proposals will need a two-thirds majority in the outgoing parliament, with the two big blocs needing the Greensâ€™ cooperation.Merz said new investment could flow into climate projects and voiced confidence that â€œwe will find a way together to achieve a constitutional amendmentâ€.But the Greensâ€™ co-chair Felix Banaszak warned they were â€œfurther away from an agreement today than we have been in recent daysâ€, criticising the fact that â€œclimate protection financing plays no partâ€ in the joint document.The CDU/CSU and SPD are in a hurry to push the changes through before a deadline looms. On 25 March the newly elected parliament will convene. From then on, the AfD and the far-left Linke will be able to block any such proposals.Explore more on these topicsGermanyFriedrich MerzEuropeOlaf ScholzAlternative fÃ¼r Deutschland (AfD)newsShareReuse this content

title: Two men arrested in India over alleged rape of Israeli and local woman | India | The Guardian
description: The two women were said to have been stargazing with three male travellers when the incident took place
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: The two women were said to have been stargazing with three male travellers when the incident took place
Content: Police at the scene of the incident in Koppal district in the southern state of Karnataka.Photograph: APView image in fullscreenPolice at the scene of the incident in Koppal district in the southern state of Karnataka.Photograph: APIndiaTwo men arrested in India over alleged rape of Israeli and local womanThe two women were said to have been stargazing with three male travellers when the incident took placeAssociated PressSat 8 Mar 2025 10.38 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 10.50 ESTShareTwo men have been arrested inIndiain connection with the alleged rape of an Israeli and a local woman.The Israeli woman and her homestay operator were said to be stargazing with three male travellers in Koppal town in southern Karnataka state on Thursday night.Police said three men on a motorbike approached them and asked for money. After an argument, the men pushed the male travellers into a nearby canal before sexually assaulting the two women.Ram L Arasiddi, a local police official, said one of travellers had drowned and his body was recovered on Saturday. The other two men swam to safety, he said.Koppal is about 217 miles (350 kilometres) from Bengaluru. Arasiddi said police had set up a special investigation team that arrested two of the suspects on Saturday. They were being investigated on suspicion of attempted murder, gang-rape and robbery, he said.Sexual assaults on women have become a prominent issue in India, where police recorded 31,516 rape cases in 2022, a 20% increase from 2021, according to the National Crime Records Bureau. The real figure is believed to be much higher given the stigma surrounding sexual violence and victimsâ€™ lack of faith in police.Rape and sexual violence have been under the spotlight since the 2012 gang-rape and killing of a 23-year-old student on a Delhi bus. The attack galvanised huge protests and inspired lawmakers to set up fast-track courts dedicated to rape cases and stiffen penalties.The rape law was amended in 2013, criminalising stalking and voyeurism and lowering the age at which a person can be tried as an adult from 18 to 16. The government approved the death penalty in 2018 for people convicted of raping children under age 12.High-profile cases involving foreign visitors have drawn international attention to the issue. Last year, in a video that was later deleted, a Spanish tourist said his wife had been raped in northern India, while an Indian-American woman said she had been raped at a hotel in Delhi. A British tourist was raped in front of her partner in Goa in 2022.Information and support for anyone affected by rape or sexual abuse issues is available from the following organisations. In the UK,Rape Crisisoffers support on 0808 500 2222 in England and Wales, 0808 801 0302 inScotland, or 0800 0246 991 inNorthern Ireland. In the US,Rainnoffers support on 800-656-4673. In Australia, support is available at1800Respect(1800 737 732). Other international helplines can be found atibiblio.org/rcip/internl.htmlExplore more on these topicsIndiaRape and sexual assaultSouth and central AsianewsShareReuse this content

title: Mormon church rocked by child sexual abuse allegations in California | California | The Guardian
description: Look-back window results in nearly 100 allegations against the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
Author: Edward Helmore
Headline: Look-back window results in nearly 100 allegations against the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints
Content: The Mormon temple in Salt Lake City, Utah.Photograph: Mervyn Rees/AlamyView image in fullscreenThe Mormon temple in Salt Lake City, Utah.Photograph: Mervyn Rees/AlamyCaliforniaMormon church rocked by child sexual abuse allegations in CaliforniaLook-back window results in nearly 100 allegations against the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day SaintsEdward HelmoreSat 8 Mar 2025 10.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 10.03 ESTShareThe Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints (LDS) in the US has been rocked by a slew of sexual abuse allegations launched against it in California in the latest scandal to hit the organization that is better known as theMormon church.A three-year look-back legal window that allows adult survivors of sexual assault to file claims inCaliforniahas produced almost 100 allegations of childhood sexual abuse by Mormon leaders.The claims, in keeping with similar allegations against theCatholic church, theChurch of Scientology, theBoy Scouts of Americaand other hierarchical institutions in the US, have a consistent theme: alleging that officials used their power to groom, manipulate and abuse children, and that senior leaders of the institution that either knew or should have known about the abuse did not act to halt it.US polygamous leader with 20 â€˜wivesâ€™ sentenced to 50 years for sexual abuse of childrenRead moreIn the most recent claims against the Utah-based church, five plaintiffs allege they were abused inSan Diegocounty, including three who say they were sexually assaulted by the top spiritual leaders of their congregations.Several allege they disclosed the abuse to other church leaders. A female plaintiff alleged that the leaders â€œacted to protectâ€ the abusers and the church â€œhandled the repeated allegations internally as a â€˜matter of sinâ€™ and not one leader reported any matter to policeâ€.A woman from Escondido alleged that she was sexually assaulted from 1961 to at least 1978 by two male family members, including a bishop and a â€œhome teacherâ€ assigned to deliver spiritual lessons.Another claim filed on behalf of the estate of woman alleges repeatedly abused by two LDS home teachers beginning in 1961. A man alleges he was abused between five and nine times over a two-month span in 1978 by his bishop, when he was 14. He alleges he later disclosed the abuse to the bishop of a different area but was â€œignored and disregarded plaintiffâ€.Another claims he was assaulted by a bishop in 1995 and reported the abuse to his father, who in turn reported it to an LDS official who warned him â€œthat he needed to support his sonâ€™s abuser or risk being excommunicated from the churchâ€.A fifth claimant claims he was abused, at age 16, during private lessons by a bishop who told him, the lawsuit alleged, that â€œif he kept quiet, he would go to heaven, but if he told of the abuse, he would go to hellâ€.Michael Carney, a Los Angeles attorney with Slater Slater Schulman,told the San Diego Tribunethat the LDS church is unique because of â€œhow much power and influence the church has over peopleâ€™s livesâ€.A church spokesperson said that â€œabuse of a child or any other individual is inexcusable. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints believes this, teaches this, and dedicates tremendous resources and efforts to prevent, report and address abuseâ€ and outlined steps related to abuse LDS church leaders and members are instructed to follow: stop the abuse, help victims receive care and comply with whatever reporting is required by law.But the spokesperson also noted that the cases were filed by a single contingency law firm, â€œwhich has aggressively marketed for clientsâ€ and many are decades old and some potential witnesses have died.â€œThe church takes these claims seriously and is carefully investigating each case individually,â€ the spokesperson added. â€œEarly investigation has revealed multiple discrepancies in many of the claims.â€The lawsuits against the LDS church have become so numerous, and with so many common threads, that attorneys want to consolidate the actions into a single multi-district litigation in the central district ofCalifornia.One focus of the litigation against the church involvesclaimsthat an LDS â€œhelp lineâ€ was used to suppress reports of abuse and shield abusers, not to help victims. The LDS churchâ€™sgeneral handbookdirects church leaders to â€œnot involve themselves in civil or criminal cases for members in their units without first consulting with Church legal counselâ€.â€œInstitutions are more concerned about their public appearance because that translates into monetary donations,â€ said Mitchell Garabedian, an attorney known for representing sexual abuse claims against the Catholic church. â€œHistory has taught us that first and foremost institutions protect themselves and not the child.â€But the success of claims against individuals and institutions is not as legally sure-footed as it was at the onset of the #MeToo movement seven years ago. Earlier this week, Jay-Z filed a lawsuit against attorneys Tony Buzbee and David Fortney and their Jane Doe client over a lawsuit claiming sexual abuse that that was subsequently dropped.Jay-Z â€“ also known as Shawn Carter â€“ proposed three causes of action to an Alabama court: malicious prosecution, abuse of process and civil conspiracy against all three defendants, as well as defamation against the Jane Doe, claiming the allegations of rape against him were knowingly â€œfalseâ€ and â€œmaliciousâ€.Next month, movie mogul Harvey Weinstein, 72, faces retrial in New York on rape charges after his earlier convictions five years ago for the third-degree rape of one woman and a first-degree criminal sex act against another woman were tossed on appeal.According to Wendy Murphy, a former sex crimes prosecutor and director of the Womenâ€™s and Childrenâ€™s Advocacy Project in Boston, itâ€™s harder to prove liability in claims against institutions because the plaintiff needs to show that a high-level officer had knowledge and failed to take action. With institutions that are in some ways structured around secrecy, claims of offenses in cases dating back decades can be especially difficult to establish.â€œThe capacity to structure secrecy so that they can somehow avoid being held accountable by the way they create their power structures also means they have to accept the consequences that a lot of bad stuff is going to happen,â€ Murphy said.Despite efforts to weaken liability standards, Murphy said, deference to the sanctity of religious organizations provides â€œunbelievable natural insulation from accountability and oversight, not just because thatâ€™s how the legal standards are set up but because of an added layer of first amendment protections. Law enforcement often doesnâ€™t want to intrude behind the doors of godly places.â€Whatever the legal outcome of abuse claims against the Mormon church, says Garabedian, any change will probably come externally from the legal framework of institutional protections.â€œInstitutions are icebergs unto themselves, so the real change comes from the public realizing that institutions are not properly supervising and protecting children,â€ he said, â€œand the public is now more aware that they have to watch their children.â€In the US, call or text theChildhelpabuse hotline on 800-422-4453 or visittheir websitefor more resources and to report child abuse or DM for help. For adult survivors of child abuse, help is available atascasupport.org. In the UK, theNSPCCoffers support to children on 0800 1111, and adults concerned about a child on 0808 800 5000. The National Association for People Abused in Childhood (Napac) offers support for adult survivors on 0808 801 0331. In Australia, children, young adults, parents and teachers can contact theKids Helplineon 1800 55 1800; adult survivors can seek help atBlue Knot Foundationon 1300 657 380. Other sources of help can be found atChild Helplines InternationalExplore more on these topicsCaliforniaMormonismSan DiegoUS crimeUtahWest CoastnewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Iâ€™m like the TV Lorraine - just more swearyâ€™: at home with the queen of the small screen | Television | The Guardian
description: Sheâ€™s the chatty daytime presenter with a nice line in withering putdowns. But as a judge once ruled, thatâ€™s just a role she performs. So who is the real Lorraine Kelly?
Author: Simon Hattenstone
Headline: Sheâ€™s the chatty daytime presenter with a nice line in withering putdowns. But as a judge once ruled, thatâ€™s just a role she performs. So who is the real Lorraine Kelly?
Content: Kelly photographed at home earlier this month with her dog Angus. Photograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianSheâ€™s the chatty daytime presenter with a nice line in withering putdowns. But as a judge once ruled, thatâ€™s just a role she performs. So who is the real Lorraine Kelly?BySimon HattenstoneSat 8 Mar 2025 02.00 ESTShareLorraine Kelly opens the front door with a huge smile. â€œYou interviewed me, years ago, dâ€™you remember?â€ Now she looks disappointed. â€œAch, you donâ€™t, do you?â€ Of course I remember. And sheâ€™s hardly changed. Iâ€™ve brought a photo of us on the GMTV sofa to show her. Back then, sheâ€™d just turned 40, was a staple of breakfast telly and was about to launch her own show; a household name, if not quite the mononym she is today. Now sheâ€™s 65, her show is still on ITV five mornings a week, and last year she was awarded a lifetime achievement Bafta. Oh, and sheâ€™s just reinvented herself as a bestselling novelist. TheÂ Island Swimmer, which reached No 2 in the Sunday Times hardback fiction charts, is about to come out in paperback.â€œSo howâ€™ve you been?â€ she asks. Kelly is the kind of person who you can pick up with where you left off a quarter of a century ago. Sheâ€™s also the kind of person you feel you know, even when you donâ€™t. Perhaps thatâ€™s been her great gift as a TV presenter. She was a good journalist as Scotland correspondent for TV-am but not outstanding. Sheâ€™s a decent interviewer, but she wonâ€™t be remembered for her incisive interrogations or scoops. What she is brilliant at, though, is being Lorraine â€“ warm, likable, nosy, funny, occasionally steely and sharp-tongued, sometimes potty-mouthed and always 100% herself. Which is why it was a shock in 2019 when she told a tax court that theLorraine on TV is different from the real Lorraine; that on television she performs the role â€œof a friendly, chatty and fun personalityâ€.Her Buckinghamshire cottage, backing on to the Thames, is as you might expect â€“ plush but super homely. Inside, there are big comfy sofas and piles of illustrated cushions (one is of a saintly looking Dolly Parton, another of Angus the dog is captioned: â€œThis house is solely for the convenience of our border terrierâ€). Paintings of Angus, daughter Rosie and her husband of 33 years, Steve, adorn the walls. You canâ€™t move for family photos â€“ her grandparents dressed to the nines; her newlywed parents gorgeous at 18; Rosie with her baby daughter Billie. She dotes over the last photo. â€œSee, I am a real Granny Smith!â€ she says. I look at her, puzzled. â€œThatâ€™s my married name! Steve is Steve Smith.â€ Iâ€™m already beginning to see the difference between Lorraine Kelly the TV show presenter and Lorraine Smith, wife, mum and grandma.Daytime TV regulars will know just how obsessed she is with being a grandmother. She canâ€™t stop talking about it. Wow, I didnâ€™t know you were a gran, I say. NowÂ itâ€™s her turn to give me a look. â€œYou cheeky bugger. Well itisthe best thing thatâ€™s happened to me.â€View image in fullscreenKelly with her daughter Rosie, 2021.Photograph: Karwai Tang/WireImageThe Island Swimmer is pure fiction â€“ a romantic mystery about a woman returning to her home in Orkney after leaving unexpectedly many years ago. And yet look at the photos, explore her home, and you can see bits of Kellyâ€™s life in the book. The photo of her parents reminds me of the parents of the bookâ€™s protagonist Evie and her older sister Liv, with whom she has a troubled relationship. Kelly stops at another photograph â€“ this time herself as a six-year-old with her baby brother Graham. â€œThatâ€™s me looking dead happy that my wee brotherâ€™s here! I look like a demon.â€ Blimey, I say, you look just how I imagine the young Liv would in her furious jealousy. She bursts out laughing.â€œYessssssss!Hahahaha! Itâ€™s me as a child, oh my God!â€ It is exactly how she felt â€“ he was the golden child, and she had been usurped. She admits it inspired the relationship between Evie and Liv. â€œMy nose was put out of joint when he was born. But now I really like him. He just makes me laugh so much.â€ What did he think when he read the book? â€œHe thought it was hilarious. Itâ€™s not his thing, but he enjoyed it.â€™â€™ In the book, Liv is accused of attempting to drown Evie. Did she ever try to drown Graham? â€œOh no! It wasnâ€™tthatbad.â€Above the spices shelf in the kitchen, bottles of whisky are lined up like a military platoon. Which is her favourite? â€œI like Highland Park.â€ Highland Park gets an honourable mention in the book. â€œBut Steve and I are not guzzlers of whisky,â€ she says. Whatâ€™s their favourite tipple? â€œG&T,â€ she says. Funny how G&T is the drink of choice for a number of your characters, I say. â€œWell you have to write about what you know!â€She and Steve used to work together as part of a small team when they were young â€“ him as the cameraman, she as the journalist. â€œI knew right away as soon as he walked in the door. This wee fella from Dundee, IÂ thought, yep thatâ€™s him, thanks very much! Then it took me a year, but I got him in the end.â€ Why did it take her so long? â€œIt was a small working environment, there were only five of us. It was awkward.â€ What was special about him? â€œHeâ€™s the kindest man. Heâ€™s funny, he makes me laugh a lot, he puts up with me, heâ€™s very stable.â€On with the guided tour. Thereâ€™s a whole shelf of books dedicated to the explorerErnest Shackleton. â€œIâ€™mobsessedwith him. Always have been.â€ Kelly doesnâ€™t like standing still. She moves as quickly as she talks. We stop at the magnets on her fridge â€“ souvenirs from places sheâ€™s been to. One of her favourites is Twatt in Orkney. â€œI love that thereâ€™s a place called Twatt, as if you couldnâ€™t love Orkney enough.â€ She moves on to a photo of Steve with Billie. â€œThatâ€™s my husband with baby Billie, when she was just born. But I donâ€™t like to talk about Billie, as you know. Even though she is the best thingever.â€Is it better than being a mum? â€œWhen youâ€™re a mum you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re doing. Now you have all the love and you donâ€™t have any fear.â€Angus is barking at the door. â€œCome and say hello to Simon!â€ Angus trots in, yappy and affectionate. AÂ second later Steve arrives back from a game ofpadel. Heâ€™s a stocky, handsome man in shorts and a Dundee United top. I ask him if heâ€™s still working. â€œNo!â€ When did he retire? â€œOh God, years ago, 10 years ago or something.â€Is it true that he watches all Kellyâ€™s shows?â€œYes, I Â do.â€ Is he a tough critic? â€œNooooo.â€â€œNoooo!â€Kelly echoes.â€œBut itâ€™s lovely that he watches.â€Would he ever say, that was a bit shite? â€œNo, I donâ€™t criticise. Iâ€™ll just say, well, that was a weird guest! We watch together, donâ€™t we, Angus?â€Kelly: â€œYou do, youâ€™re very good. As does my mother.â€Could he imagine Kelly retiring? â€œNo. She never will. Sheâ€™s a grafter. Sheâ€™ll always do something.â€â€œI do love the writing, though,â€ Kelly says. â€œItâ€™s great if you can just get in the zone. Iâ€™ve been very lucky to get a chance to do it.â€ Sheâ€™s aware that she might have remained unpublished if she hadnâ€™t been well known.Kellyâ€™s publicist had suggested we talk over lunch. I find interviewing while eating quite tricky â€“ too convivial to ask difficult questions. Thankfully lunch consists of three Caramel bars and a Penguin. We head off into the lounge as Kelly tells me despite her 40 years in the business, sheâ€™s never counted her chickens.View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianShe was born in the Gorbals, spent her early years in Glasgow and then moved to East Kilbride 20-odd miles away. Her father was a TV engineer and her mother a shop assistant; they were the talk of the tenement when they were the first family to get a colour television in the late 60s. â€œEverybody came to our living room to watch this Frank Sinatra concert.â€ She says her mum and dad seemed cooler than most of her friendsâ€™ parents, partly because they were younger and partly because they were into Dylan rather thanMantovani.She was a bright child â€“ though not as bright as Graham. She would have been the first in the family to go to university, had she not got a job on the East Kilbride News at the age of 17. From the off, she loved it, and was treated as one of the lads in a predominantly male environment. In 1983, she joined BBC Scotland as a researcher, and a year later became TV-amâ€™s Scotland correspondent. It was after covering the Lockerbie disaster for TV-am that she moved to London to present Good Morning Britain in 1989.Kelly says she has never lost the insecurity of a freelancer. She learned her lesson when she was sacked from GMTV while on maternity leave and replaced by Anthea Turner. Ever since, sheâ€™s always made sure sheâ€™s had something else on the go to fall back on, whether a radio show, newspaper columns or now, her novels.â€œRosie was teeny-tiny. Weâ€™d just moved south, we had a mortgage, and it was scary to have that peeled away from you. I wasnâ€™t a member of staff. I didnâ€™t haveÂ any rights. I didnâ€™t get maternity pay. Iâ€™d like toÂ think weâ€™re a bit more enlightened these days, and that wouldnâ€™t happen.â€Cow & Gate proved to be her unlikely saviour. The processed baby milk manufacturer agreed to sponsor aÂ slot on GMTV so long as Kelly presented it. From there, she went on to host her own show, Lorraine Live, and since then hasnâ€™t looked back.Oh dear God! I canâ€™t believe whatâ€™s going on in America. Itâ€™s heartbreaking. Itâ€™s being torn apartIn 2010, she launched her current show, simply called Lorraine. Itâ€™s changed little in format over 15 years, though they recently decided to accentuate the positive because the world is so bleak. â€œWe made a conscious decision that weâ€™ll try to see the light.â€ She means light as opposed to dark, rather than trivial. As an example, she cites a recent guest, Auschwitz survivor Renee Salt. â€œAt end of the interview she said: â€˜I just want peace. If Iâ€™ve got anything to say to the world itâ€™s for goodness sake please donâ€™t let this happen again.â€™ It was extraordinary. For someone to still have faith in humanÂ kindness and peace, wow! That teaches you a lesson,Â doesnâ€™t it?â€Does she worry we could see a return to fascism, with the rise of right-wing populism? â€œOh dear God! I canâ€™t believe whatâ€™s going on in America. Itâ€™s heartbreaking. Itâ€™s being torn apart. I donâ€™t see how we can go from Obama who, for all his faults, was a good man. How did we go from this articulate, compassionate, interesting person to what weâ€™ve got now? I do spend a lot of my time being baffled. I do.â€Trump has just announced his plan to turn Gaza into the Rivieraof the Middle East when we meet. â€œI mean â€¦â€ For a moment even Kelly is lost for words. â€œIt is easy to be depressed about everything. Thatâ€™s why I think we have to get the joy where we can. I did think it was going to be OK in this country when Keir Starmer got in because I thought, OK heâ€™s a bit dull, but we need grownups. And thenthe first thing he did was take away the heating allowance from pensioners. What are youdoing? Why would youdothat?â€View image in fullscreenWith husband Steve Smith after being made a CBE.Photograph: WPA/Getty ImagesThis is Kelly at her best â€“ demolishing arguments or policies not with logic or facts, but with blunt rhetorical questions that reflect what so many of us think. â€œThen he said things are really shit and theyâ€™re going to get even shitter. We donâ€™t want to hear that.â€ Now sheâ€™s on a roll. â€œWe really donâ€™t. There are ways of communicating that: â€˜Things are bad, we know, but donâ€™t worry because weâ€™re all trying our very best to make it better.â€™ You donâ€™t have to overpromise and underdeliver, but youÂ could just go, â€˜Weâ€™re going to do our best to make it better, stick with us!â€™ We donâ€™t want to hear all that negativity right now. We just donâ€™t. It might be me putting my head in the sand, but I donâ€™t think it is. We just need a bit of hope.â€And sheâ€™s still not done. â€œI donâ€™t recognise this government as a Labour government. And he keeps mythologising Margaret Thatcher which is â€¦ scary.â€Kelly has always said it the way she sees it â€“ though perhaps not as uncompromisingly as this. I ask whether she was political as a kid. â€œOh yes, I was in theAnti-Nazi Leagueand hadCNDbadges. When youâ€™re young you should absolutely be saying, this isnâ€™t good, this isnâ€™t right.â€ Not just when youâ€™re young, I say. She nods. â€œYou should be shouting from the rooftops.â€ She looks at my plate of Caramels. â€œGo on, have a biscuit.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionJesus Christ, David Attenborough gets people being shitty to him! I mean David Attenborough, who is holding the universe together!Why does she think the world has become so toxic? She stares at her mobile phone, and pokes it with her finger. â€œThat!All the villages had idiots and extremists, but they were sitting there on their own. Now theyâ€™ve found their kindred spirits on thisbloodything.â€ Sheâ€™s talking even faster and her voice is getting louder. â€œJesus Christ,David Attenboroughgets people being shitty to him! I meanDavid Attenborough, who is holding the universe together! People shout at him â€“ climate change deniers, hunters have a go at him. And you think, well if theyâ€™re having a go at him, whatâ€™s the point?â€People sometimes think of you as soft and mumsy, I say. â€œThe mad fools! Hehehehe!â€ But youâ€™re pretty tough? â€œI can be. Especially if Iâ€™m defending somebody or something that I believe in.â€ Such as? â€œWhen people are unkind. When I was at school there was this lovely person who was our bus driver, bravest person Iâ€™ve met in my life. Her name was Jane. She used to be a chap and was now a trans woman. Jane got people speaking shit to her, saying offensive things. I remember saying to somebody, â€˜Shut your face, donâ€™t be so bloody rude.â€™â€But, even then, she says people were more open-minded than they appear to be now. â€œWe were much more tolerant. Again, itâ€™s social media giving nutters a voice. It makes no sense to me. I know a fair few people who are trans and they just want to get on with their lives. I donâ€™t think trans people should have to come on the television, or be part of the debate, to justify their existence. I just think everyone has to be a bit more tolerant. Thatâ€™s why I put a trans person in my book.â€The elderly Freya is the wise, generous heart of The Island Swimmer. â€œFreya being trans is probably the least interesting thing about her. I was keen to show sheâ€™s just Freya. I love her. Sheâ€™s just a lovely, lovely person.â€ Itâ€™s touching how she talks about her characters as if they are friends â€“ or enemies. Just as she swoons over Freya, she rages over Evieâ€™s boyfriend, the controlling Jeremy. â€œHeâ€™s like all the horrible people Iâ€™ve met in my life distilled into one.â€ Why did she call him Jeremy? â€œItâ€™s the kind of name, with apologies to all the Jeremies in the world, you think: oh, heâ€™s going to be a knob.â€She looks down at Angus, adoringly. â€œLike Angus is a great name; a strong name. Apologies to everyone who canâ€™t help that their mammy called them Jeremy.â€ Kelly has just finished writing her second novel, and is currently editing it. She tells me proudly that sheâ€™s now signed a deal for a third and fourth.View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianEarlier this year, she hit out at â€œtoxic people in tellyâ€ â€“ particularly men. In an interview with the Mirror, she said: â€œThe behaviour of Gregg Wallace and other people that weâ€™ve seen, should it come about as all true, is appalling.â€ She talked about the abuse of power and said that TV bosses who enabled this behaviour were as much to blame as the perpetrators. Last year, she said some male presenters lacked â€œgenerosityâ€. Interestingly, she singled out former fellow morning TV star Phillip Schofield as one who was generous.Schofield resigned from ITV in 2023and was dropped by his talent agency after admitting to an â€œunwise, but not illegalâ€ affair with a younger colleague. Today, she says: â€œI think Phillip was awful daft. I think he made a lot of choices he shouldnâ€™t have. But all I can go by isÂ what it was like to work with him, and it was easy. He was lovely, and I think itâ€™s really sad.â€As I get older, I want to do other things. Iâ€™ve been doing this for 40 years, working my arse offKelly has recently been under attack herself. She has been criticised on social media for not presenting her show five days a week.An X account called LorraineKWatchkeeps track of her absences. At the end of last year, the account, which has 25,000 followers, concluded that she had only hosted 59.7% of the episodes. This year she has presented 67.5% at the time of writing. I thought she might laugh it off, but she doesnâ€™t. â€œItâ€™s really hurtful actually. It really is. Iâ€™ve not spoken about it before. Iâ€™m a grafter and I work really hard and Iâ€™ve had to take Fridays off for the past year. I just thought it was weird to care so much.â€ Why was she taking time off? â€œInitially, it was for my mum who has been ill. And it sort of brings you into line with everyone else because if you look at This Morning, everybody else does four days. And as Iâ€™m getting older, I want to do other things, more writing, all of that. Mate, Iâ€™ve been doing this for 40 years, working my arse off.â€I guess the difference is that your show is called Lorraine, I say. â€œI get that. I get that 100% because This Morning is just called This Morning and GMB is just GMB.â€ But she says it does feel horribly personal. â€œMaybe it just started off as a wee joke, but itâ€™s the way that everyone piles on. It starts off as a wee tiny thing and it gets bigger and bigger. I find it really sad.â€We talk about the highs. There have been so many, she says. And this is when you really see that Kelly is one of lifeâ€™s great enthusiasts â€“ a professional fangirl. She talks about meeting Star Trek heroes Leonard Nimoy (â€œMr Spock was my first crush!â€) and William Shatner; interviewing real-life space hero Buzz Aldrin; being sent to San Francisco for a zero-gravity flight for her 60th birthday; travelling to America on the QE2 with the Cure (â€œThey were delightful â€“ so polite and cuteâ€).She has been groundbreaking in normalising conversation about once-taboo topics such as miscarriage and menopause. In 2017, Kelly revealed that menopause had left her feeling â€œflat and joylessâ€. She only shared her experience because at the time she couldnâ€™t find a famous guest willing to talk about it.Perhaps the thing we remember most from her show are the spontaneous Lorraine moments, often when doing live links with the GMB show â€“ she toldEsther McVey she didnâ€™t remember her, after the Conservative MPsaid they used to work together;tore a strip off Jennifer Arcuri, the businesswoman who had an affair with Boris Johnson, for saying nothing in her interview (â€œWhatâ€™s the point in you coming on and not saying anything?â€). In 2023, she voiced surprise at Nigel Farageâ€™s relative youth (â€œIs he only 59? I thought he was a helluva lot older than that. Thatâ€™s astonishing. It just shows you get the face you deserve!â€)I ask about the lows. She struggles to think of any.Â TheÂ few there have been tend to be personal. â€œIÂ hadÂ a miscarriage, which was horrible, and I went back toÂ workÂ too fast. Thatâ€™s the thing I do. I plough on.Â ButÂ lows, not really.â€ She says she would love to have hadÂ moreÂ children.View image in fullscreenHair and makeup by Alice Theobald at Arlington Artists using makeup by Mario and hair by Sam McKnight.Photograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianIn 2019, she took HMRC to court after receiving a Â£1.2m tax bill. The battle was about whether she was an employee or a freelancer, and whether she appeared as a performer or herself. Kelly won the case, but for the first time she got a drubbing in the press. Judge Jennifer Dean ruled Lorraine â€œpresents a persona of herselfâ€ so could be described as a â€œtheatrical artistâ€, meaning payments to an agent were allowed as a tax-deductible expense. Judge Dean said: â€œFor the time Ms Kelly is contracted to perform live on air she is public â€˜Lorraine Kellyâ€™; she may not like the guest sheÂ interviews, she may not like the food she eats, she may not like the film she viewed but that is where the performance lies.â€ It made Kelly sound like a fake, and her USP had always been authenticity.Was that a low? â€œYes,â€ she winces. â€œThat was horrible. But we had no choice. We took them to a tribunal because what they were trying to do was unfair. They were trying to say that I was a member of staff when Iâ€™mÂ a freelance, so they sent me a massive tax bill.â€She says it felt like a David and Goliath battle against HMRC. â€œThe thing that has negated some of the stress and angst and bad publicity is that it has helped so many people â€“ not just people in the media or famous people, but, say, hairdressers and beauticians who had been treated as staff by HMRC but were actually freelancers.â€ How did it affect her? â€œYour peace of mind goes.â€To have argued that Lorraine is a character â€¦ I begin to say. She answers before I finish as she tends to do when sheâ€™s on the defensive. â€œYes, that was weird. But that was the only way we could do it.â€ A lot of people took the piss out of you, I say. â€œOh, they did but thatâ€™s OK.â€ Does she genuinely think that Lorraine is a character? Yes and no, she says. â€œI am a version of me on the telly. And yes, Iâ€™m kind of like that but Iâ€™m a lot more open, a lot more sweary, and Iâ€™m not that person. Thereâ€™s nobody that goes on television who is themselves.â€ She says sheâ€™s quieter in real life; less sociable. â€œI am not the life and soul of the party. My husband is. Iâ€™m the first one there and the first to leave. Iâ€™m at my happiest with people I trust and know, watching something on the telly and having a nice meal.â€What really hurt about the court case, she says, was people thinking sheâ€™s a tax dodger. â€œIâ€™ll show you my tax returns. I pay my taxes on time every year, of course I do.â€ She looks at my plate. â€œHave another biscuit.â€I ask Kelly if Steve was right when he said sheâ€™d never give up work. â€œI would do the telly as long as people want me to do it.â€ Is she enjoying getting older? â€œYes!â€ Is her brown hair natural? â€œLook, Iâ€™ve got grey.â€ Hardly any. â€œI know, but my mum and granny were the same, then it just went white. Like Helen Mirren. Sheâ€™s beautiful, but she still looks like a normal human being. Sheâ€™s not got the boiled-egg face. I donâ€™t like that. Iâ€™ve not had anything done. Iâ€™m too scared, and I donâ€™t want to. I want to look normal, I want to look like me.â€ Is there any pressure to have work done? â€œNot in the job I do, no. I was never hired for my looks!â€ She hoots with delight.Well you say that, but you have been hailed as a sex symbol. â€œHahhaha! By whom? Blind people?â€ Actually, it was the Daily Mail, among others. â€œWell itâ€™s very kind, Iâ€™ll take that all day long.â€ Sheâ€™s also been called a gay icon. â€œIâ€™ll take that all day long, too.â€ And sheâ€™s been labelled the nationâ€™s naughty mum. â€œI didnâ€™t know that. Iâ€™ll take that too.â€ What title is she going for next? She thinks. â€œNovelist of the year? No! I couldnâ€™t possibly!â€Sheâ€™s just delighted to still be working, still be relevant, and still be finding new things to do. â€œI love this stage of my life. Especially with the wee one.â€ She grins. â€œBut I donâ€™t mention her. I like to keep that quiet!â€The Island Swimmer by Lorraine Kelly is published by Orion in paperback on 13 March. title: Silence please: how book clubs without the chat help focus the mind | Books | The Guardian
description: A Silent Book Club is growing in popularity in Melbourne as an antidote to the social pressure of group discussions
Author: Stephanie Convery
Headline: A Silent Book Club is growing in popularity in Melbourne as an antidote to the social pressure of group discussions
Content: Silent book clubs have become global since one began in 2012 in San Francisco, with chapters opening on every continent.Photograph: Andriy Popov/AlamyView image in fullscreenSilent book clubs have become global since one began in 2012 in San Francisco, with chapters opening on every continent.Photograph: Andriy Popov/AlamyBooksSilence please: how book clubs without the chat help focus the mindA Silent Book Club is growing in popularity in Melbourne as an antidote to the social pressure of group discussionsGet our weekend culture and lifestyle emailStephanie ConverySat 8 Mar 2025 18.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 20.08 ESTShareItâ€™s commuter hour on a late-summer morning and the sun is still stretching through the leafy canopy of Melbourneâ€™s Queen Victoria Gardens. In the cool, concrete sanctuary ofMPavilionâ€“the cityâ€™s annual architecture installation/event space/public shelter â€“ a small group of people sit reading. Some recline on beanbags, some perch on stools; others lean against the fluted concrete wall, breeze running through their hair. For close to an hour, nobody speaks; they just read.This is Silent Book Club, where there is no required book list, no entry fee, no organised discussion. Just reading, quietly, in company.Billed as â€œbook clubs for introvertsâ€, Silent Book Club was started in 2012 when a couple of friends in San Francisco felt traditional book clubs involved too much pressure â€“ to read a particular book in a certain amount of time, to â€œhave something smart to sayâ€ â€“ so they started their own kind of club, where neither was required. Silent book clubs have become global since then, with chapters openingon every continent.50% of Australians want to read more â€“ but donâ€™t. So what is stopping us?Read moreTaken at face value, itâ€™s a project that seems steeped in contradiction. A good book should be absorbing â€“ why consciously gather to participate in a solitary practice that, if itâ€™s going well, should result in you ignoring each other? What makes this any different or better to sitting in a library on any given day â€“ especially if the other people reading around you are strangers?Sign up for the fun stuff with our rundown of must-reads, pop culture and tips for the weekend, every Saturday morningOn this morning, Skye Bennett, theMelbournechapterâ€™s founder, greets everyone gently. She invites them to take a seat wherever they feel comfortable, and to find a book if they donâ€™t have one: the Wheeler Centre, Melbourneâ€™s hub for all things literary, has set up a bookshelf against one wall of the pavilion. Itâ€™s stacked with books linked to ideas around community and gathering. Most attendees, though, have brought their own.Bennett says about 60 people attend the regular sessions she holds in Docklands onthe last Sunday of the month, and they often sit around reading for far longer than the set time. Today, about 10 people gather in the pavilion â€“ the small turnout likely a reflection of it being both a workday and an out-of-schedule, pop-up event. Thereâ€™s a bit of quiet chatter before reading time officially begins, but not much. And then we open our books.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Iâ€™ve witnessed many new connections and friendships form and flourish at Silent Book Club,â€™ says Skye Bennett, the Melbourne chapterâ€™s founder.Photograph: Silent Book Club MelbourneLast month,research commissioned by advocacy organisation Australia Readsshowed that more than half of us want to read more than we actually do, but even very engaged readers struggle to make enough time for it â€“ particularly those who work full-time. It doesnâ€™t bode well for recreational reading that many also said finding motivation for it was more difficult than scrolling through social media or watching television â€“ even when they said they read for leisure and pleasure.Bennett says many of the Melbourne participantsare keen readers but busy people, and Silent Book Club allows them to ensure they prioritise a reading habit among other competing tasks. It seems likely, too, that for those struggling with motivation, it may function like body-doubling â€“ a tactic used by some people with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder to accomplish tasks they find difficult by having a second person working alongside them, as a kind of social scaffolding.The low-expectations of social contact that goes along with it also seem to help people come out of their shell, Bennett says.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toSaved for LaterFree newsletterCatch up on the fun stuff with Guardian Australia's culture and lifestyle rundown of pop culture, trends and tipsEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionâ€œIt seems counter-intuitive that new friendships would be forged in a club that embraces silence, however Iâ€™ve witnessed many new connections and friendships form and flourish at Silent Book Club,â€ says Bennett.â€œItâ€™s quite typical for a participant to initially attend a meeting alone however leave in the company of others. I think thatâ€™s the beauty of Silent Book Club â€“ once the social pressure, expectations and obligations are removed, people feel permitted to connect with others in ways that feel comfortable and authentic to them.â€For Melbourne in particular â€“ famouslythe most locked-down city in the worldand still arguably in the long tail of Covid recovery â€“ thereâ€™s perhaps an understandable attraction to the idea of consciously spending time in company with minimal social pressure.Perhaps part of the attraction, though, is something slightly more numinous.At MPavilion, as the sun slowly creeps above the semi-open roof and the traffic hums in the background as we sink into our novels, the experience of Silent Book Club feels less like engaging in art with friends and more like meditation, or even prayer. Here we gather together with like-minded devotees, setting our own individual intentions for the time weâ€™ve carved out to participate in this, a ritual of reading. Itâ€™s church for people who love books.Explore more on these topicsBooksMelbourneLiteracyHealth & wellbeingfeaturesShareReuse this content

Headline: Sealing years of collaboration with their first official duo album, the singer and producer fuse folklore and the everyday with dazzling directness
Content: â€˜Wonder and darknessâ€™: Lisa Knapp and Gerry Diver.Photograph: Rosie Reed GoldView image in fullscreenâ€˜Wonder and darknessâ€™: Lisa Knapp and Gerry Diver.Photograph: Rosie Reed GoldThe ObserverFolk musicReviewLisa Knapp and Gerry Diver: Hinterland review â€“ folk at its most exalted(Ear to the Ground)Sealing years of collaboration with their first official duo album, the singer and producer fuse folklore and the everyday with dazzling directnessNeil SpencerSat 8 Mar 2025 12.00 ESTShareSince her 2007 debut,Wild and Undaunted, LondonerLisa Knapphas blazed an impressive trail at the avant edge of British folk, her bravura vocals lighting up self-penned songs and well-loved standards, while the inventive arrangements of partner and producerGerry Diverâ€“ now credited as co-creator â€“ have helped capture the wyrdness, wonder and darkness of folklore.OnHinterland, the pair repeat the trick to thrilling effect. Opener Hawk & Crow has Knapp at her larkish best, giving voice to a cast of birds over a stumbling, broken rhythm â€“ a kind of elfin Tom Waits. The spoken-wordTrain Songrelocates us to todayâ€™s mundane realities â€“ â€œpoplars tall, village hall, stately home, sewage worksâ€ â€“ before Star Carr whisks us back to theMesolithic Yorkshire sitewhere ritual headdresses of red deer antler hint at ancient raves.Along with intense fiddle playing from Diver, crepuscular instrumentation accompanies a clutch of traditional ballads; the tender romance of I Must Away Love, the murderous Long Lankin and the forlorn Lass of Aughrim, the last with Knapp in heartbreaking form. She sings carefully throughout but remains unafraid to spill the odd yowl and yelp; you get the whole person. Folk at its most exalted.Listen to Hawk & Crow by Lisa Knappy and Gerry Diver.Explore more on these topicsFolk musicThe Observeralbum reviewsShareReuse this content

title: Xiaolu Guo: â€˜Write less, in order to write strongerâ€™ | Xiaolu Guo | The Guardian
description: The author and film-maker on why she was inspired to reimagine Moby-Dick in her new novel, her love of Coleridge and returning to the â€˜addictive power of fictionâ€™
Author: Anthony Cummins
Headline: The author and film-maker on why she was inspired to reimagine Moby-Dick in her new novel, her love of Coleridge and returning to the â€˜addictive power of fictionâ€™
Content: â€˜I wanted the whole world on that shipâ€™: Xiaolu Guo.Photograph: Sophia Evans/the ObserverView image in fullscreenâ€˜I wanted the whole world on that shipâ€™: Xiaolu Guo.Photograph: Sophia Evans/the ObserverBooks interviewXiaolu GuoInterviewXiaolu Guo: â€˜Write less, in order to write strongerâ€™Anthony CumminsThe author and film-maker on why she was inspired to reimagine Moby-Dick in her new novel, her love of Coleridge and returning to the â€˜addictive power of fictionâ€™Sat 8 Mar 2025 13.00 ESTShareXiaolu Guo, 52, was born in China and lives in London. The author of more than 20 books in a variety of genres in Chinese and English, sheâ€™s also a film director whose awards include the Golden Leopard at the Locarno film festival, previously won by Claire Denis and Jim Jarmusch. This month she publishes two books: thepaperback of her 2024 memoir,My Battle of Hastings:Chronicleofa Year Bythe Sea, and a new novel,Call Me Ishmaelle, a retelling ofMoby-DickWhat led you to take onHerman Melvilleâ€™s1851classic?I was in New York, a foreigner walking around for a year while teaching at Columbia and writing my memoir,Radical[2023], and this was a parallel project, a philosophical experiment. Most people are Asiatic â€“ the worldâ€™s population is 60% Asian â€“ and with each novel I write, I ask myself in what ways a non-westerner from a non-biblical background can engage in dialogue with the western literary canon. The word â€œChristendomâ€ appears repeatedly inMoby-Dick. I wondered: what if people never knew what that is? If it said â€œTaoismâ€ instead, would you still listen to the story? Iâ€™m a guerrilla gardener â€“ I secretly go out planting trees in my neighbourhood â€“ and it made me think: can I somehow just bring ancient east Asian philosophy into this American landscape? Guerrilla sabotage. I wanted the whole world on that ship. I spent so much time figuring out how to get a black captain from the civil war period into dialogue with a Chinese Taoist sailmaker.And then thereâ€™s the headline twist. Why Ishmaelle rather than the original novelâ€™s Ishmael?I was so struck by stories of working-class Victorian girls who went to sea out of poverty and desperation. I drew on the case of Anne Jane Thornton, who met a captain from New York when she was 15. Those girls just wanted more life: they put on cabin boysâ€™ clothes, shaved their hair and went on the ships. A lot of them were discovered only when they were pregnant: the captain wouldnâ€™t know, because when a girl was discovered, the sailors would have sex â€“ a secret agreement. I was so struck by these cases that I almost forgot about the nautical journey: I wanted to write about Ishmaelleâ€™s journey, from Ishmaelle to Ishmael and then Ishmaelle again.In Chinese, Shakespearean language becomes utterly abstract and meaningless. Itâ€™s such a challenge, you give upIn content, the book is deliberately disruptive, yet in style it feels more traditional than your previous books. How come?I couldnâ€™t see the necessity to write novels any more afterA Loverâ€™s Discourse[shortlisted for the Goldsmiths prize for experimental fiction in 2020]. I had an overwhelming sense of nausea at the overproduced superfluousness of contemporary fiction. I donâ€™t have this need to consume â€œstoryâ€: I need to have a debate, a dialogue with truth; to think more, write less, and to address issues not in a political way but in a philosophical way, a poetic way. Write less, in order to write stronger. But somehow in this book â€“ the biggest Iâ€™ve ever written â€“ I was carried away by the characters. I have to confess, itâ€™s the first time. Iâ€™ve returned to the addictive power of fictionâ€¦ Our fascination with myth-making seems to be a human malady.Can you recall the first time you readMoby-Dick?It was in translation at university [in China]. In Chinese, the Shakespearean and biblical language becomes utterly abstract and meaningless â€“ itâ€™s such a challenge, you give up. The second time, in New York, I still found it difficult, especially the huge cetology chapter, which troubles most readers in English. Thatâ€™s pre-Wikipedia writing: youâ€™d never write a novel that way these days, but Melville just accumulates so much. Iâ€™d rather have the nautical stuff first-hand. He was very affected by the Essex whaling tragedy â€“ shipwrecked sailors who started to eat one another â€“ and I found thememoir by the shipâ€™s first mate, Owen Chase, more powerful than readingMoby-Dick10 times for research.What sways you to work in one genre or another?This question isnâ€™t a problem for a writer who isnâ€™t a wordsmith. Most writers are wordsmiths â€“ they invent the same stories every few years â€“ but I donâ€™t feel like Iâ€™m a writer. I think of something and play with it: I make a film and think, oh, thatâ€™s actually prose, or memoir, or verse. Iâ€™m very idea-led. A lot of my previous work is close to my life, because when I came to the west [in 2002], I suddenly became a young girl again and had a prolonged adolescence to discover myself in Europe as a woman. Turning 50, I realised I never really went deep into history. People change:Tolstoy became a vegetarian at 50, after eating 50 years of Russian sausage and Russian meat! Reading theAnglo-Saxon Chronicleand theDomesday Bookto writeMy Battle of Hastingswas part of a process of self-education in the dynamics of power over the past 1,000 years; it gave me confidence for thisMoby-Dickproject.Tell us what youâ€™ve been reading lately.Wordsworth and Coleridgeâ€™sLyrical Ballads, every night before bed for the past two weeks. Iâ€™ve been reading Coleridge for ever because ofKubla Khan: whenever a western author writes about Asia, you have this immediate feeling of generosity. â€œYes, man, thank you! You addressed the east, Iâ€™m gonna look at your work to find out why.â€ Itâ€™s like a dream language when I read Coleridge every night before bed. Wordsworth is much more rational, more structured.What was the last book you gave as a gift?Thomas Hardyâ€™sTess of the Dâ€™Urbervilles, which has one of the most original female characters in the British novel. For years, I loved DH Lawrence. I wanted to find out where his prose came from and had to go back to Hardy: so good. That same week, I gave someone John Fowlesâ€™sThe French Lieutenantâ€™s Woman. I had three copies at home, to keep it in easy reach, because I love that novel so much. I reread it again after visiting Lyme Regis [where itâ€™s set]. I wish we still wrote novels like that: reflectionandnarrative, not just narrative.Call Me Ishmaelleby Xiaolu Guo is published on 20 March by Chatto & Windus (Â£18.99). Delivery charges may applyMy Battle of Hastings: Chronicle of a Year By the Seaby Xiaolu Guo is published in paperback on 20 March by Vintage (Â£10.99).
