description: Participants view scenes of daily life as well as travel adventures â€“ then process the emotions they trigger through art
Author: Guardian staff reporter
Headline: Participants view scenes of daily life as well as travel adventures â€“ then process the emotions they trigger through art
Content: In the seven-day intensive VR program, participants experience scenes from daily life, as well as some more adventurous ones such as traveling to Paris or paragliding.Photograph: Courtesy of Creative ActsView image in fullscreenIn the seven-day intensive VR program, participants experience scenes from daily life, as well as some more adventurous ones such as traveling to Paris or paragliding.Photograph: Courtesy of Creative ActsVirtual realityâ€˜An ideal toolâ€™: prisons are using virtual reality to help people in solitary confinementParticipants view scenes of daily life as well as travel adventures â€“ then process the emotions they trigger through artAbigail GlasgowSat 8 Mar 2025 10.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 18.58 ESTShareOne Monday in July, Samantha Tovar, known as Royal, left her 6ft-by-11ft cell for the first time in three weeks. Correctional officers escorted her to the common area of the CentralCaliforniaWomenâ€™s Facility and chained her hands and feet to a metal table, on top of which sat avirtual realityheadset. Two and a half years into a five-year prison sentence, Royal was about to see Thailand for the first time.When she first put on the headset, Royal immediately had an aerial view of a cove. Soon after, her view switched to a boat moving fairly fast with buildings on either side of the water. In the boat was a man with a backpack, and it was as if she were sitting beside him. With accompanying meditative music and narration, the four-minute scene took Royal across a crowded Thai market, through ancient ruins, on a tuk-tuk (a three-wheeled rickshaw) and into an elephant bath with her backpacked companion. For Royal, these vignettes felt real enough to be deserving of a passport stamp.View image in fullscreenCreative Acts volunteers giving a virtual reality headset to a person.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of Creative ActsBefore Thailand, Royal had been held in the facilityâ€™s â€œrestricted housing unitâ€, orsolitary confinement. There, the only opportunity incarcerated people typically have to speak with each other is through cell vents or across the yard during recreation. Typically for this program, participants in solitary sit inside individual cells the size of phone booths known as â€œtherapeutic modulesâ€. In Royalâ€™s facility, she and fellow participants were separated by plastic dividers, and each participant was shackled to a metal seat attached to a table.The VR stirs up the triggers and the trauma and the emotions â€“ and then the art transformsSabra Williams, Creative Acts founderIn the seven-day intensive VR program, participants experience scenes from daily life, as well as some more adventurous ones such as traveling to Paris or paragliding, for four hours each day. Facilitators ask them to process emotions that come from these scenes through various art exercises involving theater tactics, poetry, painting, etc.â€œThe VR stirs up the triggers and the trauma and the emotions â€“ and then the art transforms,â€ Sabra Williams, the founder of Creative Acts, the organization behind the program, shares. The non-profit conducts the program both in general population and in solitary.Now released, Carlos Ortega went through the virtual reality program in March of last year while in solitary confinement at Corcoran state prison. At 6ft tall, he remembers needing to sit down on the provided stool within the solitary cage to immerse himself in the VR scenes, even though the headsetâ€™s 360-degree view was programmed to work within the cageâ€™s confines.â€œIf youâ€™re not mindful of your body in prison, that can lead to conflict. Weâ€™re always aware of the amount of space we have, so I didnâ€™t fidget a lot,â€ he shares. Ortega rarely bumped into the walls, carefully moving his torso and neck in order to take in his surroundings. â€œIt was difficult, but we worked with what we got.â€Freedom within â€“ and from â€“ a controlled environmentâ€œThe micro environment is really, really controlled,â€ Ortega goes on to explain. Even when he would try to initiate interaction with prison guards, he would get shut down. â€œI would always say, â€˜Hey, good morning. How was your drive here? How are you doing?â€™ Iâ€™d mostly get a glare or a look like â€˜Why do you care?â€™ Itâ€™s kind of humiliating.â€View image in fullscreenAn incarcerated person uses a VR headset.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of  Creative ActsCreative Actsseeks to work against this hardened environment. The California-based organization relies on the arts as a resource for behavioral change and practical preparation for coming home from prison. With VR in four institutions â€“ Valley state prison (VSP), Kern Valley state prison, Corcoran state prison and the Central California Womenâ€™s Facility (CCWF) â€“ the organization has more requests coming in from other California facilities. Plans to expand beyond the state, however, can not be fulfilled due to lack of funding, according to Williams.Williams first had the idea to bring VR into prisons five years ago. After founding Creative Acts in 2018, she said she â€œgot real tired of hearing people come home after life sentences, having done multiple decades inside, and literally landing on a different planetâ€. She felt there was an urgent need for her organization to visually puncture the concrete barriers separating incarcerated people from the outside world. â€œAs the world was changing out here, we missed it,â€ said Star Van Pool, Creative Actsâ€™ program facilitator, who was incarcerated for 17 years.So when Williams heard about a rudimentary VR program led by correctional officers in another state, she began to workshop how her organization could safely and humanely adapt this work. â€œI was looking for something that would bring the outside world inside. I heard that VR works on your brain as if youâ€™ve had the experience,â€ Williams said. â€œIt seemed like an ideal tool.â€Breathing through the overwhelming emotions of the everydayIt took a year for Creative Acts to persuade Meta to donate 20 headsets and two of itsCleanboxheadset sanitation machines for a VR pilot. Meanwhile, Creative Actsâ€™Alumni Labworked with content makers includingUnincarcerated Productionsto produce scenes reflecting the collective fears and curiosities that arise when preparing to come home from prison, such as exiting the facility on release day, conducting a job interview or going on a date.For Major Bunton, Creative Actsâ€™ director of programming, the big fear was paying for groceries. â€œIf Iâ€™m sitting in line, swiping my credit card, and I canâ€™t get it done, the first thing that comes to my mind is â€˜Oh my God, someoneâ€™s going to know Iâ€™ve been incarcerated,â€™â€ he said.To film a Thanksgiving dinner scene, Williams made an entire meal â€“ â€œI cooked a terrible turkey,â€ she quipped â€“ and brought in actors to demonstrate various conflicts that could come up when interacting with a loved one who has just come home from prison. When a person puts on the VR headset to experience this scene, it is as if they are at the table. â€œWhen I came home, I had to realize that my family had changed. I had to learn how to adapt to their lives,â€ Bunton shares. â€œAnd conversely, they saw me as the person I was when I went in 20 years ago.â€ Williamsâ€™ goal is for participants to get a handle on the rollercoaster of emotions that comes after long-term separation through these family-conflict scenes.View image in fullscreenVolunteers assist people with their VR headsets.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of Creative ActsWilliams says that the programming is not about therapizing or diagnosing anyone; itâ€™s about providing them with the tools to feel and be aware of their own emotions in an otherwise repressive environment. Daniel Garcia, a participant incarcerated at Valley state prison in rural central California, got upset experiencing a scene in which a person bumped into him on a crowded street inLos Angeles. Following a breathing exercise while still in VR, Garcia said he was able to calmly consider how he might better resolve this type of conflict. â€œA lot of us, when we do come to prison, weâ€™re not aware of the triggers from traumatic experiences that weâ€™ve had, so we just react. VR helped us recognize those triggers.â€ Introducing this level of emotional awareness supports participants in coping and responding differently because, as Van Pool shares, â€œif a person doesnâ€™t even understand why theyâ€™re angry or where it came from, they canâ€™t change their behaviorâ€.The transformative scene for Ortega was sitting around the Eiffel Tower. â€œYou see tourists, regular people going to and from work,â€ he said. â€œAnd thatâ€™s when it hit me: I want to live life like that. I deserve it. I owe it to myself.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toTechScapeFree weekly newsletterA weekly dive in to how technology is shaping our livesEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionAs a responsive exercise, Creative Acts gives participants physical masks to paint. On the outside o the mask theyâ€™re asked to portray how they believe society perceives them; on its inside, how they see themselves. On his mask, Garcia wrote â€œcondemnedâ€ with cracks on the outside, to reflect his sentence of life without parole. â€œBut I want to be bigger than that,â€ he said, â€œso on the inside I painted a sunset, full of life, so bright.â€Working through â€˜a lot of painâ€™ in virtual realityReflecting on her experience in VR six months ago, Royal shares that she initially â€œsaw a lot of painâ€ when the group started. â€œBut by the end, I saw smiles on the faces of all these women and the ability to trust somebody again,â€ she said. Released from solitary confinement within two months after donning the headset, Royal still conducts unified breathwork she learned from the program with people in the prison if she senses conflict.View image in fullscreenSome incarcerated people have reported transformative experiences when using the VR devices.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of  Creative ActsGarcia similarly retains his meditation practice, oftentimes putting in earbuds to quiet his surroundings, slowly counting while envisioning a sunset. Matias Magana, another program participant at Valley State, shares that now he says hello to individuals he never would have spoken to had it not been for his Creative Acts group. For him, â€œweâ€™re breaking cultural boundariesâ€. And Ortega, who spoke sporadically on a Tuesday when he had gone to Creative Actsâ€™ office to pick up some of his old art, says that he now finds himself â€œbeing comfortable in the uncomfortableâ€. His birthday was the second to last day of his Creative Actsâ€™ experience; he still has the sticky notes the facilitators put on his â€œtherapeutic moduleâ€ with birthday wishes from everyone.Closing a solitary unit after virtual reality workshopsIn response to Creative Acts programming, facilities are witnessing an immense change. â€œPrison is toxic. You become accustomed to it: the corruption, the duplicitousness. Hell is normalized,â€ Ortega said. But prisons that have piloted the VR program report a 96% reduction in infractions from incarcerated participants in solitary confinement, according to Creative Acts. Corcoran state prison in rural centralCaliforniasaw the number of infractions of the men in solitary go from 735 to one after one week-long session. One of Corcoran wardens commuted so many solitary confinement sentences that the facility closed one of its four buildings dedicated to the practice.The organization attributes this level of transformation to the role that art plays in encouraging people to redirect their anger, share and process their trauma, and envision, quite literally with the help of VR, a world beyond the bars that confine them.Pros and cons of tech in prisonsIntroducing new technology into prisons has inspired skepticism as well as praise. Making available tablets with texting, email and books en masse in prisons has also made way for anotherpredatory profit channelfor companies, increased the ability to further surveil incarcerated people, and createdfalse promises of more connectionoreducation. Many argue that tech is just a bandage solution that only serves to maintain an inhumane carceral system. Others say that working with the same prisons that continue to incarcerate people in droves cannot possibly benefit those inside. Williams has grappled with these critiques.I learned that, even if someone has nothing in common with me, I can find a way to connect with themSamantha â€˜Royalâ€™ Tovarâ€œAnything can be used to cause harm, [and] people will always make money off of anything that goes into prisons, so the benefits for the people inside, to me, outweigh the issues,â€ Williams says when discussing the introduction of tablets and other technology inside prisons. For the Creative Actsâ€™ founder, the key to administering VR is by utilizing team members who have endured incarceration themselves to thoughtfully facilitate the experience as well as providing trauma-informed art exercises paired with every scene. As for criticisms about working with the California department of corrections and rehabilitation rather than against it, Williams has a consistent motto: â€œDo you want to be right, or do you want to make change? You canâ€™t make deep cultural change without including the people that work there.â€View image in fullscreenCritiques of the VR program have included that it helps maintain an inhumane carceral system.Photograph: Sam Richardson/Courtesy of Creative ActsStill, the non-profit must go the financial and physical lengths of bringing VR inside prisons while many of the scenes that participants interact with in their headsets are just on the other side of their cell walls. However, participants said the small doses of virtual freedom and exposure to the outside world shifted their behaviors and perceptions more than solitary confinement ever did.â€œI learned that, even if someone has nothing in common with me, I can find a way to connect with them,â€ Royal shares. She will parole from prison in May and feels more confident in her ability to build a community for herself. For Ortega, Creative Acts laid an emotional foundation that informs the work heâ€™s doing upon release. â€œI feel content, Iâ€™m more tolerant, people call me reliable again. I go to AA and NA meetings, Iâ€™m in school. I actually started my own program. Itâ€™s called Dream Catchers. Iâ€™m trying to catch that dream that I didnâ€™t catch before.â€Explore more on these topicsVirtual realityUS prisonsCaliforniaSolitary confinementWest CoastfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Musk? Heâ€™s horrendousâ€™: Martha Lane Fox on diversity, tech bros and International Womenâ€™s Day | Martha Lane Fox | The Guardian
description: The investor and former Twitter board member believes rejecting DEI initiatives is simply denying US firms talent
Author: Richard Partington
Headline: The investor and former Twitter board member believes rejecting DEI initiatives is simply denying US firms talent
Content: Martha Lane Fox said companies that take diversity seriously appeal to the widest employee talent pool and are better placed to target a broad range of customers.Photograph: Matt Crossick/AlamyView image in fullscreenMartha Lane Fox said companies that take diversity seriously appeal to the widest employee talent pool and are better placed to target a broad range of customers.Photograph: Matt Crossick/AlamyThe ObserverMartha Lane FoxInterviewâ€˜Musk? Heâ€™s horrendousâ€™: Martha Lane Fox on diversity, tech bros and International Womenâ€™s DayRichard PartingtonThe investor and former Twitter board member believes rejecting DEI initiatives is simply denying US firms talentSat 8 Mar 2025 02.37 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 08.37 ESTShareAs Elon Musk grinned in the Oval Office, one of Britainâ€™s most influential tech investors looked on in horror. â€œHe is absolutely horrendous. I have said it multiple times: I think it is horrifying what is happening,â€ saysMartha Lane Fox.For the British peer and ex-Twitter board member, the sight of Musk holding forth from the bully pulpit of Donald Trumpâ€™s White House shows theSilicon Valleydream has gone sour.â€œThe richest man in the world, who can stand there alongside the president, and kind ofcarte blanchemake jokes about how heâ€™s carving up peopleâ€™s jobs in the government. Then he can be there with achainsaw laughing on stageâ€¦â€œIt is really, really alarming, and I find it extremely unpleasant at a values-based level â€“ but also, just how can we be watching this in plain sight? It makes me feel very anxious. I think it is gross.â€In an interview with theObserverto mark International Womenâ€™s Day, the president of the British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) warned the diversity pushback orchestrated by Trump and his tech bro acolytes will not only damage society, but also the economy at large.What Musk is doing is really alarming. How can we all be watching this in plain sight? I think it is grossSince his return to the White House, the US president hasshut down all federal diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) initiatives,while Muskâ€™s â€œdepartment of government efficiencyâ€ (Doge) is ripping up funding schemes.Some of the worldâ€™s biggest companies are following suit. Amid a wider pushback against everything from environmental targets to sustainable development, among themost prominenttaking part are US finance and tech companies, including Goldman Sachs, Accenture and Amazon, whileUK businesses such as GSK have also fallen in line.â€œHe needs to be contained,â€ Lady Lane Fox says of Muskâ€™s role in the rollback. â€œI find it extraordinary that the richest man in the world is trampling all over these things and that we still have kind of fanboying from the tech sector. Itâ€™s already been corrosive for society, and I would argue it is going to continue to be.â€For businesses, she says the bottom line is that companies that take diversity seriously appeal to the widest possible employee talent pool and are better placed to target a broad range of customers. This, she adds, is about profit as much as social justice. However, she has a broader concern about the future.â€œThe first thing, itâ€™s financial. But the second thing, itâ€™s about power and money â€“ like everything, right?â€œIf youâ€™re looking at a sector like the digital sector, where thereâ€™s the growth in jobs, growth in opportunity â€“ it is the growth sector in the economy. Yet you are not including a whole bunch of people in that. Then you are going to be creating inequality. Full stop. So itâ€™s financial and itâ€™s a question of social justice.â€Given the close ties between Britain and the US, there is a view that where corporate America treads, the UK naturally follows. But there are signs that some UK businesses â€“ and even the British operations of some US companies â€“ are prepared to stand apart.The accountancy firm Deloitte instructed staff working on contracts for the US government toremove pronouns from their emails, while also announcing the end of its DEI programme. But its UK boss told staff its British operations remained â€œcommitted to [its] diversity goalsâ€.â€œIt feels as though global companies rooted in the US are making a politically motivated slight shift in emphasis and tilt, through to rowing back everything. And it does feel a bit more tempered here,â€ says Lane Fox.UK businesses have an opportunity to do something different, she says, which could bring financial benefits. â€œI think weâ€™ll build more robust companies, attract talent and have a much better shot at building the most resilient companies of the future.â€For almost three decades, Lane Fox has built a career â€“ and multimillion-pound fortune â€“ in tech. She made her first big moneyfloating Lastminute.com, the online travel site co-founded alongside fellow Oxford graduate Brent Hoberman in 1998.View image in fullscreenElon Musk holds court with his son X in the White Houseâ€™s Oval Office in February.Photograph: Abaca/Rex/ShutterstockShejoined the board of Twitterâ€“ now X â€“ in 2016, landing herself a huge payday in Muskâ€™s$44bn hostile takeoverin 2022, before he dissolved the board and appointed himself the sole director.Seeing Musk in the Oval Office,parading his son X on his shoulders, made her question the gender divide. â€œCan you imagine if that was a woman? Can you imagine what that would look like? I mean, I just think the whole thing is really gross.â€Trump signs executive order expanding power of Elon Muskâ€™s Doge agencyRead moreBut while railing against Musk in a personal capacity, the BCC president does not suggest this approach is for everyone. â€œIt is really tricky to navigate. You have a responsibility to your customers and your employees that might be different to our personal view sometimes.â€Government regulation to enshrine diversity targets is also a bad idea, she says, preferring instead that companies report their progress. â€œKeeping it in the light, keeping up the reporting, is important â€“ keeping up good investors, looking at the right metrics and investing in the right companies all helps.â€However, not enough progress is being made. Analysis this week showed that worsening unemployment and workforce participation for women haspushed the UK behind Canadato its lowest global ranking for workplace equality among large economies in a decade.The gender pay gap has been declining slowly over time, butaverage pay is still 7% lessfor women than for men. It is a challenge Lane Fox is all too aware of. â€œLook at the data and it is really freaking depressing â€“ and it is not moving,â€ she says.â€œWhat worries me is that itâ€™s far too easy to find numbers that I thought we were moving on from.â€œIn this week of International Womenâ€™s Day, we see representation at the executive level has gone back. I see progress on boards is still good at the FTSE 100 level, but bad at FTSE 250 and 350 level.â€œI know there will be people in the sector thinking: â€˜Oh, here she goes again.â€™ Thatâ€™s true of many women [that people think that]. But it is so important to keep making these arguments.â€Explore more on these topicsMartha Lane FoxThe ObserverInvestingInternational Women's DayElon MuskTrump administrationDonald TrumpSilicon ValleyinterviewsShareReuse this content

title: Skype got shouted down by Teams and Zoom. But it revolutionised human connection | John Naughton | The Guardian
description: The company that pioneered voice communication over the internet has withered to dust in Microsoftâ€™s hands. Still, I for one am grateful for it
Author: John Naughton
Headline: The company that pioneered voice communication over the internet has withered to dust in Microsoftâ€™s hands. Still, I for one am grateful for it
Content: The first to bring the magic of free telephony to consumers: Skype, 2003-25.Photograph: Sheldon Cooper/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenThe first to bring the magic of free telephony to consumers: Skype, 2003-25.Photograph: Sheldon Cooper/SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty ImagesThe ObserverSkypeSkype got shouted down by Teams and Zoom. But it revolutionised human connectionJohn NaughtonThe company that pioneered voice communication over the internet has withered to dust in Microsoftâ€™s hands. Still, I for one am grateful for itSat 8 Mar 2025 11.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 16.47 ESTShareSo Microsofthas decidedto terminate Skype, the internet telephony company it bought in 2011 for $8.5bn (Â£6.6bn). Its millions of hapless users are to be herded into Microsoft Teams, a virtual encampment with a brain-dead aesthetic that makes even Zoom look cool. This eventuality had been telegraphed for quite a while but, even so, it comes as a jolt because Skype was a remarkable venture, and its demise closes a chapter of an interesting strand of technological history.The internet has been around for much longer than most people realise. It goes back to the 1960s and the creation of Arpanet, a military computer network that emerged after the US had its â€œSputnik momentâ€ â€“ the awful realisation that the Soviet Union seemed to be racing ahead in the technology stakes. The design of Arpanetâ€™s successor, the internet we use today, started in the early 1970s and it was first switched on in January 1983.The designers of the network were, from the outset, determined to avoid the limitations of earlier communication systems, particularly the analogue telephone network, which was optimised for voice, hopeless for digital signals and owned by corporations which resisted innovations that they themselves had not originated. So the new network would not have an owner or be optimised for any particular medium, and would therefore be more permissive than any earlier network. Anyone could access it, and create services that ran upon it, so long as their computers conformed to the protocols of the network.The result was the explosion of creativity â€“ good and bad â€“ that we are still living with today. What the internetâ€™s designers had built was what a scholar later called â€œan architecture for permissionless innovationâ€; or, put another way,a globalplatform for springing surprises.The world wide web, created by Tim Berners-Lee in the late 1980s, was one of those surprises. But so too was something called VoIP (voice over internet protocol). Speech could be digitised (converted into ones and zeroes) and put into data packets which could be sent over the internet; and then, having reached their destination, converted back into audio. The result: free telephony to anywhere in the world!Skype was the first company to bring this magic to ordinary consumers. It was founded in 2003 by Janus Friis (a Dane) and Niklas ZennstrÃ¶m (a Swede) and headquartered in Luxembourg; but the software that powered it was written by three Estonians who also wrote software for peer-to-peer file sharing. In 2005, eBay bought it for $2.6bn (Â£2bn). By 2006 it had 100m registered users and by 2009 was adding about 380,000 new users each day and generating around $740m (Â£575m) in annual revenue. So you could say thatSkypewas the first European company to reach US-level scale.I grew up in a time when a phone call from the US meant only one thing: a death in the family. If emigrants kept in touch with the folks back home, it was only by letterAt which point the inevitable happened: in 2011 Skype was bought byMicrosoftand absorbed into the maw of the tech colossus. Many observers, including this columnist, wondered what Microsoft thought it was doing with its new toy. Last weekâ€™s news suggests that the company never quite figured it out. And in any event, once the pandemic arrived in 2020 and people started working from home, it was clear that Microsoft would need to have something to ward off the threat posed by Zoom. Skype conceivably could have been at the core of its response, but instead the decision was made to put all the energy into making Teams the behemothâ€™s answer to remote working. From then on, Skype was surplus to requirements and the die was cast.Before it disappears, though, itâ€™s worth remembering what an energising newcomer it was on the scene two decades ago. Most people nowadays have no idea how closed and depressing telephony was in the analogue era. It was an industry run either by complacent, unresponsive and domineering monopolies (AT&T in the US) or government agencies (the GPO in the UK). It could take months to get a telephone installed in your home. Phone calls were expensive and international calls positively prohibitive.I grew up in a country (Ireland) with a huge diaspora in a time when a phone call from the US meant only one thing: a death in the family. If emigrants kept in touch with the folks back home, it was only by letter and perhaps the odd parcel; never by phone. In rural Ireland, on the night before a son or a daughter departed for America or Australia, their family would sometimes hold a wake, because they assumed they would never hear their voices again.And now? The VoIP technology that Skype brought into peopleâ€™s lives has been commoditised. Social media platforms such as WhatsApp and Signal offer unlimited â€“ and free â€“ audio (and video) connections with friends, families and colleagues all over the world. Phone calls that would once have bankrupted a family are made every day. Microsoft may not have found Skype useful in the end. But the rest of us certainly did.What Iâ€™ve been readingThree-market economyDave Karpfâ€™ssharp essayidentifies the three types of money behind Silicon Valleyâ€™s power.Bringing back sovereigntyAninsightful editorialinNoemaby Nathan Gardels on why the current and 47th US president is behaving like the 25th.Fighting talkA seismic regulatory clash is in the offing, says David Allen Greenâ€™sprescient analysisin theFinancial Times.Explore more on these topicsSkypeThe networkerMicrosoftInternetZoomTelecomsComputingcommentShareReuse this content

title: Meet-cutes, boysâ€™ bedrooms and buff bodies: meet the people behind TikTokâ€™s viral vox pop accounts | Life and style | The Guardian
description: From the woman who asks to see teenage boysâ€™ rooms to the gang who want to know how couples found love, some people are attracting a huge following (and financial rewards) from being nosy - and asking one killer question
Author: Michael Segalov
Headline: From the woman who asks to see teenage boysâ€™ rooms to the gang who want to know how couples found love, some people are attracting a huge following (and financial rewards) from being nosy - and asking one killer question
Content: Rachel Coster: â€˜A lot of boys have no idea whatâ€™s in their room.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianView image in fullscreenRachel Coster: â€˜A lot of boys have no idea whatâ€™s in their room.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianLife and styleMeet-cutes, boysâ€™ bedrooms and buff bodies: meet the people behind TikTokâ€™s viral vox pop accountsFrom the woman who asks to see teenage boysâ€™ rooms to the gang who want to know how couples found love, some people are attracting a huge following (and financial rewards) from being nosy - and asking one killer questionMichael SegalovSat 8 Mar 2025 09.00 ESTShareâ€˜Boy, will you show me your room?â€™Rachel Coster,@boyroomshowTikTok followers: 232,400Instagram followers: 71,400Rachel Coster (pictured above) loves boys. â€œTheyâ€™re fun,â€ she says. â€œIÂ love to date them, befriend them, and see how they decorate their bedrooms. Women, I think, from childhood are taught how to keep a home. Itâ€™s less ingrained in the culture of raising young men, so a lot of them are misguided when it comes to domesticity.â€New York-based Coster, 28, is a comedian with aÂ background in film production. During the Sag-Aftra film and television actorsâ€™ strike in Hollywood, jobs were few and far between. â€œI sent a few one-sentence ideas to a new social media production company for short-form digital shows,â€ she says. â€œBoy Room was one of my pitches: Boy, will you show me your room?â€A proof-of-concept was shot at a friendâ€™shouse. â€œHeÂ told me a girl had been over the previous night, refusing to stay because of the mess, then asked what he should do to change his room.â€ On camera, Coster surveyed the scene. â€œThrow out the garbage, put your clothes in a dresser, and put sheets on your bed. HeÂ nodded along, gratefully.â€At first, she didnâ€™t tell participants that her focus was untidy rooms. â€œBut turns out these boys donâ€™t feel shame about their messiness,â€ she says. â€œIt made no difference if we told them. Some boys, it transpires, are proud of their mess. Others do start to reflect on their choices in an outsiderâ€™s presence: youâ€™re right,Â whydoI have a 30-month-old boiled egg on myÂ bedside table?â€There are plenty of messy-home TV formats, butÂ Costerâ€™s tone is different: nonâ€‘judgmental. She has shot at least 40Â episodes now, and themes are emerging. â€œA lot of boys have no idea whatâ€™s in their room: a housemate left that; an ex-girlfriend this. Lots of garbage. They often lack ownership of their space. And thereâ€™s a lack of concern for their cleanliness and comfort. Like,whydo you want to sleep on a yellowing pillow, a stained, broken mattress and a disgusting quilt? Itâ€™s so easily fixable.â€The intimacy of the format is what makes it endearing. â€œIn the same way we like to watch Architectural Digest on YouTube to see how the rich and famous live, itâ€™s also nice to see how normals do.â€ Itâ€™s this, she believes, alongside some of the muckier moments captured (â€œThink extremely yeasty smells or baked-in cigarette stench â€“ one boy had maybe 7,000 vapes in a drawer and behind his bedâ€) that keep viewers coming back. â€œNothing gets more comments,â€ she says, â€œthan a handsome boy living in total squalor.â€â€˜How did you two meet?â€™Jeremy Bernstein, Aaron Feinberg and Victor Lee (below, from left),@meetcutesnycTikTok followers:1.8 millionInstagram followers:2.9 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜Early on, we were only looking for the best meet-cute stories.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianTwo years ago, friends Aaron Feinberg, Jeremy Bernstein and Victor Lee werenâ€™t even onTikTok. Now, itâ€™s an occupation for the three 30-year-old New Yorkers. Feinberg handles partnerships and collaborations; LeeÂ oversees editing and posting; Bernstein is the voice, politely accosting random couples on the street, and probing into their relationships.It was Leeâ€™s baby, initially. He was working in his family clothes manufacturing business. â€œThe first question you ask a couple,â€ he says, â€œis where did you guys meet? Maybe it could be something â€¦ â€ He floated the idea of asking strangers on camera past Feinberg.â€œI thought it was fun,â€ says Feinberg. â€œWe didnâ€™t realise what it could become, but I knew we had the perfect person to ask the questions in Jeremy, who wouldnâ€™t be afraid to stop people â€“ and he won the most distinguished voice award at high school.â€Bernstein wasnâ€™t interested at first. â€œI was selling renewable energy on the street, so, yes, I was always approaching strangers. But when Aaron suggested we do this, I took quite a lot of convincing.â€ However, interviewees were receptive to the concept from the getâ€‘go, says Bernstein, â€œalthough we had to learn about the physicality. How to approach someone in a non-threatening way is key,â€ he says. â€œFirstly, itâ€™s body language â€“ making yourself small and smiley. Then, get to the â€˜Are you two a couple? How did you meet?â€™ questions immediately. Once people hear that, they relax.â€They have heard some remarkable stories: highâ€‘school sweethearts, chance encounters, arranged marriages. â€œMy favourite,â€ says Lee, â€œis the onewe titled Tunnel Vision.â€ In it an older gentleman who was a train supervisor at Grand Central station explains how he met his wife, 30 years ago. For days, he kept moving trains on to the platform he worked nearest to, to try to find a beautiful woman he had noticed getting out of a carriage. She grins, standing next to him, as he tells the story, and says: â€œI had no idea!â€Itâ€™s no wonder people love it. The group have started working on a book, and begun franchising. â€œWeâ€™ve just opened aMeetCutes London account,â€ says Feinberg â€“ a British friend goes out to record, â€œand weâ€™re interviewing to hire people in Paris and Madrid. Weâ€™reÂ off camera, so we can recreate it globally.â€To date, the lads have interviewed maybe 7,000 couples, but only post a small fraction. â€œEarly on, we were only looking for the best meet-cute stories,â€ says Bernstein. â€œNow weâ€™re also asking about the relationship: whatâ€™s your favourite thing about your partner? What advice do you have for a new couple?â€They have each used these lessons in their own love lives. â€œMy favourite piece of advice, which Iâ€™ve taken into my relationship, is â€˜Never stop datingâ€™,â€ says Lee. â€œIâ€™ve been with my fiancee for six years. Itâ€™s so easy to fall into a routine and be lazy.â€â€œAs someone looking for a relationship while asking all these couples questions,â€ says Bernstein, â€œmy main takeaway is that thereâ€™s no one way to do it. People have such different types of romantic relationships.â€â€˜Whatâ€™s your dream?â€™Simon Squibb,@simonsquibbTikTok followers:6.1 millionInstagram followers:3 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜I wanted to make my son proud â€“ not just sit around and play golf.â€™Photograph: Simon SquibbFor Simon Squibb, 49, perfecting the question was key. â€œAÂ dream is both something weâ€™re never really asked, but also feels safe to admit,â€ he says. â€œMuch bigger than an objective thatâ€™s fleeting, or a resolution that comes and goes. Ask someone their dream, and you get to the heart of what they want from life.â€This is exactly what he does when approaching strangers on the street. â€œIâ€™m an entrepreneur, and investor in startups,â€ he says. â€œI offer free business knowledge, support peopleâ€™s dreams, and promote them on my channel.â€ In essence, heâ€™s an iPhone-wielding, street-scouring, one-man Dragonsâ€™ Den.Squibb, who lives in Sussex, started his first business aged 15. â€œI had no choice, having been made homelessÂ when I fell out with my mum.â€ His dad had recently died. â€œI couldnâ€™t get a job, so I started my own gardening company. IÂ asked someone who knew I was struggling for help. They were selling courses, andÂ offered to support me â€“ for a fee. I couldnâ€™t afford to pay. I vowed one day, if IÂ could afford to help people for free, I would.â€In2015, Squibb sold his business â€“ a Hong Kong-based creative and digital agency â€“ to PricewaterhouseCoopers. â€œI made life-changing money. I wouldnâ€™t need to work again. I took two years off. My wife and I had a baby. But I wanted to make my son proud, I realised â€“ not just sit around and play golf.â€He thought back to his hustling teenage self. â€œI knew so little about business. School hadnâ€™t equipped me for it at all. I wanted to help educate others, and TikTok is where young people were.â€No doubt his advice is gratefully received. He has also invested in 79 businesses to date. Most significant, though, is the exposure a chance encounter with Squibb and his camera brings: millions of followers; 315mÂ monthly views. â€œLots of people still think you shouldnâ€™t film kind gestures,â€ says Squibb, â€œthat IÂ should offer my advice privately, else itâ€™s tainted. Thatâ€™s stupid; part of the help I can offer is eyeballs. Why not use social media for social good?â€œNot long ago, someoneâ€™s reply to me was, â€˜I want to travel and take picturesâ€™.â€ Squibb had a think. â€œHow do we get there? Not, I said, saving money and planning. Letâ€™s get you a sponsor. That video clocked 112m views.lastminute.comoffered to sponsor her â€“ now sheâ€™s travelling the world, filling their social media feeds.â€ There was a woman in Lewes, getting off the bus. â€œShe said her dream was to be a fashion blogger and designer. Twenty-four hours later, she had 300,000+ followers. Done. The rest is up to her.â€œMy whole life is built around this concept: whatever I want to achieve, put a business model behind it. Teach people the basics, and any dream is possible.â€Simon Squibbâ€™s bookWhatâ€™s Your Dream?, published by Century, is out nowâ€˜What do you do for your workout?â€™Mark Langowski,@bodybymarkTikTok followers:527,200Instagram followers:1.5 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜Of course fitness trainers have the perfect workout. But what about real people?â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The GuardianThe approach, for Mark Langowski, 44, who lives in New York, still feels a little icky. His street-interview format relies on the camera rolling before the first question is asked â€“ initially filming someone without their consent. â€œI try to get them walking towards me,â€ he says, â€œso Iâ€™m looking two blocks ahead. Then I have a split second to scan them and decide if they look fit. I donâ€™t love that.â€ After making a judgment on their physique, heâ€™ll ask: â€œWhat do you do for your workout?â€ The shtick is simple, but the results are compelling: revealing the dedication of the majorly muscled, uberâ€‘athletic and, often, shirtless.The scale of the challenge varies seasonally. â€œInÂ summer and springtime New York, itâ€™s obviously easier to spot someone fit: tank tops, vests and workout gear; lots of skin on show,â€ he says. â€œWinter and fall are harder. Itâ€™s why I travel to Miami or Los Angeles at that time of year.â€He has been in the fitness business for 20 years, and started TikTokâ€‘ing 18 months ago. â€œIâ€™m a personal trainer by trade. I already had theInstagramaccount of a traditional fitness influencer: me and my clients working out; showing my abs off,â€ he says. â€œI got bored with it. Sick of the narcissism. I knew I needed a presence for my business, to keep myself relevant. But how to without making it all about me?â€Then, inspiration. â€œI was in an exercise class, and saw this woman in the most spectacular shape. I wondered what she was doing? It couldnâ€™t just be this class.â€ He went out the next day to film on the streets of New York. â€œIâ€™m an introvert; Iâ€™d never approach a stranger. I was so self-conscious and nervous, holding the camera down by my waist.â€ After a few weeks, people started to know about the videos. â€œIt made things easier â€“ if someone was into fitness, the algorithm was probably already showing them my stuff. And people were keen to talk. Now, my videos have been seen more than 1bn times.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. Sign up to get the inside story from our top writers as well as all the must-read articles and columns, delivered to your inbox every weekend.Enter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionOccasionally, heâ€™s still thrown by interviewee responses, like â€œwhen I was interviewing a stripper at a nightclub who had been shot in the leg by his dad and said he never goes to the gym and hasnâ€™t been since high school, and yet he had a six-packâ€.Heâ€™s confident his films have real value for people who watch. â€œEveryone knows what fitness trainers or influencers do to work out,â€ he says, â€œthey tell you every day. Itâ€™s tedious â€“ofÂ coursethey have the perfect breakfast, perfect workout, perfect everything. Itâ€™sÂ their day job. But what about real people? Iâ€™m asking the construction worker, the stay-at-home mum of three, the doctor or shop assistant.â€Langowski has learned plenty himself. â€œYou start to see patterns: lift heavy weights, donâ€™t run too much, eat healthy, sleep a lot and donâ€™t drink much alcohol. Iâ€™m surprised at how little cardio very fit-looking people do.â€â€˜How much do you pay for rent?â€™Caleb Simpson,@calebwsimpsonTikTok followers:8.5 millionInstagram followers:2.5 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜At first, 100 New Yorkers told me to eff off. Then one guy in Brooklyn showed me his apartment. It went viral.â€™Photograph: Chris Buck/The Guardianâ€œEveryone is low-key a snoop, when it comes to homes,â€Â says Caleb Simpson, 33. â€œWe all want to poke around places.â€Simpson grew up in Morganton, North Carolina, â€œinÂ aÂ small house with eight siblings, very humble beginnings â€“ a food-stamps-and-white-rice sort of lifeâ€. He moved to New York in 2015, and soon started to make a living doing social media for startups. â€œI was also always trying to do my own thing,â€ he says, â€œmaking videos on YouTube and Instagram.â€Simpson had spent years wandering the streets of New York, looking up at buildings, imagining what was within. â€œI had this lightbulb moment: just ask to look inside. Now most people know me as the â€˜apartment tour guyâ€™ â€“ the dude who asks the questions: how much do you pay for rent? Can I see?â€ He has done about 300 apartment tours in New York. â€œGlobally, itâ€™s more like 500 now: Paris, London, Hong Kong. All major US cities.â€œIt began with being shown a bunch of middle fingers on the streets of Manhattan,â€ he says. â€œNew Yorkers are straight up â€“ they told me to eff off.â€ How many times? â€œMaybe 100. It was deflating.â€ Then, a yes. â€œA Â guy in Brooklyn showed me around his apartment. It went viral.â€ It hasnâ€™t stopped since.Simpsonâ€™s selections are dictated by his own sense of curiosity. â€œThere are lots of identical, cookie-cutter flats in New York, housing finance guys.â€ He no longer steps foot inside them. â€œIâ€™m not interested. Instead, itâ€™s places where I think: I want to see what that looks like. A strange building, low-income housing, rent-controlled places, someone who pays $70,000 a month.â€ He still roams the street looking for volunteers, but with 11 million followers on Instagram and TikTok, there is no shortage of doors opening these days; sometimes prearranged.What has he learned from the endless property perusal? â€œAll New York renters think theyâ€™re getting a deal, but, really, everybody is getting ripped off,â€ says Simpson. â€œAnd beauty really lies in the eyes of the beholder. Sometimes, I film small apartments, and people comment saying itâ€™s depressing, but the people who live there are thrilled.â€This is why, heâ€™s certain, itâ€™s not just beautiful Brownstone-owning Brooklynites who let him in. â€œPeople are proud of what they have,â€ he says, â€œon whatever scale, and they want to show the world. Price isnâ€™t the only determiner of worth or value: how they decorate, how they live in the architecture, how they found a place. And thereâ€™s the 15 minutes of fame that comes with letting me in.â€â€˜What do you do for a living?â€™Daniel Mac,@itsdanielmacTikTok followers:14.2 millionInstagram followers:2.8 millionView image in fullscreenâ€˜It was tough at the beginning â€“ Iâ€™m shy by nature. Money was the motivator. I wanted to know how to get rich.â€™Photograph: CraSH/Shutterstockâ€œWhen I started,â€ says Los Angeles-based Daniel MacDonald, 27, known online as Daniel Mac, â€œIâ€™d just moved to Dallas, Texas, from a small-ish town in Arizona where there werenâ€™t any Lamborghinis. Iâ€™d never seen supercars â€“ and was curious. How did the driver afford it? What could I, fresh out of college, do to get one?â€ Unabashed, he began walking up to their tinted windows to ask: â€œWhat do you do for a living?â€His first video clocked up 40m views. â€œWhen I posted it, I thought there was a glitch in the app and the numbers were wrong, but within a week Iâ€™d gained aÂ million followers on TikTok.â€ This quadrupled in aÂ matter of months â€“ all during Covid. â€œPeople were bored and needed cash,â€ he says. â€œThey wanted to get rich, and to find out how.â€Sometimes, answers are unexpected.He has stoppedformer stockbroker Jordan Belfort, rapper Wiz Khalifa and Shou Zi Chew, theCEO of TikTok. Mostly, though, the responses are fairly formulaic. â€œThe golden rule to getting rich, it transpires, is to invest, and buy real estate. Otherwise, common jobs are finance, healthcare, computer science and tech. Plus some trades, like plumbing and electricians â€¦ Accumulating wealth isnâ€™t that sexy, it transpires.â€How does he earn his living? â€œMy revenue is split into three buckets: roughly 40% from ad revenue paid out primarily by Facebook and Snapchat, then some from YouTube and TikTok.â€ Thatâ€™s his commission from the advertising that the platforms sell. â€œAnother 40% or so comes from brand partnerships.â€ Thatâ€™s the sponsored content. â€œInstagram brings in the most from this, then TikTok. And the last section comes from other miscellaneous things like speaking gigs.â€Raised in Tucson, MacDonald had just graduated with a degree in finance from the University of Arizona when he started his TikTok. Initially, he was reluctant to be in front of the camera. â€œIt was tough at the beginning,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™m shy by nature, and wasnâ€™t used to negativity and criticism, or people being mean to me online. Money was the motivator to continue. I wanted to know how to get rich.â€ It worked. In 2023, he bought his dream car: a $100,000 Porsche GT4.Thereâ€™s a candidness to interviewees, he reckons, when theyâ€™re filmed on an iPhone camera, with no chunky kit or team of producers. â€œIâ€™ve gotten people into hot water. One of thehigh-ups at Apple left the company after they made a lewd joke in a video of mine. People say stuff they regret.â€Certainly, a strata of the super-wealthy would be reluctant to publicly parade their wealth. But MacDonald preys on those in flashy cars â€“ the shy, modest and secretive types donâ€™t tend to drive Bugattis. â€œItâ€™s very American, for sure,â€ he says. â€œIâ€™ve tried filming in several other countries where people donâ€™t show off so much; they arenâ€™t as flashy. In London, people were far more reluctant to talk about money.â€â€˜Why are you a fan?â€™Morfo Peyiazis,@morfopeyiazisTikTok followers:47,800Instagram followers:15,600View image in fullscreenâ€˜Football fans are either portrayed as mindless, violent hooligans or as sugar-coated and family-friendly. Nothing captured the true, unfiltered chaos somewhere in between.â€™Photograph: Robin Lee / robin.p.leeLondon-based Morfo Peyiazis, 30, took a clinical approach to viral success. She worked in marketing before starting out as aÂ professional poster. â€œIÂ wasÂ pitching video ideas to brands,â€ she says, â€œparticularly football clients. IÂ wanted to do interviews embedded with fans, and got fed up with being told, â€˜No, itâ€™s too risky.â€™â€During Euro 2020, she spotted a chance. â€œFuck it,â€ she thought, â€œIâ€™ll make my own fan-focused series. Football fans are either portrayed as mindless, violent hooligans on the news, or, by their clubs, as sugar-coated and family-friendly. Nothing captured the true, unfiltered chaos somewhere in between.â€Getting in among it suited her personality. â€œI get it from my dad,â€ she reckons, â€œa crazy Cypriot man. Growing up he had so much energy, and so much empathy with people.â€Peyiazis saw TikTok as a way in to a more traditional telly career. â€œIn essence, I used it to create a public portfolio: a place to make your own pilots, and prove that your ideas are popular. My ambition over the nextÂ five years is to build a media brand, and I want to be future-proof.â€ Whether or not thatâ€™s possible on TikTok, sheâ€™s still unsure. â€œThe turnaround is so crazy. I couldnâ€™t tell you the last five videos I watched. Itâ€™s instant: bam-bam-bam. How to create long-term impact is challenging.â€ She has landed gigs with Channel 4 and Sky Sports.Thereâ€™s a natural warmth to her presenting style: playful, inquisitive, genuine interest in what her interviewees are saying. â€œI donâ€™t like being on the periphery; Iâ€™m there to soak up the experience theyâ€™re having.â€ Itâ€™s this attitude that explains Peyiazisâ€™s on-screen appeal, entirely unfazed by whatever sheâ€™s confronted with: hordes of screaming Celtic and Rangers fans at the high-octane â€œold firmâ€ derby; youngÂ men playing up to the camera once microphonesÂ are pointed in their direction. â€œAmong some of the supposedly most dangerous rivalries in theÂ world, IÂ feelÂ entirely safe. Having no fear, and gettingÂ stuck in. Youâ€™ve got to be able to hold your own â€“ and I can.â€Explore more on these topicsLife and styleSocial mediaTikTokInstagramDigital mediafeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Donald Trump is a bully, not a strongman. And Australia will pay for his destruction as he panders to the mega-rich | Julianne Schultz | The Guardian
description: Performance is all for the US president, who is intent on creating a world dreamt of by global libertarian thinktanks
Author: Julianne Schultz
Headline: Performance is all for the US president, who is intent on creating a world dreamt of by global libertarian thinktanks
Content: The US president, Donald Trump, leaves the White House after his meeting with the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelenskyy.Photograph: Carol Guzy/ZUMA Press Wire/REX/ShutterstockView image in fullscreenThe US president, Donald Trump, leaves the White House after his meeting with the president of Ukraine, Volodymyr Zelenskyy.Photograph: Carol Guzy/ZUMA Press Wire/REX/ShutterstockOpinionDonald TrumpDonald Trump is a bully, not a strongman. And Australia will pay for his destruction as he panders to the mega-richJulianne SchultzPerformance is all for the US president, who is intent on creating a world dreamt of by global libertarian thinktanksSat 8 Mar 2025 14.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 21.09 ESTShareFor six weeks we watched asDonald Trumpâ€“ primped with golden hair, bronzer, fat pens and a zigzag signature â€“ played the lead role in his new series, The Strongman. It was solid, not great, television, driven by an unspoken, looming threat â€“what will he do next?This makes sense if you understand that on the way to creating a new world order of unfettered, red-blooded, male-dominated American capitalism, there is also a cultural revolution. As Stephen Marchewrites in the Atlantic: â€œWashington today can be understood only as a product of show business, not of law or policy.â€True to the norms of show business, performance is all. There can only be one hero, everyone else must genuflect or cheer. So for weeks, other leaders, men who recognised that their power was not God-given or made in a TV studio, used the best tools their cultures bequeathed when dealing with erratic old men. The French president, Emmanuel Macron, charmingly patted The Strongman on the knee and quietly corrected him, the British prime minister, Keir Starmer, came bearing an invitation from a real king. Lower-order Australians raised on a diet of neoliberalism offered lower-order Americans squillions of dollars â€“ fordefenceandindustry.The dangerous folly of Australiaâ€™s come-what-may sycophancy towards Trump is on full display | Paul DaleyRead moreUnlike President Teddy Roosevelt, who in 1902invited Vida Goldsteinto advise on how America might copy Australia and give women the vote, few women of substance crossed the portal to this Oval Office.And then The Strongman momentarily dropped his guard, overreached and became his true self, The Bully, while his wingman, JD Vance, sat itching to lay a killer punch on the war-weary president of Ukraine.Volodymyr Zelenskyy sat quietly, the loss of his people and country heavy on his shoulders, until he was goaded into trying to set the record straight.Trump must have loved being able to land his line: â€œThis is going to be great television.â€ No wonder some commentatorsthought it was planned. Close watchers thought it was one of those stoushes that got out of hand whenthe wingmanâ€™s ignorance was challenged.Any woman who has ever been treated as though they were from another, lower, speciesrecognised the tactics. Belittle, gaslight, talk over, threaten, demand gratitude and dismiss.It has long been clear that women were to be Trumpâ€™s first target. He has made no secret of his contempt for women for decades, choosing to believe his mythic self-creation: â€œWhen youâ€™re a star, they let you do it. You can do anything. Grab â€™em by the pussy. You can do anything.â€He quickly turned to attacking diversity, equity and inclusion policies, suggesting that the fatal collision between the Black Hawk helicopter and an American Airlines planewas the result of DEI. He began outlawing such policies, not just in government departments funded directly by the state, but every organisation that received grants, and every business that had a connection with the government. That included all the big ones of the old and new economy; public money is the lifeblood of many American enterprises.The speed with which corporations fell into line was astonishing. The values that had been trumpeted for decades â€“ of inclusion, opportunity, reflecting the diversity of society and tapping the best talent even if they werenâ€™t white men â€“ evaporated. Forget the triple bottom line, sustainability and equity.The Australian branches of American companies followed the directives from head office â€“scaling back policiesthat had begun to change the face of their workforces. The Australian Stock Exchange appeared to embrace the opportunity andabandoned new diversity reporting plans for listed companies.Australian legislation to impose stronger gender and equity requirements on companies with government contractsstill awaits Senate approvalbut it has started to change the nature of work and the opportunities available to women, as theincome inequality data this week showed. It has been slower for other under-represented groups. The opposition, which has never managed to ensure appropriate representation of women in its own party, grasped the prospect ofabolishing rules that ensured the public sector workforce reflected society.The DEI attack was the first telltale sign of the sort of society Trump wants to create, one dreamt of for years by global libertarian thinktanks. The destruction of USAid underlined this single-mindedness, along with removal from the Paris climate agreement and the World Health Organization, and undermining the National Institutes of Health.Our worst politicians are wondering if they can make Trumpism work here. Why not? | First Dog on the Moon|Read moreThese institutions are not window dressing. They did real good, gathered useful information,saved lives and enabled societies to function with a degree of humanity and safety. They softened the blows of unfettered capitalism and recognised the power of interconnectedness.I write this waiting for Cyclone Alfred to cross the coast a kilometre from my house â€“ ferocious winds and rain are threatening the worst. This is not random but a cyclone propelled too far south bytropical water temperatures, supercharged by the global heating that capitalism has refused to constrain.American power is unprecedented. Its military bases dot the globe, its companies drive national economies, its popular culture shapes minds. But sticking to his script, the alacrity of The Strongmanâ€™s determinationto go it alone and create opportunities for the mega rich is astonishing.Fifty years of effort to save capitalism from itself, to be inclusive, to respect the environment and rule of law, to use unprecedented knowledge to ameliorate likely impacts, has been jettisoned. Instead, the tech revolution, embraced by The Strongman and powered by the worst imperial notions, will leave a trail of extraordinary destruction and missed opportunities for a better, fairer world.And in the wake of another International Womenâ€™s Day, it is worth stating the obvious:women and the poor will suffer most.Julianne Schultz is the author of The Idea of AustraliaExplore more on these topicsDonald TrumpOpinionUS politicsAustralian politicsWomencommentShareReuse this content

title: The Observer view: Europe must now come of age as a global player | Observer editorial | The Guardian
description: As Trump upends old alliances, Keir Starmerâ€™s collaboration with EU leaders is welcome and should extend beyond defence
Author: Observer editorial
Headline: As Trump upends old alliances, Keir Starmerâ€™s collaboration with EU leaders is welcome and should extend beyond defence
Content: The French president Emmanuel Macron at last weekâ€™s special meeting in Brussels.Photograph: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenThe French president Emmanuel Macron at last weekâ€™s special meeting in Brussels.Photograph: Ludovic Marin/AFP/Getty ImagesThe ObserverEuropeThe Observer view: Europe must now come of age as a global playerObserver editorialAs Trump upends old alliances, Keir Starmerâ€™s collaboration with EU leaders is welcome and should extend beyond defenceSat 8 Mar 2025 13.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 15.14 ESTShareBritain and Europe are together facing a watershed moment,a turning point, a secondZeitenwende,a paradigm shift, a new world order.Regardless of which of these overused phrases best describes the dramatic shifts unfolding since Donald Trump began his second US presidential term in January, politicians, diplomats and analysts all agree: nothing will be the same again. The key question now is what, in practical terms, Europe and Britain can and will do to meet this challenge. Is this Europeâ€™s moment, when it finally comes of age as a global player? Or will the EU and its close neighbours collectively fail to rise to the occasion, condemning their citizens to an era of domination by bigger, rapacious and more determined powers?Donald Trump is in the process of attempting, rashly, to dothree extraordinary things. First, he is trying to force Ukraine, which has spent more than three years under murderous assault, to accept a â€œpeace dealâ€ on inimical terms dictated by himself and the aggressor, Vladimir Putinâ€™s Russia. Second, in a stunning reversal of US policy, he is seeking a rapprochement with Moscow that includes re-establishing full political and diplomatic relations, lifting sanctions and launching joint economic partnerships. Third, he is telling Europeans they must henceforth defend themselves, that the US, in effect, is no longer a loyal, reliable partner or even necessarily a friend, and that Nato, for 76 years the solid bedrock of transatlantic security, is dispensable.European leaders, with some exceptions on the political fringes, are united in their alarm at all three of these unwise, irrational and dangerous interventions. At the same time, most accept that even if Trump vanished entirely â€“ a desirable but unlikely eventuality â€“ a change in the balance of US-Europe relations is inescapable and overdue. In a national address last week, Emmanuel Macron, Franceâ€™s president,summed up the position well. â€œEuropeâ€™s future should not be decided in Washington or Moscow,â€ he said. â€œThe war in Ukraineâ€¦ continues with the same intensity [but] the US, our ally, has changed its position.â€ As a result, Europe was entering a new era of self-reliance.Nato is a crucial shield for Poland, as it is for the three neighbouring Baltic republics. Now its removal or weakening is threatenedAccused of appeasing Putin in 2022, Macron, like many others, has learned better since. Now he warns that Russian imperialist aggression â€œknows no bordersâ€, directly threatening France and Europe. Macron is not just talk. He has shown imaginative leadership, producing a tentative plan for astaged ceasefirethat has Ukrainian support, lobbying, flattering and correcting Trump to his face in the Oval Office, and promoting an Anglo-French proposal to deploy a European â€œassurance forceâ€ in Ukraine composed of a so-called coalition of the willing.In a week that saw repeated recourse to another overused phrase â€“ the need for Europe to â€œstep upâ€ â€“ Germany surprised many with a positive leap into the future. A country that nurtures visceral horror of debt announced a spectacular U-turn of its own â€“ the amending of its Basic Law to permit multibillion-euro investments in defence and national infrastructure. Friedrich Merz, the Christian Democrat who held off the far-right to win last monthâ€™s federal election, has a reputation as a deficit hawk and fiscal conservative.Not any more. And he has gone further even than Macron inurging Europeâ€™s â€œindependenceâ€from the US and vowing ongoing, expanded military aid for Kyiv. Other European leaders, notably Donald Tusk, have â€œstepped upâ€ in commendable ways. Polandâ€™s prime minister is in an unenviable position. A strong believer in the transatlantic alliance, he, like so many others, must now feel utterlybetrayed by Trump.Nato is a crucial shield for Poland, as it is for the three neighbouring Baltic republics. Now its removal or weakening is threatened.Keir Starmer also recognises the historic nature of this moment, and has risen to meet it. He has worked assiduously and carefully to restrain Trumpâ€™s worst instincts. His evident contempt, displayed in the Commons last week, for the ignorant comments of US vice-president JD Vance about â€œrandom countriesâ€ showed he is not afraid to push back, too. Starmerâ€™s collaboration with EU leaders is a very welcome post-Brexit development that should be extended beyond defence and security. Yet like them, the UK faces daunting hurdles. Although they now recognise the necessity, their shared, chronic dependence on the US will behard to break.These challenges â€“ on reducing Europeâ€™s reliance on America, boosting its defences and maintaining support for Ukraine â€“ were the focus of last weekâ€™s emergency EU summit. As is often the case in Brussels, the results were mixed. New overall defence spending ofâ‚¬800bn (Â£670bn) was agreed. But whether it ever materialises will depend on national governmentsâ€™ willingness to borrow. The usual divisions were apparent; Hungary blocked a joint statement on Ukraine. Within Nato, most member states, like Britain, are now committing to higher spending. Non-EU countries, such asNorway, are piling in, too. Oslo is belatedly yet commendably doubling its aid to Kyiv.Europe is stepping up. In time, if it perseveres and its leaders keep their promises, it will be better able to deter Russia alone â€“ and survive in a reordered, more hostile world. But how effective Europe can be in rescuing Ukraine in the short term from a developing Trump-Putin axis is in serious doubt. Trump still refuses to provide Kyiv with meaningful postwar security guarantees. His suspension of military aid and mapping and intelligence assistance is encouraging Russia to intensify attacks. More civilians are dying each day because of Trumpâ€™s treachery. Each day, Ukraine is further brutalised and degraded. A just peace looks further away than ever.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toObservedFree weekly newsletterAnalysis and opinion on the week's news and culture brought to you by the best Observer writersEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. title: Being Putinâ€™s stooge wonâ€™t win Trump a peace prize. The Order of Lenin, though, is in the bag | Simon Tisdall | The Guardian
description: The strange warmth between the leaders has sent a chill globally at the prospect of a troika of authoritarian states
Author: Simon Tisdall
Headline: The strange warmth between the leaders has sent a chill globally at the prospect of a troika of authoritarian states
Content: Donald Trump pictured at his former home Greenwich Mansion in Connecticut in 1987, the year of his visit to Moscow.Photograph: Joe McNally/Getty ImagesView image in fullscreenDonald Trump pictured at his former home Greenwich Mansion in Connecticut in 1987, the year of his visit to Moscow.Photograph: Joe McNally/Getty ImagesThe ObserverDonald TrumpBeing Putinâ€™s stooge wonâ€™t win Trump a peace prize. The Order of Lenin, though, is in the bagSimon TisdallThe strange warmth between the leaders has sent a chill globally at the prospect of a troika of authoritarian statesSat 8 Mar 2025 09.30 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 09.53 ESTShareDonald Trumpâ€™s sinister affinity for Russiaâ€™s president, Vladimir Putin, has long been the subject of intense speculation. Former KGB officers claim Trump wasrecruited in Moscow in 1987 and cultivated as an assetin the years prior to his 2016 US election victory.Two retired Russian spies weighed in again last month, alleging that the then 40-year-old Trump,codename â€œKrasnovâ€, was personally compromised in an â€œactive measuresâ€ operation and has secretly danced to Putinâ€™s tune ever since.Nothing is proved and all is denied. Yet the so-calledSteele dossier, compiled by a British MI6 ex-spy chief, the FBIâ€™sMueller report, and US intelligence agencies all agree there were â€œmultiple, systematicâ€ Russian efforts to swing the 2016 vote to Trump. Candidate Trump praised Putin at the time as a â€œstrong leaderâ€ while claiming never to have met him.Previously, he said he had.Heâ€™s less coy now. Their phone call on 12 February lasted 90 minutes â€“ and changed the world.What did Putin say? It must have been persuasive. Since then, Trump has been falling over himself to please andappease the Kremlinâ€™s dictator. He has suspended US military aid and intelligence assistance to Ukraine, pilloried and plotted to oust its president, Volodymyr Zelenskyy, and demanded a â€œpeace dealâ€ on Russiaâ€™s unjust terms. Meanwhile, the wider ramifications of Trumpâ€™s sellout carry huge negative implications for Europe and western interests in China, the Middle East and Africa.If Trump is not Russiaâ€™s stooge, what explains his epic volte-face? Apologists offer several excuses. One is that Ukraine is not Americaâ€™s problem. Nonsense. Unprovoked armed aggression against a sovereign democratic state is every free nationâ€™s problem. Another is that the US should not have to fight Europeâ€™s wars. Answer: it doesnâ€™t. ItÂ fights its own wars on other peopleâ€™s territory, out of self-interest.It always has.Supporters say Trump is a master dealmaker and peacemaker. Phooey! He has already offered crucial Ukraine giveaways to Putin, for zero return. Remember his North Korea and Afghanistan fiascos? And look at Gaza. Howâ€™s that going, Comrade Krasnov? Fans claim heâ€™s performing a clever â€œreverse Nixonâ€ by disrupting Russia-China ties, like that other disgraceful US president in 1972. Except, only days ago, PutinÂ and President Xi Jinping reaffirmed the â€œunique strategic valueâ€ of their alliance.Lucrative joint economic projects provide another key to understanding Trumpâ€™s broader surrender strategy. Marco Rubio, US secretary of state turned cheap hustler, gushes embarrassingly about â€œextraordinary opportunitiesâ€. Putin is dangling deals onrare earth metals, energy and aluminium.Joint Arctic exploitation is mooted. Meanwhile, Trump helpfully imposes costly tariffs on Russiaâ€™s foes.Whatever Trumpâ€™s reasons, the shocking truth is that Putin owns him now, even if he didnâ€™t own him before. The US has switched sides. Trump boasts, self-incriminatingly, that he alone has inside information about Kremlin intentions. This dumb patsy likes the strongman vibe. Heâ€™d like to be a dictator, too. He admires how Putin terminates opponents â€œwith extreme prejudiceâ€, as inApocalypse Now. Except in this twisted White House remake,JD Vanceis mad, bad Colonel Kurtz.Trump betrayed his warm feelings for Putin during his Oval Office put-up row with Zelenskyy. Asked why Putin would keep his word in any peace deal when he never has before, Trump exploded: â€œThey respect me! Let me tell you. Putin went through a hell of a lot with me. He went through aphoney witch-huntâ€¦â€ Trump was referring to the past investigations into Russian collusion. Plainly, he sees Putin, an indicted war criminal and mass murderer, not merely as role model but as personal friend and fellow victim of political persecution.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toObservedFree weekly newsletterAnalysis and opinion on the week's news and culture brought to you by the best Observer writersEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionRussia is intensifying the war to exploit Trumpâ€™s surrender, gain ground and further squeeze Kyiv. Europe is Moscowâ€™s new bogeymanMuch flows from this, none of it good for Britain and Nato. Ukraineâ€™s capitulation is now a shared US-Russia war aim. Trump is trying to bully Zelenskyy and stampede Europe into a deal without credible security guarantees. He is planning to ease or lift sanctions, not strengthen them, as he occasionally suggests. He has already halted US cooperation with Europe on countering Russianâ€œshadow warâ€ cyber operations.Continued American backing for Nato is rightly questioned by German and French leaders. The alliance may not survive this crisis. Would-be bridge-builder Keir Starmer lacks a pontoon to stand on. Poland and the Baltic states understandably fear they may be next. The US nuclear umbrella is in doubt, too, which has led Emmanuel Macron to revive his idea of a pooledAnglo-French deterrent.Russia is intensifying the war to exploit Trumpâ€™s surrender, gain ground and further squeeze Kyiv. Europe is Moscowâ€™s new bogeyman. Putin now says the US is more like a partner, run by people with a â€œpragmatic, realistic worldviewâ€ who are discarding â€œstereotypes, so-called â€˜rulesâ€™ and the messianic, ideological cliches of their predecessorsâ€.There goes the laws-based international order, right there. Trump may not win a Nobel peace prize but he has certainly earned the Order of Lenin.If it lasts, and thatâ€™s a big â€œifâ€ given fickle Trumpâ€™s record, this US-Russia reset may remake the geopolitics of the Middle East, Asia and Africa. Iran stands to gain, unless, as Tehran fears, Putin sells it out to Israel. North Korea is a likely winner, too. Putin may win a freer hand in Syria, the Sahel and central Asia. Facing an emboldened Beijing, Trump may giveTaiwan the Kyiv bumâ€™s rush.The most threatening prospect, for western democracies, is the idea, discussed by Rubio, of an emerging troika ofauthoritarian superstatesâ€“ the US, Russia and China â€“ dominating and dictating a new world order.As Judas Trump blunders about, betraying friends, rewarding enemies and smashing the global crockery, one cold-eyed certainty remains: in their dysfunctional, deeply dubious relationship, Putin is the dominant partner. Trump is Putinâ€™s bitch.Simon Tisdall is the Observerâ€™s Foreign Affairs CommentatorDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article?
