title: â€˜We joke about whoâ€™s getting their knees doneâ€™: the rock veterans still touring into their late 70s | Music | The Guardian
description: Yoga and ice baths have replaced all-nighters, but musicians such as Graham Nash, Bonnie Raitt, Rick Wakeman and Elkie Brooks arenâ€™t planning to retire any time soon
Author: Dave Simpson
Headline: Yoga and ice baths have replaced all-nighters, but musicians such as Graham Nash, Bonnie Raitt, Rick Wakeman and Elkie Brooks arenâ€™t planning to retire any time soon
Content: Rock of agesâ€¦ how and why do mature musicians keep going so long?Photograph: Martina Lang/The GuardianView image in fullscreenRock of agesâ€¦ how and why do mature musicians keep going so long?Photograph: Martina Lang/The GuardianMusicâ€˜We joke about whoâ€™s getting their knees doneâ€™: the rock veterans still touring into their late 70sYoga and ice baths have replaced all-nighters, but musicians such as Graham Nash, Bonnie Raitt, Rick Wakeman and Elkie Brooks arenâ€™t planning to retire any time soonDave SimpsonSat 8 Mar 2025 06.55 ESTShareIalways said Iâ€™d retire when I got to 50,â€ chucklesRick Wakeman, who didnâ€™t do any suchÂ thing. Instead â€“ after realising that far fromÂ being left adrift by popâ€™s ever-changing styles, people were still interested in what he had to offer â€“ he recorded another 37 albums (taking his total to more than 100), penned two bestselling autobiographies and a film score andÂ carried on performing shows. ThenÂ last yearÂ he announced that heâ€™d stop touring whenÂ heÂ reaches 77, but heâ€™ll be 76 this May andÂ his packedÂ liveÂ schedule doesnâ€™t suggest a performer saying his last goodbyes.â€œThere was a time when I thought, maybe itâ€™s time to gracefully bow out,â€ the prog keyboard caped crusader explains, before his latest gig in Bradford. â€œBut unfortunately I canâ€™t. Music is the world to me. Itâ€™s just become blatantly obvious that Iâ€™m going to keep doing it until they put an epitaph on my gravestone reading: â€˜Itâ€™s not fair. Iâ€™m not finished yet.â€™â€Elkie Brooks knows exactly how he feels. TheÂ â€œQueen of British bluesâ€ (whose hits include Pearlâ€™s a Singer and Lilac Wine) has had 13 Top 75 albums in total andÂ isÂ on the road again at 80, having performed a â€œfarewell tourâ€ when she was 40. â€œThe promoter thought it might be a nice idea,â€ she chuckles. â€œIâ€™ve been saying â€˜farewellâ€™ ever since.â€View image in fullscreenThereâ€™s Only One â€¦ Graham Nash.Photograph: Ralf LouisThe pair are not alone in rocking way past pensionable age. When rockâ€™nâ€™roll was considered a young personâ€™s game, the young Mick Jagger once said: â€œIÂ donâ€™t wanna be singing Satisfaction when Iâ€™m 30,â€ but he still tours with the Rolling Stones at 81, while other venerable rockers treading the boards include Bob Dylan (83), Paul McCartney (82), Bruce Springsteen (75) and Mavis Staples (85). Folk legend Peggy Seeger is even touring this year aged 89. â€œItâ€™s like a drug,â€ Wakeman explains. â€œOnce itâ€™s inside you, you canâ€™t do without it.â€The top stars donâ€™t need the money but perform because it is rooted in their psyche and the demand is there. For Graham Nash, the Blackpool-born co-founder of the Hollies and supergroup Crosby, Stills and Nash, itâ€™s about â€œthe passion of music, and the energy I get from performing a new song to an audience. And when itâ€™s a song Iâ€™ve sung a million times, Iâ€™m going to sing it with the same passion I had when I wrote it.â€Seventy-five-year-old, California-born roots singerBonnie Raitthas spent 54 years on the road and says she canâ€™t think of anything more fun. â€œWhen I started out, my heroes were the jazz, blues and classical people who played well into their 70s and 80s. But touring is like a travelling summer camp. Then every night I get to have a party with the audience.â€Iâ€™m about to turn 83. I donâ€™t have a vocal coach, I do 22 songs a night, 25 shows a tour. Iâ€™m singing as well as everGraham NashStars get hooked young. Wakeman first performed in childhood and Salford-born Brooks got the bug through singing in her uncleâ€™s wedding band. Raitt watched audiences going â€œnutsâ€ when her father sang in musicals such as Oklahoma! â€œNone of us could believe this was his job,â€ she remembers. â€œSo once I took to it and got to open for James Taylor and Muddy Waters there was no turning back.â€Nash was a teenager when he entered a talent contest at Manchester Hippodrome with his pal Allan Clarke. â€œOn that show were myself and Allan, who later formed the Hollies, Freddie Garrity, who became Freddie and the Dreamers, Ron Wycherley, who became Billy Fury, and Johnny and the Moondogs, who became the Beatles.â€ John Lennon, Paul McCartney and George Harrison had dashed for the last bus back to Liverpool by the time Nash and Clarke were declared the winners, but Nash says â€œ2,000 people going crazy was the moment I knew I loved singing for peopleâ€.In the Hollies, he experienced the archetypal touring life: â€œFive of us in the back of a Transit, trying to get toÂ sleep on the amps and drum cases. One night the doors flew open and I fell out of the van.â€ Aged 20, Wakeman lived similarly during his time in the Strawbs.Â He chuckles. â€œYouÂ couldnâ€™t get my keyboard rig in a Transit now.â€View image in fullscreenâ€˜The trick is to pace yourselfâ€™ â€¦ Bonnie Raitt.Photograph: Scott Newton/Photo Courtesy of Austin PBS/Austin City Limits Photo by Scott NewtonJoining prog rock giants Yes in 1971 took his touring experiences to a very different level. â€œStaying on Sunset Strip with a whole bathroom and a shag pile carpet. IÂ thought: â€˜Bloody hell. I could move in here.â€™â€ But for older artists comfort is essential, rather than a luxury. â€œI wouldnâ€™t want to be running around in a van trying to break into the business, loading the equipment andÂ not getting decent hotels or food,â€ Raitt says. â€œThe trick is to pace yourself.â€ Sheâ€™s been touring for the last four years, and she does five months on the road out of every 12. â€œEnough to keep my band and crew working with me and to keep it fun.â€In her youth, Brooks hated touring. â€œJust me in my little Mini with a little suitcase, driving everywhere, finding my own bed and breakfasts. I wouldnâ€™t wish it on my worst enemy.â€ Now she tours the country with long gaps between gigs, pointing out that her vocal warmup, soundcheck and show still add up to more than three hours of exertion. â€œYou wouldnâ€™t ask Mo Farah to run the marathon again the next day, would you?â€ On show days, she avoids speaking to restÂ her voice. Raitt concurs: â€œOne of the great gifts hasÂ been texting and email to save your voice during the day.â€I never want to hear people walk out of a concert and go: He used to be really good.Rick WakemanIt also helps to stay fit. Brooks became a black belt in aikido when she was 50. Raitt does yoga and weights, hikes and takes a bike on tour. Wakeman merely walks his dogs. â€œWe recently sold a house and in one of the outbuildings I came across this strange equipment,â€ he chuckles. â€œMy wife said: â€˜Thatâ€™s the gym you built four years ago.â€™â€As a member of Yes, he enjoyed excesses such as mocking a studio upÂ like a farmyard, after which his keyboard had to goÂ forÂ repair because it was full of woodlice. â€œWeâ€™dÂ comeÂ up with mad suggestions,â€ he chuckles. â€œâ€˜Why donâ€™t we travel by camel?!â€™ It was ridiculous, butÂ it was the 70s.â€ His own excess stopped at drugs â€“ â€œIâ€™ve never popped a pill or smoked a jointâ€ â€“ but, heÂ says, tooÂ much booze and cigarettes gave him aÂ series of heart attacks by the age of 25, so he quit both.Â â€œIÂ tryÂ notÂ to think about all that,â€ he admits, moreÂ seriously, â€œbecause you ask yourself: â€˜Should I still be here?â€™â€â€œHonestly, to go on at the Newcastle Fiesta in 1964 or 65 you needed half a bottle of brandy,â€ argues Brooks, who admits that in Vinegar Joe, the band she formed with Robert Palmer in the 1970s, taking cocaine was like having a cup of coffee. â€œThe thing was, weâ€™d go on in Sheffield at 10pm, then weâ€™d be doing a gig in the London Roundhouse at 3am. Two shows a night. I often wondered why the record company were taking cocaine but we were taking it just to stay bloody awake.â€ SheÂ stopped after meeting Trevor, her sound engineer husband of 47 years, who didnâ€™t touch the stuff. â€œIÂ wanted him to like me,â€ she says. She last drank alcohol before a show in 1979, when â€œa stomach upset meant I couldnâ€™t keep anything downâ€.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. Sign up to get the inside story from our top writers as well as all the must-read articles and columns, delivered to your inbox every weekend.Enter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionView image in fullscreenElkie Brooks â€¦ â€˜Text and email mean I can save my voice during the dayâ€™Photograph: Kev Nicholsonâ€œBy your 30s, staying up drinking and doing drugs and not sleeping arenâ€™t wearing so well,â€ considers Raitt, who had also got â€œsucked inâ€ to the rockâ€™nâ€™roll lifestyle. â€œThe next thing you know your liver is shot or youâ€™re not recovering from colds or you lose your voice, say stuff you donâ€™t mean or youâ€™re sloppy on stage.â€ After a 1987 skiing accident, she had to take two months off after surgery so took the opportunity to get sober, go on a diet and lose weight, in preparation for a video shoot with Prince. â€œThe biggest change was not partying all night after the show but it proved serendipitous: I got famous at the same time I got sober.Â Then I saw other people whoâ€™d got sober and they were singing and playing better than ever, so my last excuse was gone.â€In Nashâ€™s autobiography Wild Tales, he describes mind-boggling 70s tours involving helicopters, limousines, coke dealers and five-hour shows that wentÂ on past midnight, but life is different now. â€œIÂ wasÂ never really an addict,â€ he insists, â€œbut I stopped taking cocaine 40 years ago after I went to an aftershowÂ party and saw everybody smiling, but the smiles never reached their eyes. I realised they must be looking at me and seeing the same thing.â€ He still uses marijuana before shows, but says, â€œIâ€™m about to turn 83. I donâ€™t have a vocal coach, I do 22 songs a night, 25 shows a tour. Songs such as Military Madness or Immigration Man are still relevant and Iâ€™m singing as well as ever.â€Some older stars carry scars from a lifetime on the road.Â Along with those heart attacks, Wakeman has had â€œdouble pleurisy,Â double pneumonia, arthritis, diabetesâ€ and has to plunge his throbbing arthritic hands into an iceÂ bath after every show. â€œI had some health problemsÂ in America this year and if it wasnâ€™t for the show Iâ€™d have been in bed or calling the medics,â€ heÂ reveals. â€œBut when you go on stage, something takesÂ over â€“ adrenaline or whatever â€“ and you feel great, until youâ€™re back in the dressing room and you feelÂ dreadful.â€View image in fullscreenRick Wakeman â€¦ not planning to put his musical career on ice any time soon.Photograph: Lee Wilkinson MultimediaRaitt has had to postpone shows in recent years because of laryngitis or â€œwear and tearâ€ and says her older musician pals joke about â€œwhoâ€™s getting their knees done or whoâ€™s got tendonitis and so on. But in every city there are parks I love to go to, friends I love to see. And there are people who saw me in the 1970s who still come and see me now.â€Younger fans discover veteran artists through parents, radio, magazines or streaming. It amazes Nash that he can pack a hall at his age and Wakeman appreciates every second in ways he could never have done when he was younger. What would make him stop performing? â€œIf I couldnâ€™t play like I want to. I never want to hear people walk out of a concert and go: â€˜HeÂ used to be really good.â€™â€Raitt wants to prove that sheâ€™s as â€œbadassâ€ as ever, but insists: â€œIâ€™m not slowing down and Iâ€™m not going toÂ stop until I canâ€™t do it any more.â€ Brooks jokes thatÂ when she can no longer hit the high notes, â€œtheyâ€™llÂ find a place for me in Tesco on the tillsâ€. NashÂ saw Spanish guitar giant AndrÃ©s Segovia play when he was 92. â€œAnd he knocked me on my ass withÂ the energyÂ andÂ brilliance of his performance. SoÂ IÂ think: â€˜Why not me?â€™â€Perhaps thereâ€™s a life lesson here for all of us. AsÂ RaittÂ puts it: â€œIf you find something you love doing, keep doing it.â€Elkie Brooksplaysthe Lowry, Salford, 16Â March, and is touring until 2026;Bonnie Raitttours the UK from 1Â toÂ 17Â June, starting atthe Usher Hall, Belfast;Graham Nashis touring from 4 to 19 October, starting at theGlasshouse, Gateshead;RickÂ Wakemanand the English Rock Ensemble tour the UK from12 to 29October.Explore more on these topicsMusicPop and rockRick WakemanBonnie RaittfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Jack White review â€“ rockâ€™nâ€™roll showman makes believers of us all  | Jack White | The Guardian
description: Touring his 2024 solo album No Name in a barnstorming gig, the former White Stripe plays fast and loose with the truth but is absolutely the real deal
Author: Kitty Empire
Headline: Touring his 2024 solo album No Name in a barnstorming gig, the former White Stripe plays fast and loose with the truth but is absolutely the real deal
Content: â€˜Guitar shock and aweâ€™: Jack White at Troxy.Photograph: David James SwansonView image in fullscreenâ€˜Guitar shock and aweâ€™: Jack White at Troxy.Photograph: David James SwansonKitty Empire's artist of the weekJack WhiteReviewJack White review â€“ rockâ€™nâ€™roll showman makes believers of us allTroxy, LondonTouring his 2024 solo album No Name in a barnstorming gig, the former White Stripe plays fast and loose with the truth but is absolutely the real dealKitty EmpireSat 8 Mar 2025 09.00 ESTShareâ€œDo you believe me yet?â€ yellsJack Whitefrom the lip of the stage, a few songs into his second nightâ€™s work at this classy art deco venue in east London. Itâ€™s a very Jack White kind of location: highly stylised, lovingly restored, but not entirely removed from its unglamorous surroundings.Lit in deep blue and strobing white, the colour palette of his solo career, White and his band have played tracks from his most recent album, the surprise-releasedNo Name, firsthanded out freeon white-label vinyl to unsuspecting shoppers at Third Man stores in Nashville, Detroit and London last summer (Third Man Records is Whiteâ€™s own imprint).Itâ€™s Rough on Rats (If Youâ€™re Asking)is a particularly rousing workout full of guitar shock and awe, from an album that has drawn relieved and delighted comparisons to Whiteâ€™s first band,the White Stripes.Heâ€™s also stormed throughBlack Math, from the White Stripesâ€™ fourth album, 2003â€™sElephant, a disc recorded entirely on analogue gear at Toe Rag Studios in Homerton, Hackney, just a few miles down the road. Roaming across his discography, White and his band have just absolutely pulverisedBroken Boy Soldierâ€“ a 2006 cut fromthe Raconteurs, another White side outfit. Itâ€™s virtually unrecognisable in this early 70s acid-blues-rock version. Mini whirlpools of flailing bodies ebb and flow through it all.View image in fullscreenâ€˜Johnny Guitar, from Hackney.â€™Photograph: David James SwansonWhite began this gig with an affirmation â€“ that â€œeverything that comes out of my mouth tonight will be the truth!â€ A little while later, though, he introduces himself as â€œJohnny Guitar, from Hackneyâ€. You canâ€™t help but grin. Itâ€™s 2025, the postwar world order is in grave flux, but we are on surprisingly steady ground here tonight. Kaleidoscopic garage-punk blues fills the air, and a mischievous artist who always delivers is playing fast and loose in more ways than one.Since White first started damaging speaker cones as half of the White Stripes in the early 00s, this Detroit-born Nashville transplant has enjoyed a relationship with fact perhaps best described as capricious. White Stripes drummer Meg White being his â€œsisterâ€ was a key foundational sleight of hand.But White doesnâ€™t actually want audiences to believe every tall tale he tells. A keen student of legends past, he has long been drawn to obfuscation and myth-making â€“ creative strategies that go back to Bob Dylan and beyond, to blues people and showfolk of all kinds.Rather, White wants us to believeinhim â€“ in the intensity with which he curates his 360-degree aesthetic, and in the righteousness of the sound-world he has manifested from source materials brimming with raw, pre-modern resonance.Most of all, he wants us to be won over by the fervour with which all this is delivered. He stalks around in bone-white shoes, shaking his replenished mop of curly black hair (it was short and blue for a while). He faces off against the keys player, wears grooves in the stage. The band make everything heavy and roiling, then they pull out a blithe, garage-pop song such as the White Stripesâ€™Youâ€™re Pretty Good Looking (For a Girl).The viral terrace-chant riff to Seven Nation Army causes the usually immune security guards to whip their heads aroundThereâ€™s never been a bad set of musicians backing this showboating guitarist, but tonightâ€™s trio â€“ go-to drummer Patrick Keeler (the Raconteurs), bassist Dominic Davis (from the Buzzards, a previous White backing band) and Bobby Emmett, a relative new boy vamping on keys, who wears his shades all night â€“ are a particularly taut lineup. White joins Emmett at his organ station for a keyboard-heavy, rococo romp through the White Stripesâ€™Apple Blossom. Elsewhere, there are long, jam-like codas, near-constant segues; at one point, Iggy and the Stoogesâ€™ I Wanna Be Your Dog emerges out of the squall.The encore is nearly as long as the first set. At the end, the viral terrace-chant riff to Seven Nation Army causes the security guards â€“ normally immune to whatever music is going on behind them â€“ to whip their heads around. Somewhere in the middle isArchbishop Harold Holmes, an instant classic White tune from the new album, where truth, falsehood, patter and faith are remixed to a Led Zeppelin-like swinging chug.In the lyrics, White plays the itinerant preacher, coming to your town. It is, in part, a riff of hucksters ancient and modern, promising a cure for all ills. â€œAnd if you are suffering a strange sickness,â€ White hisses, â€œOr someone is blocking up all of your success, you need to see me right away so I can fix this.â€The many parallels between religious and musical spectacle are well studied but tonight, White makes a very convincing salesman of rockâ€™nâ€™rollâ€™s fundamentals. Under all the bluster, his belief in the power of pacy, sly electric blues to cure a lot of ills remains very persuasive. He really is the kind of showman who can make you feel better for a while.Watch the video for Thatâ€™s How Iâ€™m Feeling by Jack White.Explore more on these topicsJack WhiteKitty Empire's artist of the weekThe White StripesThe RaconteursPop and rockreviewsShareReuse this content

Author: Simon Hattenstone
Headline: Sheâ€™s the chatty daytime presenter with a nice line in withering putdowns. But as a judge once ruled, thatâ€™s just a role she performs. So who is the real Lorraine Kelly?
Content: Kelly photographed at home earlier this month with her dog Angus. Photograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianSheâ€™s the chatty daytime presenter with a nice line in withering putdowns. But as a judge once ruled, thatâ€™s just a role she performs. So who is the real Lorraine Kelly?BySimon HattenstoneSat 8 Mar 2025 02.00 ESTShareLorraine Kelly opens the front door with a huge smile. â€œYou interviewed me, years ago, dâ€™you remember?â€ Now she looks disappointed. â€œAch, you donâ€™t, do you?â€ Of course I remember. And sheâ€™s hardly changed. Iâ€™ve brought a photo of us on the GMTV sofa to show her. Back then, sheâ€™d just turned 40, was a staple of breakfast telly and was about to launch her own show; a household name, if not quite the mononym she is today. Now sheâ€™s 65, her show is still on ITV five mornings a week, and last year she was awarded a lifetime achievement Bafta. Oh, and sheâ€™s just reinvented herself as a bestselling novelist. TheÂ Island Swimmer, which reached No 2 in the Sunday Times hardback fiction charts, is about to come out in paperback.â€œSo howâ€™ve you been?â€ she asks. Kelly is the kind of person who you can pick up with where you left off a quarter of a century ago. Sheâ€™s also the kind of person you feel you know, even when you donâ€™t. Perhaps thatâ€™s been her great gift as a TV presenter. She was a good journalist as Scotland correspondent for TV-am but not outstanding. Sheâ€™s a decent interviewer, but she wonâ€™t be remembered for her incisive interrogations or scoops. What she is brilliant at, though, is being Lorraine â€“ warm, likable, nosy, funny, occasionally steely and sharp-tongued, sometimes potty-mouthed and always 100% herself. Which is why it was a shock in 2019 when she told a tax court that theLorraine on TV is different from the real Lorraine; that on television she performs the role â€œof a friendly, chatty and fun personalityâ€.Her Buckinghamshire cottage, backing on to the Thames, is as you might expect â€“ plush but super homely. Inside, there are big comfy sofas and piles of illustrated cushions (one is of a saintly looking Dolly Parton, another of Angus the dog is captioned: â€œThis house is solely for the convenience of our border terrierâ€). Paintings of Angus, daughter Rosie and her husband of 33 years, Steve, adorn the walls. You canâ€™t move for family photos â€“ her grandparents dressed to the nines; her newlywed parents gorgeous at 18; Rosie with her baby daughter Billie. She dotes over the last photo. â€œSee, I am a real Granny Smith!â€ she says. I look at her, puzzled. â€œThatâ€™s my married name! Steve is Steve Smith.â€ Iâ€™m already beginning to see the difference between Lorraine Kelly the TV show presenter and Lorraine Smith, wife, mum and grandma.Daytime TV regulars will know just how obsessed she is with being a grandmother. She canâ€™t stop talking about it. Wow, I didnâ€™t know you were a gran, I say. NowÂ itâ€™s her turn to give me a look. â€œYou cheeky bugger. Well itisthe best thing thatâ€™s happened to me.â€View image in fullscreenKelly with her daughter Rosie, 2021.Photograph: Karwai Tang/WireImageThe Island Swimmer is pure fiction â€“ a romantic mystery about a woman returning to her home in Orkney after leaving unexpectedly many years ago. And yet look at the photos, explore her home, and you can see bits of Kellyâ€™s life in the book. The photo of her parents reminds me of the parents of the bookâ€™s protagonist Evie and her older sister Liv, with whom she has a troubled relationship. Kelly stops at another photograph â€“ this time herself as a six-year-old with her baby brother Graham. â€œThatâ€™s me looking dead happy that my wee brotherâ€™s here! I look like a demon.â€ Blimey, I say, you look just how I imagine the young Liv would in her furious jealousy. She bursts out laughing.â€œYessssssss!Hahahaha! Itâ€™s me as a child, oh my God!â€ It is exactly how she felt â€“ he was the golden child, and she had been usurped. She admits it inspired the relationship between Evie and Liv. â€œMy nose was put out of joint when he was born. But now I really like him. He just makes me laugh so much.â€ What did he think when he read the book? â€œHe thought it was hilarious. Itâ€™s not his thing, but he enjoyed it.â€™â€™ In the book, Liv is accused of attempting to drown Evie. Did she ever try to drown Graham? â€œOh no! It wasnâ€™tthatbad.â€Above the spices shelf in the kitchen, bottles of whisky are lined up like a military platoon. Which is her favourite? â€œI like Highland Park.â€ Highland Park gets an honourable mention in the book. â€œBut Steve and I are not guzzlers of whisky,â€ she says. Whatâ€™s their favourite tipple? â€œG&T,â€ she says. Funny how G&T is the drink of choice for a number of your characters, I say. â€œWell you have to write about what you know!â€She and Steve used to work together as part of a small team when they were young â€“ him as the cameraman, she as the journalist. â€œI knew right away as soon as he walked in the door. This wee fella from Dundee, IÂ thought, yep thatâ€™s him, thanks very much! Then it took me a year, but I got him in the end.â€ Why did it take her so long? â€œIt was a small working environment, there were only five of us. It was awkward.â€ What was special about him? â€œHeâ€™s the kindest man. Heâ€™s funny, he makes me laugh a lot, he puts up with me, heâ€™s very stable.â€On with the guided tour. Thereâ€™s a whole shelf of books dedicated to the explorerErnest Shackleton. â€œIâ€™mobsessedwith him. Always have been.â€ Kelly doesnâ€™t like standing still. She moves as quickly as she talks. We stop at the magnets on her fridge â€“ souvenirs from places sheâ€™s been to. One of her favourites is Twatt in Orkney. â€œI love that thereâ€™s a place called Twatt, as if you couldnâ€™t love Orkney enough.â€ She moves on to a photo of Steve with Billie. â€œThatâ€™s my husband with baby Billie, when she was just born. But I donâ€™t like to talk about Billie, as you know. Even though she is the best thingever.â€Is it better than being a mum? â€œWhen youâ€™re a mum you donâ€™t know what youâ€™re doing. Now you have all the love and you donâ€™t have any fear.â€Angus is barking at the door. â€œCome and say hello to Simon!â€ Angus trots in, yappy and affectionate. AÂ second later Steve arrives back from a game ofpadel. Heâ€™s a stocky, handsome man in shorts and a Dundee United top. I ask him if heâ€™s still working. â€œNo!â€ When did he retire? â€œOh God, years ago, 10 years ago or something.â€Is it true that he watches all Kellyâ€™s shows?â€œYes, I Â do.â€ Is he a tough critic? â€œNooooo.â€â€œNoooo!â€Kelly echoes.â€œBut itâ€™s lovely that he watches.â€Would he ever say, that was a bit shite? â€œNo, I donâ€™t criticise. Iâ€™ll just say, well, that was a weird guest! We watch together, donâ€™t we, Angus?â€Kelly: â€œYou do, youâ€™re very good. As does my mother.â€Could he imagine Kelly retiring? â€œNo. She never will. Sheâ€™s a grafter. Sheâ€™ll always do something.â€â€œI do love the writing, though,â€ Kelly says. â€œItâ€™s great if you can just get in the zone. Iâ€™ve been very lucky to get a chance to do it.â€ Sheâ€™s aware that she might have remained unpublished if she hadnâ€™t been well known.Kellyâ€™s publicist had suggested we talk over lunch. I find interviewing while eating quite tricky â€“ too convivial to ask difficult questions. Thankfully lunch consists of three Caramel bars and a Penguin. We head off into the lounge as Kelly tells me despite her 40 years in the business, sheâ€™s never counted her chickens.View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianShe was born in the Gorbals, spent her early years in Glasgow and then moved to East Kilbride 20-odd miles away. Her father was a TV engineer and her mother a shop assistant; they were the talk of the tenement when they were the first family to get a colour television in the late 60s. â€œEverybody came to our living room to watch this Frank Sinatra concert.â€ She says her mum and dad seemed cooler than most of her friendsâ€™ parents, partly because they were younger and partly because they were into Dylan rather thanMantovani.She was a bright child â€“ though not as bright as Graham. She would have been the first in the family to go to university, had she not got a job on the East Kilbride News at the age of 17. From the off, she loved it, and was treated as one of the lads in a predominantly male environment. In 1983, she joined BBC Scotland as a researcher, and a year later became TV-amâ€™s Scotland correspondent. It was after covering the Lockerbie disaster for TV-am that she moved to London to present Good Morning Britain in 1989.Kelly says she has never lost the insecurity of a freelancer. She learned her lesson when she was sacked from GMTV while on maternity leave and replaced by Anthea Turner. Ever since, sheâ€™s always made sure sheâ€™s had something else on the go to fall back on, whether a radio show, newspaper columns or now, her novels.â€œRosie was teeny-tiny. Weâ€™d just moved south, we had a mortgage, and it was scary to have that peeled away from you. I wasnâ€™t a member of staff. I didnâ€™t haveÂ any rights. I didnâ€™t get maternity pay. Iâ€™d like toÂ think weâ€™re a bit more enlightened these days, and that wouldnâ€™t happen.â€Cow & Gate proved to be her unlikely saviour. The processed baby milk manufacturer agreed to sponsor aÂ slot on GMTV so long as Kelly presented it. From there, she went on to host her own show, Lorraine Live, and since then hasnâ€™t looked back.Oh dear God! I canâ€™t believe whatâ€™s going on in America. Itâ€™s heartbreaking. Itâ€™s being torn apartIn 2010, she launched her current show, simply called Lorraine. Itâ€™s changed little in format over 15 years, though they recently decided to accentuate the positive because the world is so bleak. â€œWe made a conscious decision that weâ€™ll try to see the light.â€ She means light as opposed to dark, rather than trivial. As an example, she cites a recent guest, Auschwitz survivor Renee Salt. â€œAt end of the interview she said: â€˜I just want peace. If Iâ€™ve got anything to say to the world itâ€™s for goodness sake please donâ€™t let this happen again.â€™ It was extraordinary. For someone to still have faith in humanÂ kindness and peace, wow! That teaches you a lesson,Â doesnâ€™t it?â€Does she worry we could see a return to fascism, with the rise of right-wing populism? â€œOh dear God! I canâ€™t believe whatâ€™s going on in America. Itâ€™s heartbreaking. Itâ€™s being torn apart. I donâ€™t see how we can go from Obama who, for all his faults, was a good man. How did we go from this articulate, compassionate, interesting person to what weâ€™ve got now? I do spend a lot of my time being baffled. I do.â€Trump has just announced his plan to turn Gaza into the Rivieraof the Middle East when we meet. â€œI mean â€¦â€ For a moment even Kelly is lost for words. â€œIt is easy to be depressed about everything. Thatâ€™s why I think we have to get the joy where we can. I did think it was going to be OK in this country when Keir Starmer got in because I thought, OK heâ€™s a bit dull, but we need grownups. And thenthe first thing he did was take away the heating allowance from pensioners. What are youdoing? Why would youdothat?â€View image in fullscreenWith husband Steve Smith after being made a CBE.Photograph: WPA/Getty ImagesThis is Kelly at her best â€“ demolishing arguments or policies not with logic or facts, but with blunt rhetorical questions that reflect what so many of us think. â€œThen he said things are really shit and theyâ€™re going to get even shitter. We donâ€™t want to hear that.â€ Now sheâ€™s on a roll. â€œWe really donâ€™t. There are ways of communicating that: â€˜Things are bad, we know, but donâ€™t worry because weâ€™re all trying our very best to make it better.â€™ You donâ€™t have to overpromise and underdeliver, but youÂ could just go, â€˜Weâ€™re going to do our best to make it better, stick with us!â€™ We donâ€™t want to hear all that negativity right now. We just donâ€™t. It might be me putting my head in the sand, but I donâ€™t think it is. We just need a bit of hope.â€And sheâ€™s still not done. â€œI donâ€™t recognise this government as a Labour government. And he keeps mythologising Margaret Thatcher which is â€¦ scary.â€Kelly has always said it the way she sees it â€“ though perhaps not as uncompromisingly as this. I ask whether she was political as a kid. â€œOh yes, I was in theAnti-Nazi Leagueand hadCNDbadges. When youâ€™re young you should absolutely be saying, this isnâ€™t good, this isnâ€™t right.â€ Not just when youâ€™re young, I say. She nods. â€œYou should be shouting from the rooftops.â€ She looks at my plate of Caramels. â€œGo on, have a biscuit.â€skip past newsletter promotionSign up toInside SaturdayFree weekly newsletterThe only way to get a look behind the scenes of the Saturday magazine. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionJesus Christ, David Attenborough gets people being shitty to him! I mean David Attenborough, who is holding the universe together!Why does she think the world has become so toxic? She stares at her mobile phone, and pokes it with her finger. â€œThat!All the villages had idiots and extremists, but they were sitting there on their own. Now theyâ€™ve found their kindred spirits on thisbloodything.â€ Sheâ€™s talking even faster and her voice is getting louder. â€œJesus Christ,David Attenboroughgets people being shitty to him! I meanDavid Attenborough, who is holding the universe together! People shout at him â€“ climate change deniers, hunters have a go at him. And you think, well if theyâ€™re having a go at him, whatâ€™s the point?â€People sometimes think of you as soft and mumsy, I say. â€œThe mad fools! Hehehehe!â€ But youâ€™re pretty tough? â€œI can be. Especially if Iâ€™m defending somebody or something that I believe in.â€ Such as? â€œWhen people are unkind. When I was at school there was this lovely person who was our bus driver, bravest person Iâ€™ve met in my life. Her name was Jane. She used to be a chap and was now a trans woman. Jane got people speaking shit to her, saying offensive things. I remember saying to somebody, â€˜Shut your face, donâ€™t be so bloody rude.â€™â€But, even then, she says people were more open-minded than they appear to be now. â€œWe were much more tolerant. Again, itâ€™s social media giving nutters a voice. It makes no sense to me. I know a fair few people who are trans and they just want to get on with their lives. I donâ€™t think trans people should have to come on the television, or be part of the debate, to justify their existence. I just think everyone has to be a bit more tolerant. Thatâ€™s why I put a trans person in my book.â€The elderly Freya is the wise, generous heart of The Island Swimmer. â€œFreya being trans is probably the least interesting thing about her. I was keen to show sheâ€™s just Freya. I love her. Sheâ€™s just a lovely, lovely person.â€ Itâ€™s touching how she talks about her characters as if they are friends â€“ or enemies. Just as she swoons over Freya, she rages over Evieâ€™s boyfriend, the controlling Jeremy. â€œHeâ€™s like all the horrible people Iâ€™ve met in my life distilled into one.â€ Why did she call him Jeremy? â€œItâ€™s the kind of name, with apologies to all the Jeremies in the world, you think: oh, heâ€™s going to be a knob.â€She looks down at Angus, adoringly. â€œLike Angus is a great name; a strong name. Apologies to everyone who canâ€™t help that their mammy called them Jeremy.â€ Kelly has just finished writing her second novel, and is currently editing it. She tells me proudly that sheâ€™s now signed a deal for a third and fourth.View image in fullscreenPhotograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianEarlier this year, she hit out at â€œtoxic people in tellyâ€ â€“ particularly men. In an interview with the Mirror, she said: â€œThe behaviour of Gregg Wallace and other people that weâ€™ve seen, should it come about as all true, is appalling.â€ She talked about the abuse of power and said that TV bosses who enabled this behaviour were as much to blame as the perpetrators. Last year, she said some male presenters lacked â€œgenerosityâ€. Interestingly, she singled out former fellow morning TV star Phillip Schofield as one who was generous.Schofield resigned from ITV in 2023and was dropped by his talent agency after admitting to an â€œunwise, but not illegalâ€ affair with a younger colleague. Today, she says: â€œI think Phillip was awful daft. I think he made a lot of choices he shouldnâ€™t have. But all I can go by isÂ what it was like to work with him, and it was easy. He was lovely, and I think itâ€™s really sad.â€As I get older, I want to do other things. Iâ€™ve been doing this for 40 years, working my arse offKelly has recently been under attack herself. She has been criticised on social media for not presenting her show five days a week.An X account called LorraineKWatchkeeps track of her absences. At the end of last year, the account, which has 25,000 followers, concluded that she had only hosted 59.7% of the episodes. This year she has presented 67.5% at the time of writing. I thought she might laugh it off, but she doesnâ€™t. â€œItâ€™s really hurtful actually. It really is. Iâ€™ve not spoken about it before. Iâ€™m a grafter and I work really hard and Iâ€™ve had to take Fridays off for the past year. I just thought it was weird to care so much.â€ Why was she taking time off? â€œInitially, it was for my mum who has been ill. And it sort of brings you into line with everyone else because if you look at This Morning, everybody else does four days. And as Iâ€™m getting older, I want to do other things, more writing, all of that. Mate, Iâ€™ve been doing this for 40 years, working my arse off.â€I guess the difference is that your show is called Lorraine, I say. â€œI get that. I get that 100% because This Morning is just called This Morning and GMB is just GMB.â€ But she says it does feel horribly personal. â€œMaybe it just started off as a wee joke, but itâ€™s the way that everyone piles on. It starts off as a wee tiny thing and it gets bigger and bigger. I find it really sad.â€We talk about the highs. There have been so many, she says. And this is when you really see that Kelly is one of lifeâ€™s great enthusiasts â€“ a professional fangirl. She talks about meeting Star Trek heroes Leonard Nimoy (â€œMr Spock was my first crush!â€) and William Shatner; interviewing real-life space hero Buzz Aldrin; being sent to San Francisco for a zero-gravity flight for her 60th birthday; travelling to America on the QE2 with the Cure (â€œThey were delightful â€“ so polite and cuteâ€).She has been groundbreaking in normalising conversation about once-taboo topics such as miscarriage and menopause. In 2017, Kelly revealed that menopause had left her feeling â€œflat and joylessâ€. She only shared her experience because at the time she couldnâ€™t find a famous guest willing to talk about it.Perhaps the thing we remember most from her show are the spontaneous Lorraine moments, often when doing live links with the GMB show â€“ she toldEsther McVey she didnâ€™t remember her, after the Conservative MPsaid they used to work together;tore a strip off Jennifer Arcuri, the businesswoman who had an affair with Boris Johnson, for saying nothing in her interview (â€œWhatâ€™s the point in you coming on and not saying anything?â€). In 2023, she voiced surprise at Nigel Farageâ€™s relative youth (â€œIs he only 59? I thought he was a helluva lot older than that. Thatâ€™s astonishing. It just shows you get the face you deserve!â€)I ask about the lows. She struggles to think of any.Â TheÂ few there have been tend to be personal. â€œIÂ hadÂ a miscarriage, which was horrible, and I went back toÂ workÂ too fast. Thatâ€™s the thing I do. I plough on.Â ButÂ lows, not really.â€ She says she would love to have hadÂ moreÂ children.View image in fullscreenHair and makeup by Alice Theobald at Arlington Artists using makeup by Mario and hair by Sam McKnight.Photograph: Harry Borden/The GuardianIn 2019, she took HMRC to court after receiving a Â£1.2m tax bill. The battle was about whether she was an employee or a freelancer, and whether she appeared as a performer or herself. Kelly won the case, but for the first time she got a drubbing in the press. Judge Jennifer Dean ruled Lorraine â€œpresents a persona of herselfâ€ so could be described as a â€œtheatrical artistâ€, meaning payments to an agent were allowed as a tax-deductible expense. Judge Dean said: â€œFor the time Ms Kelly is contracted to perform live on air she is public â€˜Lorraine Kellyâ€™; she may not like the guest sheÂ interviews, she may not like the food she eats, she may not like the film she viewed but that is where the performance lies.â€ It made Kelly sound like a fake, and her USP had always been authenticity.Was that a low? â€œYes,â€ she winces. â€œThat was horrible. But we had no choice. We took them to a tribunal because what they were trying to do was unfair. They were trying to say that I was a member of staff when Iâ€™mÂ a freelance, so they sent me a massive tax bill.â€She says it felt like a David and Goliath battle against HMRC. â€œThe thing that has negated some of the stress and angst and bad publicity is that it has helped so many people â€“ not just people in the media or famous people, but, say, hairdressers and beauticians who had been treated as staff by HMRC but were actually freelancers.â€ How did it affect her? â€œYour peace of mind goes.â€To have argued that Lorraine is a character â€¦ I begin to say. She answers before I finish as she tends to do when sheâ€™s on the defensive. â€œYes, that was weird. But that was the only way we could do it.â€ A lot of people took the piss out of you, I say. â€œOh, they did but thatâ€™s OK.â€ Does she genuinely think that Lorraine is a character? Yes and no, she says. â€œI am a version of me on the telly. And yes, Iâ€™m kind of like that but Iâ€™m a lot more open, a lot more sweary, and Iâ€™m not that person. Thereâ€™s nobody that goes on television who is themselves.â€ She says sheâ€™s quieter in real life; less sociable. â€œI am not the life and soul of the party. My husband is. Iâ€™m the first one there and the first to leave. Iâ€™m at my happiest with people I trust and know, watching something on the telly and having a nice meal.â€What really hurt about the court case, she says, was people thinking sheâ€™s a tax dodger. â€œIâ€™ll show you my tax returns. I pay my taxes on time every year, of course I do.â€ She looks at my plate. â€œHave another biscuit.â€I ask Kelly if Steve was right when he said sheâ€™d never give up work. â€œI would do the telly as long as people want me to do it.â€ Is she enjoying getting older? â€œYes!â€ Is her brown hair natural? â€œLook, Iâ€™ve got grey.â€ Hardly any. â€œI know, but my mum and granny were the same, then it just went white. Like Helen Mirren. Sheâ€™s beautiful, but she still looks like a normal human being. Sheâ€™s not got the boiled-egg face. I donâ€™t like that. Iâ€™ve not had anything done. Iâ€™m too scared, and I donâ€™t want to. I want to look normal, I want to look like me.â€ Is there any pressure to have work done? â€œNot in the job I do, no. I was never hired for my looks!â€ She hoots with delight.Well you say that, but you have been hailed as a sex symbol. â€œHahhaha! By whom? Blind people?â€ Actually, it was the Daily Mail, among others. â€œWell itâ€™s very kind, Iâ€™ll take that all day long.â€ Sheâ€™s also been called a gay icon. â€œIâ€™ll take that all day long, too.â€ And sheâ€™s been labelled the nationâ€™s naughty mum. â€œI didnâ€™t know that. Iâ€™ll take that too.â€ What title is she going for next? She thinks. â€œNovelist of the year? No! I couldnâ€™t possibly!â€Sheâ€™s just delighted to still be working, still be relevant, and still be finding new things to do. â€œI love this stage of my life. Especially with the wee one.â€ She grins. â€œBut I donâ€™t mention her. I like to keep that quiet!â€The Island Swimmer by Lorraine Kelly is published by Orion in paperback on 13 March. Author: Killian Fox
Headline: The artist on a moving biography of George Orwellâ€™s wife, a theatre company that should be available on the NHS, and the joy of a good crime drama
Content: Artist Bobby Baker at Tate Britain with her 2023 recreation of An Edible Family in a Mobile Home.Photograph: David Levene/The GuardianView image in fullscreenArtist Bobby Baker at Tate Britain with her 2023 recreation of An Edible Family in a Mobile Home.Photograph: David Levene/The GuardianOn my radarCultureOn my radar: Bobby Bakerâ€™s cultural highlightsThe artist on a moving biography of George Orwellâ€™s wife, a theatre company that should be available on the NHS, and the joy of a good crime dramaKillian FoxSat 8 Mar 2025 10.52 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 10.55 ESTShareThe artist Bobby Baker was born in Kent in 1950 and studied painting at St Martins School of Art. In her work, which combines performance with drawing and installation, she highlights the undervalued aspects of womenâ€™s lives, often with reference to food and cooking. In 1995, she founded Daily Life Ltd to make art that â€œexplores and celebrates everyday life and human behaviourâ€. Her artworkAn Edible Family in a Mobile Home, originally created in 1976 and featuring a family composed of cakes, biscuits and meringues, is at theWhitworth, Manchester, until 20 April. Baker lives and works in London.View image in fullscreen1.BookWifedom by Anna FunderI listened to this on Audible, which is my favourite thing to do when Iâ€™m painting and drawing and buzzing about. It tells the story of George Orwellâ€™s wife, Eileen Oâ€™Shaughnessy. Funder expresses her passion for Orwell, but in all the biographies written about him, by men, she found scarcely a mention of his wife. Eileen was so fundamentally a part of his work and his life. Itâ€™s such a revelation how hard their existence was, and how much she supported him. Itâ€™s anastonishing account, moving, tragic but also fascinating. Really worth reading.2.PlaceThe Mall Wood Green, London N22View image in fullscreenâ€˜Architecturally grim but I have enormous affection for itâ€™: The Mall Wood Green, north London.Photograph: Matthew Chattle/AlamyI am, I would say, a naturally gifted shopper. I just love shopping and I get very excited in supermarkets and covered markets. Itâ€™s shopping for anything â€“ art materials or kitchen utensils or whatever. We moved to Wood Green a few years ago and Iâ€™ve started going to this shopping centre much more. Architecturally it looks pretty grim but I have enormous affection for it. A few years ago they set up one of these NHS health assessment centres inside [the mall], which is so convenient. My favourite bit is the kitchenware shop [Karaca]; the guy who runs it is rather assertive that everything they stock is the best.3.GalleryNational Gallery, LondonWC2NView image in fullscreenChrist and the Woman of Samaria by Duccio MaestÃ , from Siena â€“ The Rise of Painting 1300-1350, at the National Gallery, London until 22 June.Photograph: Duccio/Museo Nacional Thyssen- Bornemisza, MadridThe National Gallery has to be the tops, really. As an art student, I very frequently went in there and copied paintings, particularly Cezanneâ€™sLes Grandes Baigneuses. What with life and family, I find it really difficult to get to galleries, and Iâ€™ve had so much surgery over the years that I live a lot online â€“ on the National Gallery website you can access the catalogue and look at paintings really close up. But Iâ€™m determined to spend more time in the actual gallery. Theyâ€™ve got a new show on aboutSienese paintingthat Iâ€™m really looking forward to.View image in fullscreen4.PodcastThe Week in ArtMy passion is painting and sculpture, truly, but I was very disillusioned with that back in the early 70s: it was so elitist and male. So I got into performance art, which was extraordinarily liberating. Now, through all these brilliant podcasts, Iâ€™m learning more about the visual arts.The Week in Artis absolutely my favourite. The host Ben Luke has got such a wonderful voice. The last episode I listened to was aboutAnselm Kiefer. I used to be very passionate about his work, and the extremely interesting conversation with the curator reignited my enthusiasm. For a disabled person, the online world is extraordinarily enriching.5.TheatreSh!t Theatre: Or Whatâ€™s Left of UsView image in fullscreenâ€˜Really so movingâ€™: Sh!t Theatre: Or Whatâ€™s Left of Us, performed by Rebecca Biscuit and Louise Mothersole at the Soho theatre, London.Photograph: PR HandoutSh!t Theatre should be on the NHS. They are an incredibly talented company, clever and witty but also quite political, and they take on unusual subject matter. The director they worked with,Adam Brace, died suddenly in 2023, so this latest show is, in a very helpful, thoughtful way, dealing with grief. Itâ€™s about their visit to a folk club in Leeds to do research, and all the people they meet there, and itâ€™s interspersed with singing. It was really so moving. The run at the Soho theatre is over now, but they are touring the showinApril.6.TVCrime dramaWatch a trailer for Virdee.As Iâ€™ve grown older, Iâ€™ve got into crime drama. I find it powerful and itâ€™s often incredibly well written. My absolute favourite isLaw& Order: Special Victims Unitwith the fantastic Mariska Hargitay â€“ I just watch and rewatch it. I also love the Irish seriesKinand the Bradford-setVirdee, both about organised crime. AndThe Turkish Detective, which is stunningly shot and very exciting. And of course the absolute best isHappy Valley. It must be something to do with watching baddies who do terrible things getting caught â€“ when youâ€™re older, you need that catharsis.Explore more on these topicsCultureOn my radarArtPodcastsTheatreTV crime dramaTelevisionfeaturesShareReuse this content

title: Another Simple Favor review â€“ supremely silly sequel serves more absurd twists | SXSW | The Guardian
description: Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively return in Amazonâ€™s ridiculous yet glossily enjoyable follow-up to 2018â€™s fan favorite
Author: Adrian Horton
Headline: Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively return in Amazonâ€™s ridiculous yet glossily enjoyable follow-up to 2018â€™s fan favorite
Content: Anna Kendrick in Another Simple Favor.Photograph: Lorenzo SistiView image in fullscreenAnna Kendrick in Another Simple Favor.Photograph: Lorenzo SistiFirst look reviewSXSWReviewAnother Simple Favor review â€“ supremely silly sequel serves more absurd twistsSXSW film festival:Anna Kendrick and Blake Lively return in Amazonâ€™s ridiculous yet glossily enjoyable follow-up to 2018â€™s fan favoriteAdrian Hortonin Austin, TexasSat 8 Mar 2025 10.26 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 15.38 ESTShareOn paper, there are plenty of reasons to make a follow-up to A Simple Favor, Paul Feigâ€™s 2018 comic mystery film starringAnna Kendrickand Blake Lively as two delusive, scheming suburban moms. Though it gestured at being a serious thriller â€“ a sort of Gone Girl for cable â€“ the film, based on the 2017 novel by Darcey Bell, ultimately devolved into ridiculousness, untethered from logic yet with plenty of road for more twists. Livelyâ€™s Emily Nelson, an archly manipulative psychopath straight out of a Justin Baldoni lawsuit, remains her best work since Gossip Girl. And most pertinent to Amazon MGM studios, the film found post-theatrical success on streaming, becoming a modern camp classic during the pandemic.The Electric State review â€“ Millie Bobby Brownâ€™s bot war yarn is soulless digital contentRead moreBut Feig, by his own admission at theSXSWfilm festival on Friday evening, is wary of sequels, and for good reason â€“ rarely does lightning strike twice, especially in suburban Connecticut. A Simple Favor ended in settled-enough fashion, with (spoiler alert) Emily in prison for the murder of her secret identical twin sister and attempted murder of her husband, with Kendrickâ€™s Stephanie, a successful mommy vlogger, and their hapless mutual ex Sean (Henry Golding) living in peace in San Diego.Feigâ€™s reservations were warranted: Another Simple Favor, again written by Jessica Sharzer along with Laeta Kalogridis, unsurprisingly does not match the intoxicating magic of the original, which feinted at something sinister and twisted in the facades of motherhood before plunging off the deep end. It is neither suspenseful nor thrilling, but something else: a movie so confidently ridiculous, so stylishly absurd and so self-aware of its mandate for fun that you canâ€™t help but enjoy it, reasonable wariness â€“ and all reason, really â€“ be damned.Another Simple Favor picks up where the first one left off, in that it begins in its latent camp sensibilities and barrels full-force into unabashed silliness. As with the original, Kendrickâ€™s ever-peppy and self-effacing Stephanie opens the proceedings in medias res, vlogging (or, because itâ€™s 2025, livestreaming) from house arrest in Italy. Why? How? She recaps for her followers: she has spent the intervening years baking zucchini bread and solving Redditâ€™s best mysteries with haunting results, once again revealed in pulpy flashbacks. Her fellow Connecticut moms, played by Kelly McCormack, Aparna Nancherla and Andrew Rannells, are as bitchy as ever. And Emily, now the â€œfaceless blondâ€ of Stephanieâ€™s under-selling true-crime memoir, is walking free, sprung from prison by the generosity of her mysterious new fiance, an Italian hunk/mob heir named, yes, Dante (Michele Morrone).Emily crashes Stephanieâ€™s sparsely attended book reading, slo-mo strut and jumpsuit-chic outfit on lock, with a request thatâ€™s less another simple favor than a massive, confounding ask: be her maid of honor at her lavish wedding in Capri? Stephanie accepts, which is the first sign that this movie will be uncovering new shades of the word â€œludicrousâ€ at every turn. From the minute Emilyâ€™s private jet takes flight, Another Simple Favor abandons any pretense of seriousness or grounding â€“ in fact, the first movieâ€™s deranged plot twists serve as the bread and butter of this sequelâ€™s many in-jokes, the characters quick to point out the whole perverse web of backstabbing deceit as it grows ever more complex and unhinged.Italian mob weddings being what they are, the blood begins to spill almost as soon as the guests arrive. Goldingâ€™s Sean is there, now more surly and pathetic (and naked â€“ no one can ever accuse Another Simple Favor of not knowing its audience), as well as Emilyâ€™s beloved son Nicky (Ian Ho), who is 10 going on 20 with some understandable mood issues. So, too, is Danteâ€™s unimpressed mob boss mother (Elena Sofia Ricci), Stephanieâ€™s incompetent book agent Vicky (Broadwayâ€™s Alex Newell), Emilyâ€™s senile mother (Elizabeth Perkins, taking over for Jean Smart) and her long-lost loony aunt Linda (Allison Janney), rounding out a cast of one-dimensional characters who test oneâ€™s patience but ultimately do not distract from the mission of smooth-brained amusement. (Janney, especially, can do a lot with a little.)Another Simple Favor drops threads and drags on, but survives on its self-assured baseline pleasures: the gorgeous yet nonsensical setting of Capri, the lush wonders of RenÃ©e Ehrlich Kalfusâ€™s costume design (Lively once again sports a murderersâ€™ row of completely impractical suits) and the two leadsâ€™ perfectly calibrated banter, at once winking and convincing. Lively, especially, shines in her grand return performance amid the widely scrutinized legal battle surroundingIt Ends with Us. The slippery Emily is a particular pitch of bemused psycho that could easily tip into cartoonish or smug, and she holds it. Kendrickâ€™s comic timing, meanwhile, remains sharp as a tack. Without both, the whole pageant would collapse.And it nearly does. Feigâ€™s crisp direction notwithstanding, Another Simple Favor attempts some plot twists better left unsaid and forgotten. But even overstaying its welcome at two hours, soaring past the boundaries of taste and reaching the astral plane of should-be offensive absurdity cannot derail the experience of watching these toxic frenemies back in action. It may not be the next chapter we needed, but more money-mandated sequels could stand to have this little self-seriousness.Another Simple Favor is screening at the SXSW film festival and will be available on Amazon Prime Video on 1 MayExplore more on these topicsSXSWFirst look reviewBlake LivelyPaul FeigAnna KendrickComedy filmsFestivalsComedyreviewsShareReuse this content

title: â€˜Whatâ€™s wrong with us?â€™ : Novelist Virginia Feito on our morbid obsession with true crime | Books | The Guardian
description: Her debut, Mrs March, is being adapted by Elisabeth Moss, and her new novel has already been snapped up for the screen. Virginia Feito reveals the real-life inspiration for her shocking story of a psychopathic Victorian nanny
Author: Sam Jones
Headline: Her debut, Mrs March, is being adapted by Elisabeth Moss, and her new novel has already been snapped up for the screen. Virginia Feito reveals the real-life inspiration for her shocking story of a psychopathic Victorian nanny
Content: â€˜This one felt like it had to be a rageâ€™ â€¦ Virginia Feito.Photograph: Pilar HormaecheaView image in fullscreenâ€˜This one felt like it had to be a rageâ€™ â€¦ Virginia Feito.Photograph: Pilar HormaecheaBooksInterviewâ€˜Whatâ€™s wrong with us?â€™ : Novelist Virginia Feito on our morbid obsession with true crimeSam JonesHer debut, Mrs March, is being adapted by Elisabeth Moss, and her new novel has already been snapped up for the screen. Virginia Feito reveals the real-life inspiration for her shocking story of a psychopathic Victorian nannySat 8 Mar 2025 03.00 ESTLast modified on Sat 8 Mar 2025 03.55 ESTShareWhatever people make of Virginia Feitoâ€™s new book, a scabrous, morbidly funny murder ballad, they canâ€™t say they werenâ€™t warned. Thanks to several instances of real andÂ imagined violence to men, women, children and babies â€“ not to mention aÂ deer, a duck and three whippets â€“ Victorian Psycho lives up to its name, and to the first sentence of its prologue: â€œDeath everywhere.â€â€œItâ€™s not like a surprising twist that builds slowly over the pages,â€ the 36-year-old Spanish writer says of herÂ second novel. â€œYou know where weâ€™re going from the very start.â€Feitoâ€™s debut,Mrs Marchâ€“ which explored a wealthy, Upper East Side womanâ€™s descent into suffocating paranoia â€“ earned comparisons to Patricia Highsmith and Daphne du Maurier. Like its predecessor, Victorian Psycho is written in English and has already been snapped up for ascreen adaptation. But it is, quite deliberately, a radically different book.The novel, whose title is a hat-tip toÂ  both Bret Easton Ellis and the 19th-century literature Feito grew up on, chronicles the homicidal thoughts andÂ deeds of Winifred Notty, aÂ governess who arrives at a remote country house in Yorkshire with ratherÂ more than the imparting of aÂ traditional education in mind.â€œEver since I was little, Iâ€™ve loved gothic horror and I think thereâ€™s a lot inÂ the childrenâ€™s literature that I was reading from a very young age, likeThe Secret Garden,â€ says Feito in the flawless English that is the product ofÂ her time in an American school in ParisÂ and a British school in Madrid. â€œThat book starts with a cholera epidemic thatâ€™s killed everyone and Mary is alone in her bungalow in India,Â which is the most gothic thingÂ Iâ€™ve ever read. And then thereâ€™s aÂ bit ofÂ gothic in Roald Dahl, who is aÂ huge inspiration â€“ especially his shortÂ stories.â€Feito also loved the BrontÃ«s and Dickens, but with Victorian Psycho, she says, she wanted to creep into theÂ darker recesses of the 19th century. SoÂ parts of the book are inspired by theÂ crimes of killers such asConstance Kent, who slit the throat of her half-brother and threw his body down a privy, andAmelia Dyer, the â€œbaby farmerâ€ thought to have murdered asÂ many as 400 infants placed in herÂ care.If her debut was a deeply disturbing satire on social conventions, Feito turns up the volume in the new novel, â€œbecause it was fun, but also because they did drip belladonna into their eyeballs!â€ (A poisonous Victorian beauty hack to make your pupils dilate.)â€œItâ€™s not that I was limiting myself with Mrs March, but this one felt like it had to be arage,â€ says Feito. She notes that the new bookâ€™s publication comes at a time when issues of female anger and physicality are being explored inÂ films such asTitaneandThe Substance. Victorian Psycho plays with the eraâ€™s demure Angel in the House stereotypes by giving the reader a protagonist without inhibitions, filters or limits.â€œI guess I was kind of poking at that:Â what if the evil psychopath were female this time?â€ she says. â€œWhat does that mean? And will readers justify her because sheâ€™s female?â€ Feito wants to see how far she can push things before the reader begins to lose sympathy for the abused and vengeful Notty.skip past newsletter promotionSign up toBookmarksFree weekly newsletterDiscover new books and learn more about your favourite authors with our expert reviews, interviews and news stories. Literary delights delivered direct to youEnter your email addressSign upPrivacy Notice:Newsletters may contain info about charities, online ads, and content funded by outside parties. For more information see ourPrivacy Policy. We use Google reCaptcha to protect our website and the GooglePrivacy PolicyandTerms of Serviceapply.after newsletter promotionI watch loadsÂ of true crime.Â IÂ sit there cheering them on. But then Iâ€™m like: Eurrgh! Why are we soÂ morbid?Todayâ€™s culture, she argues, seems to have lost its fear of psychopaths, with some â€“ such as TV serial killer Dexter Morgan â€“ even moving from antihero to hero. â€œYou root for them because you secretly want them to getÂ revenge against the people who wronged them,â€ says Feito. â€œI wanted to avoid that. Sure, you can feel empathy because Winifred has had an awful childhood, but Iâ€™m very explicit about the violence sheâ€™s committing againstÂ children.â€All of which raises a question: isnâ€™t she feeding the readerâ€™s appetite for Grand Guignol and depravity â€“ only to reproach them for gobbling up all the gore? Feito laughs and pretends to scold one of her readers: â€œYou love it, you sick fuck!â€ But she admits she is equally guilty. â€œI watch loads of true crime, freaking out over shows likeMonster by Ryan Murphy. Itâ€™s fun and IÂ sit there cheering them on. But then Iâ€™m like: â€˜Eurrgh! Whatâ€™s wrong with us? Why are we so morbid? These are real people who died.â€™â€Feito, who studied English and drama at Queen Mary University in London, says it was always inevitable that she would write in English rather than Spanish. The four years she spentÂ at the American school when theÂ family moved to Paris for her fatherâ€™s work proved formative. â€œI was readingÂ and writing and speaking atÂ school and watching television in English because I didnâ€™t understand French very well,â€ she says. â€œSo I clungÂ to English and I found that I tookÂ to it really, really well. YouÂ can almost add an â€˜-ingâ€™ to anything and itâ€™llÂ exist, probably. AndÂ if not, nobodyÂ will be mad. Itâ€™s soÂ much moreÂ playful.â€Femgore: why romcoms are out in womenâ€™s fiction â€“ and cannibalism is inRead moreThese days Feito says she is intimidated by her native tongue andÂ doesnâ€™t understand its rules very well. She was delighted to turn down the offer of translating Mrs March into Spanish herself â€“ â€œI couldnâ€™t; I would have destroyed itâ€ â€“ and, besides, writing in English also offers the opportunity for some entertaining back and forth with her translator, Gemma Rovira. â€œItâ€™s always fun to getÂ these emails, like: â€˜When youâ€™re slashing the babyâ€™s neck, is it penetrating the skin or is it going around it?â€™â€More seriously, it allows Feito to read her own work from a distance. â€œItÂ transforms it. Itâ€™s another animal, so to speak,â€ she says. â€œI see myself in there, but then there are other things that make me sound way smarter, which I appreciate very deeply.â€With Mrs March being developed for the screen by Elisabeth Moss, and aÂ film of Victorian Psycho, starring Margaret Qualley, also on the way, sheÂ has no regrets about her decision to leave a job in advertising a few yearsÂ ago to write full time. Now sheÂ isÂ thinking about her third novel,Â listening out for another arrestingÂ narrator.Itâ€™s an ode to the Victorian literature that I love so much, but itâ€™s also subverting itâ€œWhen I started Mrs March, I had aÂ few other ideas that were much more developed and I knew where they were going,â€ she says. â€œBut I chose Mrs March because of the voice.â€ It was the same with Winifred. â€œIt came to me in the middle of the night and itâ€™s at the beginning of the book, where she says, â€˜My breasts jiggling in my corset.â€™â€ With that one line, Feito had her protagonist and knew exactly who sheÂ was. Given Victorian Psychoâ€™s body count, carnage and general air ofÂ barely corseted ultraviolence, does she see it as a feminist, revisionist takeÂ on the 19th-century novel? As aÂ parody? AÂ homage?Mrs March by Virginia Feito review â€“ a brilliant psychological studyRead moreâ€œI think itâ€™s all those things,â€ FeitoÂ says. â€œItâ€™s an ode to the Victorian literature that I love so much but itâ€™s also subverting it. To be fair, there was a lot of death and violence and the grotesque in Dickens. But he ended itÂ in a hopeful way and he didnâ€™t delveÂ into the most graphic aspects becauseÂ readers werenâ€™t really ready. ButÂ IÂ think weâ€™re ready now.â€Victorian Psycho is published byÂ 4thÂ Estate.To support the Guardian and Observer, order your copy atguardianbookshop.com.
